PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder is characterized by persistent memories of traumatic events and inability to extinguish learned fear, is associated with reduced endocannabinoid signaling, and affects 13% of US veterans. Dysfunction of the endocannabinoid system causes impaired extinction and enhanced fear memory. Understanding how endocannabinoid in the cerebellar circuit controls the reconsolidation and extinction of fear memory may suggest novel pharmacological targets as therapeutic interventions for PTSD.

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study is particularly relevant because it attempts to improve adolescent drug and alcohol out- comes in the face of new drug threats—opioids, e-cigarettes, and legal marijuana. It is also relevant to study how to improve the implementation quality of drug prevention programs in schools because they play a central role in the lives of middle school youth in the US, and, up until now, schools have not been able to adopt and implement evidence-based drug prevention programs consistently. It is critical that schools effectively deliver high-quality programs to prevent adolescents from using drugs and alcohol in order to promote healthy adoles- cent development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research study proposes to conduct a single-arm clinical trial in 22 children who are suffering from severe heart failure and require a mechanical heart pump as a bridge to a heart transplant. Unlike adult heart failure patients who have access to wide variety of safe and reliable heart pumps that permit hospital discharge, smaller children do not, leaving children and their families hospitalized for up to a year until a heart transplant becomes available. The purpose of this study to evaluate a promising new heart pump for smaller children, the Jarvik 2015, that closes this enormous technology gap between adult and pediatric devices, and to provide the type of safety and effectiveness data that the FDA requires to review and potentially approve a high-risk medical device for a rare/orphan disease, like children hospitalized for severe heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a large unmet need for developing new approaches to Treatment-Resistant Depression (TRD), a highly prevalent and debilitating disorder with major impact on public health. Clinical trials investigating deep brain stimulation (DBS), a neurosurgical approach widely used in neurological disorders, in the treatment of TRD have led to inconsistent results, possibly due to inadequate technology to precisely identify, target, and modulate the abnormal networks that mediate this disorder. The proposed studies will investigate the feasibility and safety of using a next-generation DBS system to “steer” stimulation simultaneously to two different brain regions implicated in TRD that may lead to new and better treatments for this and other severe neuropsychiatric disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latin American descended populations, which constitute the fastest growing ethnicity in the United States, are poorly represented in psychiatric genetics research. We will reverse this underrepresentation, accelerating discoveries and reducing health disparities by creating the Latin American Biobank for Severe Mental Illness (LAB-SMI), consisting of 50,000 SMI cases and 50,000 population controls ascertained by screening electronic medical records (EMR) from the Paisa region of Colombia. We will genotype and conduct genetic analyses of SMI in this 100K sample, and better characterize SMI through analyses of the longitudinal EMR.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Achilles tendinopathy is a painful condition that does not fully resolve in 20-60% of patients following conservative treatment. In this study, we will determine rehabilitation loading profiles and ultrasound imaging biomarkers that explain tendon healing and functional outcomes in patients. We will also measure circulating levels of sex hormones to determine how variations in sex hormones impact tendon healing and outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective, brief, low-cost interventions for individuals who attempt suicide are needed to save lives and achieve the goals of the National Strategy for Suicide Prevention. In response to a NIMH Notice of Interest, this time- sensitive proposal leverages an existing federal investment in Zero Suicide to test the effectiveness of a highly promising new treatment for recent suicide attempt survivors and learn how it works. If hypotheses are supported, the study will provide evidence of a brief, practical, and cost-effective therapy that reduces suicide reattempts in a real-world health setting.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective, school-based interventions are urgently needed to protect adolescents from initiating or continuing use of electronic vaping products (EVPs). This study leverages a state-supported prevention initiative to test the effectiveness of a promising intervention that trains 8th -9th grade student peer leaders to deliver school- wide vaping prevention campaigns with ongoing adult mentoring. If study hypotheses are supported, the study will provide the first evidence of a school-based preventive intervention that reduces adolescent vaping behaviors, as well as insight into how peer communications can be harnessed to prevent vaping.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current techniques for peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosis are not suited to low-cost, high-throughput, and accurate screening and surveillance. Modern deep learning (DL) and arterial pulse waveform analysis can be combined to enhance the convenience and efficacy of PAD diagnosis but at the cost of unrealistically large datasets. In this project, we will study the feasibility of DL-enabled pulse waveform analysis for PAD diagnosis by developing a novel computational method to efficiently train DL algorithms using scare datasets.

PHR: Medication treatment of Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) saves lives and is increasingly delivered virtually. However, toxicology testing, a major component of MOUD care, is either not completed as part of virtual care or requires in-person urine testing, which is inconvenient and stigmatizing. A process of Virtual Point-of-Care Toxicology Testing will increase convenience, facilitate patient-centered care, and decrease stigma, improving MOUD utilization and patient outcomes. This research will design a Virtual Point-of-Care Toxicology Testing Process, using feedback from VA-wide leaders, providers, and patients. A pilot trial will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and proximal effects of the process by analyzing provider and patient testing uptake, qualitative feedback, and health service use. The process will be packaged into a toolkit for VA-wide dissemination, as well as testing in a future multisite, randomized effectiveness trial.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Obesity is a major cause of preventable diseases and deaths in the United States. Over 40% of Veterans using Veterans Health Administration (VA) primary care have obesity. However, less than 8% of eligible Veterans use VA’s effective weight management programs. EMBER – a novel, motivational, self-help tool – could increase Veterans’ engagement in weight management programs. Greater Veteran engagement in these programs would have a large impact on Veterans’ health, including weight loss and associated improvements in physical health, function, and quality of life. EMBER’s flexible design will facilitate the incorporation of new weight management programs as they are introduced as VA services. In addition, it may be of particular value to Veterans of color, given their high obesity rates. Finally, EMBER is patient-centered, which will facilitate Veterans’ engagement in treatments aligned with their needs and interests, while ensuring appropriate use of VA resources.

PHR: As many as 7 out of 10 Veterans have high blood pressure while in the hospital. Many doctors and nurses treat this high blood pressure with quick-acting blood pressure medications, even if the patient has no symptoms. Currently, there are no guidelines to say that this is the right thing to do. Also, recent studies show that treating high blood pressure in the hospital with quick-acting medicines may lead to very low blood pressure, kidney failure, stroke, falls and other harms, especially in older patients with other chronic illnesses like Veterans. With this study, we will find out how often doctors treat high blood pressure in VA hospitals with quick-acting medicines and talk to doctors and nurses about what makes them decide to treat. We will use this information to, in later projects, develop a tool to help doctors and nurses use these medications the right way. We hope that our research will, in the long term, improve the quality, safety and cost of hospital care for our Veterans.

ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Despite primary hyperparathyroidism being a common endocrine disease, which can lead to significant preventable complications (including kidney stones, severe bone weakening and fractures, depression, gastrointestinal problems, renal dysfunction, body aches and other symptoms, all of which decrease the quality of life), previous research has shown severe under-detection of the disease in the VA healthcare system and undertreatment of it with the recommended surgery. The proposed study will explore the underlying reasons for these findings, and it will harness the medical providers’ perceptions on the management of the disease in their practice, as well as their input on proposed interventions. These findings will lead to a robust, data-based design of corrective interventions that can effectively bridge the observed gap in care and increase the safety and value of the VA healthcare system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is the deadliest parasitic disease on the planet. The search for a vaccine against malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum has lasted for more than 100 years, yet no vaccine with acceptable efficacy in the field for malaria has so far been developed. In this project, we will use a rodent malaria model to optimize the formulation of a CDPK5 based vaccine using fusion antigen CDPK5-MSPs in combination with GARP.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Language comprehension is necessary for effective human communication and social function. Therefore, when it breaks down, as it does in many neurodevelopmental and acquired disorders, such as schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorders, the consequences can be devastating. This grant uses multimodal neuroimaging techniques to ask fundamental questions about the neural and computational mechanisms underlying language comprehension in healthy adults, laying essential groundwork for the development of theoretically motivated prevention and remediation strategies to target specific communication deficits across multiple neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders.

PHR: Rates of sexually transmitted infection (STI), especially gonorrhea and chlamydia, have increased dramatically over the past decade. However, screening remains suboptimal. Women are more vulnerable to the effects of STIs than men and are disproportionately affected by STIs. Several factors put women Veterans at higher risk for STIs as compared with both non-Veteran women and male Veterans. Few studies have examined the epidemiology of STIs in women Veterans and none has assessed health system responses to STIs or examined patterns of STI screening among women Veterans. To establish an appropriate and effective prevention plan, it is necessary to understand the current landscape of STI screening in VA. This study will assess and explore practice-, provider-, and patient-level correlates and barriers/facilitators to gonorrhea and chlamydia screening in VA women’s health. This information will be used to develop and pilot a clinical decision support tool to improve gonorrhea and chlamydia screening for women Veterans.

PHR: The Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA) reports that, in Fiscal Year 2018, tinnitus was the most prevalent service-connected (SC) disability for all compensation recipients (1,971,201 Veterans), as well as the most prevalent SC disability among new compensation recipients (157,152 Veterans). Treatments claiming to reduce the sound of tinnitus show promise, but they need reliable measures of tinnitus features such as its loudness, pitch, and maskability. The previous study found age-specific standard ranges for these measurements using our computer-automated Tinnitus Evaluation System (TES). The new study will expand the previous study to: represent all age groups equally, obtain test-retest data over an extended period of time, test a pre-test training program for tinnitus pitch matching, and update the TES for ease of use in VA Audiology clinics. This project will result in more complete standards of tinnitus measurements and state-of-the-art equipment that will promote valid and reliable measurement of how tinnitus sounds to Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research will significantly contribute to our understanding of brachial plexus strains and forces that lead to spinal cord injury and the resulting injury mechanisms. Also, data obtained from acute injury biomarkers and computational models can guide the development of clinical tools that aid in treatment and prevention of spinal cord injury due to brachial plexus stretch. Overall, the proposed study is directly aligned with the NIH high priority research areas by offering data that can be used to develop prevention strategies for neonatal brachial plexus palsy and associated spinal cord injury occurrence and their outcomes while advancing the science of neonatal care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sixty percent of parents of young children with type 1 diabetes report at least moderate levels of hypoglycemia fear, which is associated with poor quality of life and compensatory behaviors that raise children’s blood glucose levels and risk for diabetes-related complications. This study is relevant to public health because it proposes to conduct a randomized clinical trial comparing an innovative, video-based telemedicine intervention to reduce parental hypoglycemia fear to a video-based telemedicine attention control intervention in families of young children with type 1 diabetes. The long-term goal of this line of research is to develop and disseminate effective and scalable treatments for families of young children with type 1 diabetes that help children to achieve and maintain optimal glycemic control, thereby improving health outcomes and reducing their risk of diabetes-related complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Major liver surgery is a very common procedure and liver ischemia and reperfusion injury is a major clinical problem. Many patients suffer complications from liver surgery including acute kidney injury, intestinal barrier disfunction and systemic inflammatory response syndrome leading to sepsis. In this translational proposal, we will determine whether 1) cynomolgus monkey and human liver IR injury cause small intestinal Paneth cells to dysregulate and release IL-17A and 2) IL-17A neutralizing antibody attenuates hepatic as well as acute kidney injury after liver IR in cynomolgus monkeys.

PHR: This VHA Career Development Award will ensure Dr. Hayes’s expertise in translating knowledge gained from electronic health record (EHR) data and predictive analytics (e.g., predicting the future probability of an outcome for individuals) into interventions that increase Veterans’ retention in medication treatment for opioid use disorder (MOUD; e.g., buprenorphine). His specific training areas span the spectrum of learning advanced methods for working with EHR data, how to develop computer-based tools, and how to test the effectiveness of new interventions. Dr. Hayes will apply this new knowledge to (a) develop a mathematical model that will continuously assess Veterans’ risk of discontinuing MOUD, (b) create a computer-delivered clinical tool that provides clinicians with information (i.e., patient-specific likelihood risk, patient-specific risk factors for discontinuing MOUD, and treatment guidelines, when indicated) on Veterans’ risk of discontinuing MOUD, and (c) test the feasibility/acceptability of the clinical tool among VHA providers who are prescribing buprenorphine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Two human cytochrome P450 enzymes produce distinct hormones controlling blood pressure and stress/immune responses, respectively. Decreasing production of these hormones can treat high blood pressure and other diseases, but it is challenging to make drugs that impair just one of these two highly similar enzymes, thus limiting undesirable side effects. The proposed work will determine key structural information of one of these enzymes, thereby facilitate the design of drugs complementary to just one enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health because it aims to better understand neural encoding and processing of electrical stimulation in children with cochlear nerve deficiency (CND) - a poorly understood hearing disorder affecting up to 19% of children with congenital sensorineural hearing loss. Results from this study will have 1) a broad impact on the field by establishing how variations in neural survival of cochlear nerve fibers affect neural encoding of electrical stimulation in both the cochlear nerve and the central auditory system; and 2) a targeted impact on children with CND who are cochlear implant users by laying the groundwork for developing an effective, evidence-based clinical practice for managing these patients. This project is relevant to the mission of NIH because it seeks fundamental knowledge about the nature of electrical hearing in patients with CND and strives to apply this knowledge to reduce disability in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Motor deficits after stroke are a major source of disability. Stimulation of the brain during therapy may accelerate recovery, especially of hand function. We will test a new form of stimulation that uses timing based on brain activity to improve recovery from stroke.

ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Pancreatic cancer is a deadly cancer with increasing incidence for which no systematic efforts to reduce diagnostic delays exist. Our preliminary work shows that 40% of Veterans with pancreatic cancer experience diagnostic delays of  90 days and 40% experience missed opportunities to initiate or complete their diagnostic evaluation in a timely manner. Opportunities for more timely diagnosis of pancreatic cancer are possible in the VA, and the work put forth in this proposal tries to identify and transform these opportunities into decision support tools. In this project, we will: (1) identify potential missed opportunities for pancreatic cancer diagnosis; (2) develop electronic trigger (e-trigger) tools aimed at identifying high-risk patients with potential missed opportunities for pancreatic cancer diagnosis; and (3) assess local stakeholders’ views of facilitators and barriers to implementation of e-triggers for future application in clinical practice. These aims will be aligned with career development and training activities including formal coursework and a structured mentorship plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 44 million Americans experience some hearing loss, but as much as 86% of adults who could benefit from hearing aid devices (HAD) do not use them. HAD usage is disproportionately lower among rural and minority (black, Hispanic/Latino) populations. Concerns about access, cost, comfort, effectiveness and satisfaction are key barriers to HAD usage. Self-adjustment enables users to pick HAD gain (amplification) settings according to the users’ widely varying individual preferences, which has been shown to significantly increase listener satisfaction and acceptance. Automating HAD gain settings with the use of machine learning (ML) techniques will reduce costs while improving intelligibility, comfort and increase the ease of use. As OTC HADs become available, this will lead to much higher adoptions of HADs in the rural and minority communities, improving their quality of life.

PHR: Project Narrative Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) is a noninvasive therapy which relies on the nuclear capture and fission reactions for treating locally invasive malignant tumors such as glioma. In last 30-40 years, the lack of effective intracellular delivery methods for Boron-10 molecules specifically to the glioma cells has been the major limiting factor for the successful BNCT. Our proven, nanodrug based methodology to transport drugs across multiple biological barrier including blood-brain barrier to gliomas provides the missing link, thereby making BNCT a practical therapy for glioma treatment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will be a secondary data analysis of the nationally-representative and longitudinal dataset, National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (1994-2018). We will examine the extent to which adolescent social networks are predictive of dental utilization. The overall impact of this research will increase our understanding of the relationship between social networks and oral health outcomes, apply rigorous social network analytic methods to dental health research, and inform novel approaches to interventions that improve dental utilization in an age range that has persistent untreated dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are prevalent in the general population and they are often considered benign, but frequent PVC may impair heart muscle function in certain individuals. It is often unclear when patients present with heart failure and PVCs if removing PVCs through an invasive procedure or suppressing them with medications would improve heart function. This study is aimed at studying PVCs with new imaging techniques to identify which PVCs are pathologic and should be treated and which PVCs are benign and can be left alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative:  Cerebrospinal fluid flow is critical for maintaining brain health and clearing metabolic waste products from the brain. Both respiration and neural activity are thought to play a role in driving CSF flow. This project will test the role of both respiratory and noninvasive neurostimulation interventions in regulating CSF flow, laying the foundation for future clinical studies seeking to test therapeutic impact of altering CSF flow in clinical populations.

PHR: Narrative  The goal of this project is to demonstrate the feasibility for the commercialization of the CervicalMethDx Test, a precision methylation test in self-collected samples to stratify Latina women for high risk of cervical  cancer. Latinas have the highest cervical cancer prevalence and incidence rates in United States and Puerto  Rico. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uncontrolled epilepsy affects over 1.5 million Americans and is characterized by recurrent seizures that impact physical and mental well-being. These impacts can be mitigated by continuous seizure monitoring with wearable devices, but while most wearable seizure monitoring has focused on generalized tonic-clonic seizures, here we propose a new paradigm for focal seizure monitoring using commonly available biosensors on a popular consumer wearable device. Successful development and validation will significantly improve the lives of patients, caregivers and physicians by promoting independence, peace-of-mind, and better epilepsy control.

PHR: Home-based hematopoietic stem cell transplant (home HCT) has the potential to improve patient health, quality of life, and function as well as caregiver well-being outcomes by bringing hospital-level care and resources to the home setting, simplifying logistics for caregivers while also providing intensive support tailored to individual patient and caregiver needs at home. Although increased staffing will be needed upfront, overall costs and resource utilization may be reduced by keeping patients at home.

PHR: This program of research using a mixed methods approach will reveal new insights into what matters most to Veterans discharged to post-acute care, and how best to align care with their values and goals. With the aging Veteran population and rising costs of care, the VA will need robust evaluation of Veteran priorities and outcomes across post-acute care settings to inform policy decisions. Choice of post-acute care type may be one of the highest-points to influence value and improve Veteran-relevant outcomes– given if individuals are unable to recover, they frequently go on to long-term care at an extraordinary expense to themselves and the VA. However, Veterans values and priorities for post-acute care are unknown, and our approach will establish important patient-centered outcomes for the VA to consider in achieving high-value post-acute care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: We propose to develop a novel theranostic formulation of nanoparticles that accumulates in prostate cancer cells through a specific chemical reaction initiated by the tumor-specific enzyme legumain. The formulation consists of self-assembled olsalazine molecules that can provide contrast on MRI scans and simultaneously inhibits cell division, which allows us to see if the tumor takes up the drug and if this uptake leads to inhibition of tumor growth. This is important, as we may then be able to predict early on if the tumor will eventually respond to treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 100 million people in the US suffer from at least one neurological disease, many of which arise from perturbations in neuronal differentiation and/or circuit formation. Our research leverages the powerful Drosophila genetic model system to uncover the cellular, developmental, and genetic basis of neuronal differentiation, neural circuit formation, and behavior. Given the highly conserved nature of nervous system development from flies to humans, our work holds significant promise to inform on the cellular, developmental, and genetic basis of neurological diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viruses can attack their human hosts in various ways—sometimes causing a rapid onset of symptoms, as in the case with the Ebola virus, which causes disease by causing apoptosis in many different host cells; other viruses, such as HIV, are characterized by a slow onset of symptoms and long-term persistence, with disease becoming apparent only after months or even years as they modify hosts cells to resist natural cell death pathways, becoming “virus factories,” which produce high levels of virus for extended periods of time. Our goal, to repress these cell death resistance mechanisms in HIV-infected cells, will allow the present viral proteins to trigger HIV-infected cell death and eradicate HIV from the infected patient and cure the HIV infection. Successful completion of the aims of this grant will benefit not only those cured of HIV, but will also reduce the spread of HIV infection, decrease the frequency of HIV resistance, and reduce the complications of living with HIV and HIV therapies.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: My research is focused on predictive modeling, quality measurement and management, and implementation and de-implementation science. I will use the research career scientist (RCS) award to extend my programs of research in three high-impact areas. First, many health conditions have several competing treatment options but clinicians and patients do not have accurate information about which patients are most likely to benefit from which treatments. To realize the promise of “precision medicine”, accurate patient-specific prediction models need to be developed, validated, and methods to integrate the predictions into informed consent and shared decision-making need to be tested. Second, research on the effects of healthcare quality measurement is essential to ensure that our systems of accountability are having the intended effects. Finally, designing and testing strategies to get healthcare systems to provide higher quality care and to stop providing care that is unsafe, ineffective, or low value represents an enduring scientific and organizational priority.

PHR: Clinical provider burnout is a key indicator of how well a health care system is functioning. Reducing mental health provider (MHP) burnout could improve patient access to care, quality of care, and improve employee engagement, which are core components of VHA's priorities and strategic plan. We propose to conduct the largest and most comprehensive study to date on the systematic, facility-level predictors and consequences of MHP burnout. VHA can use the findings from this longitudinal, mixed methods study to facilitative future planning and interventions to improve MHP burnout, employee engagement, and patient outcomes. Supported by a wide range of VHA and community partners and stakeholders, our findings could be of clinical and financial value to VHA, its providers, and patients. Our work will contribute to broad healthcare improvements within VHA, and will generate new insights for healthcare delivery, informing efforts to address burnout in MHPs and other clinical providers.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The efficiency of synaptic transmission relies on the maintenance of a high number of receptors at the postsynaptic membrane. This proposal will explore the role of muscle calmodulin kinase II-related anchoring protein (αkap) on synaptic development and AChR stability of healthy and compromised neuromuscular synapses. These studies will have a significant impact in understanding the basic mechanisms that underlie the stability of receptors and will be relevant to developing new approaches for treating neurological diseases where the number/density of receptors is compromised.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we investigate the neuronal underpinnings of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in the cerebellum using a combination of electrophysiological experiments and computational modeling. We will first use boundary element models of the in vitro setup to study how the conductivity boundaries in in vitro studies can distort and sometimes weaken or even reverse the induced E-field and design a solution to facilitate reliable TMS stimulation in vitro. We will then systematically characterize the cellular responses to TMS in an in vitro turtle cerebellum and then use those insights to understand the TMS responses in the human cerebellum in vivo in a saccade study.

PHR: Prion diseases are fatal neurodegenerative disorders with no curative treatment available. We have engineered a new mouse model expressing a modified prion protein that develops severe neuronal pathology similar to humans and animals with prion disease. We expect that the proposed studies will reveal protein interactions and pathways that incite neuronal death in prion disease, and will uncover new targets for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) is the second leading cause of dementia behind Alzheimer’s disease (AD) but despite the massive impact of VCID in the expanding elderly population, its pathogenesis is still only poorly understood and effective treatments are lacking. We have found that mild hypoxia triggers blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption in young mice that is exacerbated by microglial depletion, and that hypoxia-induced BBB disruption is far greater in aged mice, suggesting that microglia play an important vasculoprotective role in young mice, but this mechanism may be less effective in the aged brain. As aging induces the appearance of a “primed”, pro-inflammatory microglial phenotype, here we will test the hypothesis that : (1) mild hypoxia triggers vascular leak and microhemorrhage in the brain, resulting in neuronal damage and cognitive decline, (2) vascular disruption is worse in the aged and the hypertensive, (3) microglia play an important vasculoprotective role in stabilizing the BBB, but this declines with age, and (4) repopulating the aged brain with young microglia or attenuation of microglial activation state, could stabilize the BBB and reduce cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In many neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD), proteins accumulate outside blood vessels, causing progressive damage to the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Investigating the mechanisms of interaction between the proteins aggregates and the BBB is crucial to identify therapeutic opportunities to preserve cerebrovascular health and BBB function. This project's goals are to investigate the effects of aberrant protein aggregation on the structural and functional properties of the BBB and, conversely, to evaluate the impact of physical disruption of the BBB on aberrant protein aggregation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing evidence suggests that pure Alzheimer’s disease is rare among the human population, but strikingly a significant proportion of individuals with Alzheimer’s present with vascular comorbidities in tandem with plaque deposition. Both Alzheimer’s and VCID are a major unment medical need, with no FDA approved therapy. Defining the role of abberant astrocyte inflammatory response in these conditions and whether RelA is a factor in these responses will enable new lines of development for future therapeutic targeting of these pathways to either restrain or enhance critical facets of astrocyte response to the comorbid disease milieu.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Arteriosclerotic common carotid artery (CCA) stenosis causes chronic CCA hypoperfusion and white matter injury (WMI), which is closely related to memory loss, cognitive dysfunction and dementia. A key feature of CCA hypoperfusion is massive loss of oligodendrocytes which is the only cells for producing myelin, the major component of white matter fiber, leading to WMI. Thus, oligodendrocyte replacement therapy is a critical prerequisite for white matter restoration and cognitive dysfunction and dementia. CCA hypoperfusion activate astrocytes, which will eventually form glial scar that impedes the regeneration and reestablishment of fiber networks. The proposed experiment will use a novel strategy to convert activated astrocytes into oligodendrocytes in situ in a novel model CCA hypoperfusion models that mimic arteriosclerotic CCA stenosis. Thus, we will convert the detrimental glial scar into beneficial myelin-producing cells, restore white matter structure and function and enhance cognitive function. We expect to develop new therapeutic interventions that can repair WMI as well as cognitive dysfunction and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal neuronal activity and protein-based cellular toxicity have been a hallmark of many neurodegenerative diseases. We propose to reconcile and link these two distinct disease models by identifying how increased neuronal activity drives production of toxic proteins and possibly toxic RNA species due to a genetic mutation associated with FTD/ALS. Upon completion of this proposed work, we will establish the foundation for the cause and effect relationship between abnormal neuronal activity and toxic mechanisms that contribute to the FTD/ALS neurodegenerative disease spectrum, while revealing new therapeutic opportunities for disease intervention.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Transactive response DNA-binding protein 43 kDa (TDP-43) is linked to memory loss and abnormal behaviors in aging-related neurological disorders. The effects of neuronal TDP-43 dysregulation on brain function have been studied intensely, but its roles in non-neuronal cells like astrocytes are poorly understood. The proposed research will examine how astrocytic TDP-43 dysfunction affects astrocytic-neuronal interactions, neuronal activities, and cognitive functions, and investigate novel intercellular mechanisms underlying memory loss in neurodegenerative disease.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Over the past decade, marijuana use during pregnancy has dramatically increased in conjunction with growing legalization and accessibility; yet our understanding of how the development of the child exposed to marijuana in utero may be impacted is poor. This longitudinal birth cohort study will evaluate the effects of prenatal marijuana exposure on neurodevelopmental impairments, behavioral disorders and mental health outcomes in over 420,000 children, up to 13 years of age, who were born between 2010-2021 at Kaiser Permanente Northern California hospitals to women universally screened for prenatal use of marijuana and other substances via self-report and urine toxicology tests. Findings from this study will provide pregnant women and clinicians with much needed data about the longer-term impacts of in utero marijuana exposure on the health of the child.

PHR: Project Narrative – Sexual and Gender Minority (SGM) Mental Health In Low and Middle Income Countries (SMILE) SMILE will characterize the mental health symptomatology and needs of seven different SGM groups in three culturally and contextually distinct LMICs. Respondent Driven Sampling (RDS) as well as mass media recruitment will be used to enroll a longitudinal cohort; the cultural, contextual, interpersonal, and individual determinants of mental health outcomes over 24 months will be identified. Discrete Choice Experiments (DCEs) will be used to elicit SGM preferences for different characteristics of evidence-based mental health treatments (EBTs) that can be feasibly provided and sustained for this very vulnerable population.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VHA) faces new and significant challenges with long COVID, with 10-50% of Veterans who tested positive for COVID experiencing this condition. Long COVID can involve multiple symptoms and biologic systems, ranging in severity and regularity that can last weeks to months after initial COVID infection. One of the major challenges with long COVID is that it is difficult to diagnose since a consensus has not been reached on the criteria for defining long COVID. Lack of a universal definition of long COVID hinders needed research to identify effective treatments and management strategies. Increasingly, evidence suggests that historically underserved populations may have a higher risk of long COVID and its adverse outcomes. VHA has a unique opportunity to play a critical role in defining long COVID by leveraging its multiple high-quality data sources and to advance research on Veteran’s experiences with long COVID, including possible health inequities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Secretory cells in oviducts are essential for gamete survival and fertilization. This project utilizes a novel Drosophila model to genetically interrogate the role of conserved transcription factors in oviduct secretory cells and identify novel factors for sperm attraction and ovulation. Through this work, we will gain mechanistic insights into the precise regulation of oviduct secretions, which will aid the development of new approaches for contraception, treating infertility, and controlling malaria-bearing mosquito population.

ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Post-Acute Sequelae of SARSCoV-2 (PASC), a chronic multisymptom illness, is affecting an alarming number of Veterans infected by the COVID-19 virus. PASC symptoms are often debilitating and can include various combinations of fatigue, pain, irritable bowel, and brain fog, severely impacting health quality. Importantly, exercise is reported to worsen the symptoms of PASC, a condition of post-exertional malaise (PEM), which interferes with recovery. The causes of PASC symptoms and their exacerbation with exercise are unknown, limiting treatment options. Two candidate mechanisms are disturbed gut microbiome and neuroinflammation. The proposed research will test whether Veterans with PASC exhibit PEM and whether exercise disrupts the gut microbiome and augments neuroinflammation. This research will improve our understanding of the causes of PASC-related symptoms and begin a path towards individualized treatment. These goals are directly in line with the mission of the Department of Veterans Affairs to care for those who have served this country.

ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: An estimated 10-50% of patients develop poorly understood chronic symptoms after COVID-19 (PASC), which, for many, is phenomenologically similar to chronic multi-symptom illnesses (CMI). A meta-synthesis found patients with PASC have poor experiences with care. This is consistent with decades of research on CMI, which finds patients experience wide-spread dissatisfaction with care, resulting in low uptake of evidence- based treatments and poor health outcomes. We have led VA research efforts to improve care for Veterans with CMI which has identified three key factors that lead to positive experiences with care (termed Concordant Care). Despite strong evidence supporting this care approach, there are no interventions to train clinicians on these evidence-based practices for poorly understood conditions. The objective is to leverage this research on CMI to adapt and test if a clinician training to deliver using an evidence-based, Concordant Care approach improves VA clinicians engaging in recommended practices for Veterans with PASC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The focus of our work is to determine how mutations carbohydrate aggregates impact multiple neurological diseases and to translate this knowledge into therapies. Our proposal is built on our past discoveries and uses complementary approaches to advance our understanding of the intertwined events of cell metabolism, neurodegeneration, and neurological disease. Completion of this work will yield a better comprehension of these complex events and will allow us to translate our insights into disease mechanisms, diagnoses, and treatments.

ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US population of elderly people is rapidly growing and age-related diseases constitute a major health issue in our society; however, the cellular and molecular basis of aging and age-related disorders is poorly understood. This proposal aims to determine how autophagy – a cellular process of cytoplasmic degradation with major biological functions – modulates organismal aging. The proposed research has relevance to public health, because the mechanisms to be investigated are evolutionary conserved and the findings might ultimately provide therapies to treat aging-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates a potential new risk factor for cognitive decline, seeks to understand the underlying pathophysiology, and has high relevance to brain health. Upon completion, we will understand the impact of cerebral anatomical variations on cerebrovascular and cognitive health and its association with cognitive decline. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it will provide fundamental knowledge about brain health in humans and reduce disability associated with cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Defects in RNA-binding splice factors, prominently including TDP-43, contribute to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and the AD Related Dementia (ADRD) of Frontal Temporal Lobe Dementia; although neurons have been the primary focus of work in this field, our data suggests that reduced nuclear TDP-43 in endothelial cells of the BBB leads to leak, microvascular dysfunction and cognitive decline. Here, we assess splice factor function in the human BBB endothelium with age and in AD and ADRD, and test the consequences of these defects on BBB function. Our findings will reveal how alterations in TDP-43 and other endothelial RNA-binding proteins contribute to AD and ADRD, potentially providing a readily accessible target to slow disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related cognitive decline and dementia put an increasingly heavy burden on patients, families, and communities, and may be slowed or in many cases preventable if the key mechanisms can be identified. One of such mechanisms can be the life-time arterial vascular impacts on cerebral white matter, the portion of the brain connecting different brain regions. This study will track the lifespan relationships between several vascular functional mechanisms and white matter lifespan changes, to identify the key mechanisms that may aid prevention efforts against vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease and promote normal, successful aging.

PHR: This proposal is the first attempt to address the role of post-translational modification of neuronal type2 ryanodine receptor (RyR2) as a potential contributing factor in amyloid-β (Aβ) depositions and disruption of intracellular calcium homeostasis that contributes to cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Our proposal also introduces a novel therapeutic approach to AD using a new class of orally available small molecule Rycal drugs that target intracellular calcium leak.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) tightly regulates the ﬂow of factors from the blood into the brain. Breakdown of the BBB has been associated with cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease, but the molecular mechanisms linking BBB dysfunction with Alzheimer's disease are not fully understood. Genetic studies of Alzheimer's disease have implicated a set of genes that are active in cells of the BBB. Here, we will use an entirely human experimental system to determine the function and mechanisms of action of these genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Declining brain vasculature is a key, but understudied, component of several age – associated neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias. The research described in this proposal uses a combination of bioinformatics, mouse studies and human pluripotent stem cell modeling to identify and characterize novel AD-related pathways and factors involved in the maintenance or deterioration of blood vessels and the blood-brain barrier. Identifying factors that slow or reverse the decline of brain vasculature could be a new therapeutic avenue for these devastating and deadly disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: TDP-43 pathology has been seen in a number of neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanism by which TDP-43 contributes to cellular toxicity is still not fully understood. Our recent results from a large ALS and FTD patient profiling consortium have shown that TDP-43 normally regulates expression of retrotransposons and that elevation of retrotransposons accompanies TDP-43 pathology in human cortex. Retrotransposons have been shown to be both neuroinflammatory and neurotoxic in other disease contexts, and thus their ability to contribute to TDP-43 pathomechanisms will form the focus on this proposal.

PHR: The suicide rate among female Veterans is a growing concern, yet very little research has sought to understand how to alleviate risk among this group. As such, we know surprisingly little about the health and psychosocial experiences, healthcare utilization, or barriers to care for female Veterans at risk for suicide. By interviewing Veterans about their lived experiences with suicidal thoughts, suicide attempts, and recovery needs, we will begin to develop an understanding of female Veterans' risk. Then, we will follow a large cohort of female and male Veterans over time to develop and test an explanatory model of female Veterans' risk. Findings from this study will reveal which health and psychosocial experiences are predictive of suicide attempts among female Veterans as well as which healthcare services and barriers to care require attention, providing much-needed evidence to guide the selection of intervention targets and direct valuable suicide prevention resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children; although aggressive treatments have improved outcomes, many patients still die of their disease, and survivors suffer severe long-term side effects from the therapy. Our previous studies have identified pathways that are critical for growth of medulloblastoma, and uncovered agents that may be effective for therapy of the disease. Our overarching goal in the coming years is to develop a deeper understanding of the molecular basis of medulloblastoma and to use this information to discover safer and more effective approaches for treating the disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Identifying and Targeting the Drivers of Pediatric Brain Tumors

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder is on the rise and the economic and human cost is staggering, so understanding the factors that promote resilience to opioid misuse is critical. The preclinical, neurobiological studies in this proposal will reveal how manipulations early in life promote resilience to the development of addiction-related phenotypes from the behavioral to the molecular level. These findings can help guide the development of novel interventions to better treat opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) remains a significant problem in the use of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation to cure a broad range of hematologic malignancies, bone marrow failure states, and genetic disorders; thus, novel approaches to prevent GVHD are critically needed. The adoptive transfer of certain subsets of murine invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells have been shown to suppress GVHD, and human studies suggest a similar role for iNKT cells, but the heterogeneity of human iNKT cells remains largely unexplored and the subset best suited to prevent GVHD is unknown. The proposed research will define human iNKT cell heterogeneity and develop strategies for targeted selection and generation of immunosuppressive iNKT cells, yielding important preclinical data that will inform the design of a future clinical trial of iNKT adoptive transfer for prevention of GVHD and providing a framework for future studies of iNKT cells in other diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes to deconstruct the mechanism underlying response to antipsychotic treatment in patients with early schizophrenia. The information gathered from this work is of considerable public health significance given its potential to 1) establish promising avenues for the development of novel treatments for psychotic symptoms; 2) optimize our existing treatments; 3) uncover the molecular and neural mechanisms that contribute to psychosis. Knowledge gained from this project may ultimately reduce the public health burden experienced by people living with this disabling psychiatric condition.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE A quantitative laparoscopic spatial frequency domain imaging platform is proposed to map intraperitoneal ovarian metastases as well as to treat them effectively via targeted chemo-photo therapy. Cancer-targeting drug and optimized light delivery will allow local release and preferential uptake of the drug into tumors versus normal tissue for optimal cancer cell destruction with minimal side effects to the surrounding normal tissue. This approach is relevant to public health as it is expected to significantly improve detection and destruction of micromets in ovarian cancer patients, and reduce side effects in normal tissue, thereby fulfilling the overarching goal of improving patients’ survival rates and quality of life.

PHR: MAESTRA Project Narrative Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) occurs when a baby gets reduced oxygen and blood flow to the brain, and can lead to death or long-term disabilities such as cerebral palsy. This study will determine how best to use the heart rate information so that we can reduce the number of infants who develop this severe brain condition.

PHR: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths, and African Americans have the highest lung cancer incidence and mortality rates when compared with any other racial or ethnic group in the U.S. We will study the biological differences between lung tumors from African Americans and European Americans. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Infants born to mothers who are overweight or obese during pregnancy (70% of pregnant women) are more likely to have increased fat mass at birth, an important risk factor for childhood obesity which can be accompanied by childhood non-alcoholic liver disease (NAFLD). There are no effective interventions in obese pregnancies to significantly reduce fetal overgrowth, but we have shown that maternal triglyceride levels are much higher in obesity and triglycerides are stronger predictors than glucose for newborn fat mass and liver fat storage. In this community study, we will determine the role and timing of maternal fasting and post-meal triglycerides on newborn fat mass and liver fat and mechanistically examine placental transport and early fat cell development which may identify a novel strategy to prevent fetal overgrowth and childhood metabolic disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain cells communicate using electrical and chemical signals and measuring these is crucial to understanding brain function. However, there is no natural contrast mechanism that allows us "to see" these messages. This project aims to illuminate brain communication through developing novel classes of genetically-encoded fluorescent reporters and tracers to study the brain and unravel the functional basis of neural disorders at a level of detail that has not been accessible to date empowering us to develop novel treatments.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Depressive illness is the leading cause of disability world-wide, and it frequently begins during adolescence. Child abuse/neglect is a major risk factor for depression, and depression resulting from abuse/neglect may be different from depression due to other causes. We will identify the brain changes in these two subtypes of depression in adolescents which will increase our understanding of their biological bases and improve treatment guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Worldwide, there are 36.9 million people living with HIV infection in 2017. A recent report show that HIV infected patients has twice the risk to develop cardiovascular disease and, globally the burden has tripled in the last 20 years. In patients with HIV infection, activation of the immune system and systemic inflammation have been associated as the main drives of cardiovascular events. In this proposal, we will investigate the underlying mechanisms driving vascular damage/inflammation during HIV infection by focusing in a component of the immune system, CD8 T cells that have vascular repair properties (angiogenic CD8 T cells, CD8 Tang) and HIV-driven T cell immune activation interferes with their function. The ultimate goal of the proposal is restore CD8 Tang function in HIV infected patients to reduce vascular inflammation and cardiovascular risk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will allow us to identify the brain processes that lead some smokers to lose behavioral control and start compulsive smoking in the presence of cigarette-related cues. Identifying the neural underpinnings of cue-induced compulsive behaviors is likely to foster the development of new treatments targeting the brain processes responsible for cue-induced cravings and cue- induced relapses. Hence, this project is relevant to the NIDA Behavioral and Cognitive Neuroscience Branch mission of identifying individual differences that are associated with increased risk for addiction and predict individual responses to interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efforts to examine the utility of alternate modalities for genetic results disclosure has widespread implications for how precision medicine research might yield direct health benefits for study participants. This study will be the first to examine the efficacy of an online self-guided program to return genetic results to a racial minority cohort population. Study results will provide empirical evidence on the effectiveness of alternate modalities for genetic results return, inform ongoing efforts to establish scalable approaches for effective return of genetic research results, and increase access to personal health information among African American women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) levels are elevated in early stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) in children and they are associated with CKD progression and cardiovascular disease. Thus, strategies that lower or limit the rise of FGF23 may lead to a new paradigm for the treatment of CKD-Mineral Bone Disorder. Thus, early intervention that focuses on control of FGF23 may lead to correcting 1,25D deficiency with replacement therapy that is associated with further rise in FGF23 levels.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused to determine functional and clinicopathological significance of miR-345 as well as development of novel combination therapies involving miR-345 restoration and gemcitabine therapy. The dual- delivery nanoscale device (DDND) loaded with miR-345 and GEM therapy concurrently targets pancreatic tumor cells and its stroma as well as pancreatic cancer (PC) stem cells by downregulating SHH, Kras and MUC4 for efficacious treatment of PC thereby overcoming challenges associated with current PC therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Acetylation of the histone protein H4 is one of the most essential epigenetic marks found in human chromatin. This mark is directly linked to age-related disorders, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in particular. The proposed studies will lead to a better understanding of how recognition of this acetylation mark can be therapeutically manipulated and may help to develop new strategies to prevent or treat age-related illnesses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New treatments for solid tumors can induce immune cells to ‘eat’ cancer cells, but not without toxic side effects. To avoid these side effects, we have developed nanoparticles for delivering drugs very selectively into inflammatory immune cells that infiltrate solid tumors. Our studies will reveal the mechanisms by which these selective nanoparticles can deliver drugs into tumors like a ‘Trojan Horse,’ so that inflammatory immune cells are unleashed to eat solid tumors without unwanted toxicity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women living with HIV/AIDS (WLHA) who are also impacted by adulthood interpersonal violence and co- occurring mental health and/or substance use disorders, suffer from poor outcomes along the HIV care continuum. However, few interventions have been developed and tested that address trauma from interpersonal violence among WLHA. We propose to determine the efficacy and mechanisms of change for Women SHINE, a web-based trauma-informed peer navigation-psychoeducation social support program aimed at primarily improving ART adherence and secondarily improving PTSD symptoms and emotion regulation among WLHA who have experienced interpersonal violence (i.e., physical, sexual, and/or psychological abuse) in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Approximately 70,000 Americans suffer from a brain hemorrhage each year. Although brain hemorrhage is a major cause of death and permanent disability, a substantial number of patients may be able to function independently afterwards and would benefit from avoiding a recurrent and disabling hemorrhage. This project aims to investigate possible ways to decrease the recurrence of brain hemorrhage in patients who survive their first hemorrhage. It can have important clinical implications to improve the welfare of these patients and their families; and to minimize healthcare-related expenses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a leading cause of disability in the US and globally, yet management options are limited and fundamental knowledge regarding causes of co-occurrence of multiple chronic pain conditions and neurophysiologic alterations in pain processing is lacking. Our grant creates an innovative inter-disciplinary collaboration to study the co-occurrence of multiple chronic pain conditions in middle age and older adults, focusing on potential common underlying causes, risk factor profiles, and heritability. The proposed work will bring new insights into chronic pain as a condition itself regardless of anatomic location of pain, with an aim to help the millions of American suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1.4 million postmenopausal women in the U.S. suffer an osteoporotic fracture yearly, resulting in disability and even mortality. This project will contribute to a long-term research agenda that seeks to determine if preventing rapid loss of bone mineral density (BMD) during the menopause transition (MT) and early postmenopause reduces the risk of osteoporotic fracture later in life; its specific contribution will be to examine whether we can predict accelerated BMD loss during the MT and early postmenopause before it occurs. This program of research, if successful, could ultimately redefine the way that we prevent fractures, by newly targeting high-risk women for early prevention prior to substantial BMD loss.

PHR: Narrative: This work examines the impact of SUMO modification on the biogenesis vs. degradation of the cystic fibrosis (CF) gene product, CFTR. Most CFTR mutations cause misfolding and premature degradation of the protein, preventing its trafficking to the apical membranes of epithelial cells. Understanding the ability of SUMO to increase CFTR biogenesis will enhance our knowledge of the CFTR folding pathway and support therapeutics development for CF.

PHR: Project Narrative Age-related decline of renal function reflects the reduced capability of the kidney to repair or regenerate in response to stress. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson Disease (PD) is a progressive movement disorder characterized by the dysfunction and loss of neurons which release the neurotransmitter dopamine. Recent evidence suggests that abnormalities in non- neuronal cells in the vicinity of dopaminergic neurons can influence their survival. The experiments in this proposal aim to determine the mechanisms by which a glial-enriched PD-risk gene influences dopaminergic viability, giving novel insight into the pathways by which glia support dopaminergic neuron survival in health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS), the most common cancer of soft tissue in older adults, frequently suffer from incurable disease recurrence. Immunotherapy combined with radiation is a promising alternative for these patients, but its efficacy is impeded by myeloid cells that infiltrate UPS tumors. Using mouse models and a clinical trial, the candidate will study a virus-like compound to redirect these myeloid cells, addressing a major obstacle to the success of immunotherapy and radiation for patients with UPS.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Suicide rates have increased rapidly in Veterans not using VHA care, particularly among females. Yet understanding of the reasons for these increases and how to address them is lacking. To address this knowledge gap, this study compares male and female Veterans who never used VHA care, were lost to VHA care after previous use, and who are currently using VHA care. We will examine if Veterans in these groups differ regarding: (1) circumstances and precipitants to suicide among suicide decedents; (2) mental health care experiences, barriers, and willingness to seek help; and (3) experiences, preferences, and barriers to help-seeking when suicidal. This mixed-methods study will link national datasets for suicide decedents, survey living Veterans, and conduct qualitative interviews of Veterans who have experienced suicidal ideation or suicide attempts. Gender differences will be examined to inform gender-sensitive, patient-centered suicide prevention efforts. Findings will be used to inform suicide prevention efforts for all Veterans, with an emphasis on non-VHA and female Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is aimed at reducing racial disparities in sleep health, which translate into racial disparities in cardiometabolic health and health outcomes. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission of promoting research to improve minority health and advance scientific understanding of the causes of health disparities. The proposed research is relevant to the funding opportunity announcement PAR-17-234, “Mechanisms and Consequences of Sleep Disparities in the U.S. (R01),” given its focus on understanding how multilevel psychosocial determinants contribute to sleep disparities across the life course in health disparity populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of impacts to the head in contact sports, like American football, is reportedly very high. Increasing evidence shows that effects of repetitive blows to the head are cumulative and can cause deterioration of brain structure and function. This study will use advanced neuroimaging, biomechanical techniques and neurocognitive assessments to examine brain structure and function changes in two contract sports (football or soccer) middle school and high school players after exposure to repetitive head impacts during two consecutive routine game and training seasons, in comparison with matched non-contact sports athletes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This is a competitive renewal application for a NIH R01 grant that has been continuously funded and remarkably successful for 22 years. The long-standing goals of this project are to understand the mechanisms of chemokines and their receptors in various pathologies and to translate such information into the development of new intervention strategies. We propose to extend our exciting discoveries to the development of new CXCR4- targeted stem cell mobilizers with optimized pharmacological and biological properties to further probe the structure-function relationship of CXCR4-ligand binding and signaling and as drug leads to develop new medicines for promoting stem cell-based tissue repairs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use male and female rat pups to study inflammation in the young brain after traumatic brain injury (TBI). TBI is the leading cause of acquired disability in children, yet no effective therapies exist. Our results will inform future testing of Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA), a promising therapy, in children after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic neuropathic pain is a debilitating condition that occurs in 10% of the general population and in 40-70% of those with spinal cord injury. This research aims to identify a biomarker signature with high sensitivity and specificity that is prognostic of neuropathic pain after spinal cord injury. The research would contribute knowledge about the relationship between autoantibodies and neuropathic pain, and the application of this knowledge may pave the way for clinical studies utilizing non-opioid therapeutics aimed at reducing plasma autoantibody levels in order to hinder the development of neuropathic pain.

PHR: Project Narrative Leaders from the Alzheimer’s Prevention Initiative (API) and Anti-Amyloid Treatment in Asymptomatic Alzheimer’s (A4) Trials have come together to conduct a potentially license-enabling prevention trial, using clinically informative Alzheimer’s disease biomarkers and other assessments to evaluate the promising amyloid plaque-busting antibody treatment aducanumab in cognitively unimpaired 65-80 year-old persons with a positive amyloid PET scan. The deliberately ambitious proposal is intended to 1) find an approved Alzheimer’s prevention therapy as early as 2023, ahead of the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease goal to “prevent Alzheimer’s disease by 2025; 2) introduce the use of these biomarkers to test and approve prevention therapies in almost everyone who, based on their biological tests or genetic risk, are at increased risk; and 3) help make it possible to conduct prevention trials in at risk persons even before they have extensive amyloid plaques, when some treatments may have their greatest benefit. It is intended to capitalize on a public-private partnership with the makers of aducanumab, NIH support, $5-10 million dollars in philanthropy; enable us to secure access to this promising drug and secure most of the financial support from our industry partner; provide a public resource of data and biological samples to help the field find even better ways to test prevention therapies; have the maximum public benefit; and prevent Alzheimer’s disease as soon as possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Mosquitoes are the most important arthropod vectors of disease-causing pathogens. Proposed studies will characterize the receptor binding preferences and functions of two types of neurohormones, insulin-like peptides and ovary ecdsysteroidogenic hormone, that regulate female mosquito reproduction. Results will identify new potential targets for disrupting female reproduction for potential use in vector control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an incurable, disabling, and often fatal disease characterized by the accumulation of myofibroblasts predominantly in the peripheral areas of the lung. Identifying WT1-driven gene targets involved in fibroblast activation will establish the pathological role of WT1 in fibroblast activation and help to develop innovative treatment strategies for patients with fibrotic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The ability to learn to perform specific motor movements is critical for many aspects of life, and is dysregulated in a range of neurological conditions such as Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s diseases, and dementia. Dopaminergic cells provide a reinforcement signal to promote action learning, but how the brain uses these signals to explore the action space based on past rewarding experiences is not clear. The goal of the proposed project is to broaden our understanding of how dopaminergic cells act to promote action learning in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Human paraneoplastic neurological disorders (PNDs) are debilitating disorders of the central nervous system that involve autoimmune encephalitis. The autoimmune encephalitis is triggered by cancer in PNDs, but it is also an unanticipated side effect of anti-cancer immunotherapies, broadening the scope of the problem. I have identified, using a new robust approach, previously elusive pathogenic PND antigens, and in this proposal I strengthen the link to autoimmune encephalitis and identify the molecular cues and pathways that may serve as therapeutic entry points to diminish the immune inflammation.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The goal of the Applied Research Component (ARC) proposed here is continues with the successful Translational Science Initiative (TSI) at the CPRC. The close evolutionary relationship between humans and nonhuman primates (NHPs) is reflected by many common features in their genetics, physiology, and biochemistry, and these similarities make NHPs especially valuable as model systems for biomedical research. During the execution of this project we will characterize the vaginal microbiome in non-pregnant primates and will assess their association with the multiple-body microbiome dynamics in gestation and postpartum in rhesus macaques. This will contribute to understand maternal-infant transmissibility and compare changes associated to SPF and conventional animals. As captivity is thought to significantly alter the overall microbial community composition leaving additional bio exclusion, social interactions, environmental exposure as well as exposure to human's other important factors modulating the animal microbiome and its health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Behavioral intervention such as exercise has been shown to mitigate pathogenesis of neural disease such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease, and other form neurodegeneration. I have developed a training plan and research project that will bridge my current training in genetic and molecular approaches of studying synaptic biology to exercise mediated models of neural plasticity. My ultimate goal is to utilize this approach to identify novel molecular pathways and signaling factors that mediate neural plasticity as potential targets for therapeutic applications, which aligns with the Brain Initiative on Neurotherapeutics and Mechanisms shaping neuronal circuitry.

PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders are a significant public health issue, and one of the leading causes of drug relapse is exposure to stress. This project investigates specific neuronal subpopulations involved in anxiety-like stress responses with the long-term goal of understanding their contribution to relapse. In doing so, we hope to uncover new potential therapeutic targets in the treatment of maladaptive stress responses including affective and substance use disorders.

PHR: The proposed research will adapt CPT into a brief format using empirical methods. This project is relevant to Veterans’ health because will improve treatment effectiveness, reduce attrition, and improve efficiency, enabling providers to treat more Veterans with need. This proposal is directly responsive to the 2021 HSR&D mental health priorities to increase the engagement and retention of Veterans in evidence-based therapies for PTSD and to develop innovative and efficient models of healthcare delivery. It addresses the cross-cutting HSR&D Implementation Science priority to use a theory-based method to improve uptake of effective practices. It is also directly responsive to the VA National Center for PTSD’s operational priorities to develop adapted treatments that attend to patient preferences and to improve treatment efficiency, effectiveness, and engagement.

PHR: We will refine a cognitive-behavioral therapy for loneliness and substance use disorder (CBT-L/SUD) then assess its feasibility and acceptability first through a small single-arm trial, then a small randomized clinical trial. Data from these trials will provide data to inform treatment satisfaction, and feasibility of study procedures, outcome measurement, and treatment delivery. Findings will be used to inform a larger, fully-powered Merit Award application testing the effects of CBT-L/SUD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Proper diagnosis is key to effective tuberculosis (TB) treatment, but there exist specific barriers to effective TB testing in low resource settings, especially in children. Thus, the goal of this project is to adapt our current point-of-care (POC) TB diagnostic assay to be sensitive enough for use in children, who often present with paucibacillary disease. Specifically, we will perform assay optimization and a small-scale pilot study of clinical sensitivity in Phase I that will evaluate the overall effectiveness of our assay technology, informing the next iteration of improvements prior to larger pediatric study in Phase 2.

PHR: Shared decision making is the first overarching principle for the treat to target guidelines for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and has been proposed as a potential mechanism to reduce health disparities, however there is little evidence to inform effective ways to implement this practice in the care of Veterans with RA. The purpose of this project is to evaluate the effectiveness of a multi-component shared decision making intervention on RA disease activity, adherence to RA medications and patient knowledge of RA. The proposed research will contribute to fundamental knowledge about how to effectively foster shared decision making across varied VA rheumatology clinical settings to improve patient disease outcomes and experience; and support clinicians to engage patients in meaningful ways with the ultimate goal to improve health, reduce disability, and eliminate disparities.
