PHR: Narrative In the present proposal, we will design a novel combination strategy for vaccine mediated ex vivo T cell expansion that promotes the expansion of central memory cells, enhances the activation and expansion of functionally dominant clones, and reverses critical mediators of the immunosuppressive milieu through TGFβ inhibition. Patient specific DC/AML fusions will be used to interrogate the relative dominance of T cell clones targeting individual neoantigens. In third aim, we will translate the preclinical findings into a phase I clinical trial and study the correlation between the characteristics of the T cell product with toxicity, in vivo activation, expansion, and persistence, and protection from relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cytochrome P450-1B1 (CYP1B1) is absent or expressed at very low levels in the liver and healthy tissues while being overexpressed in tumors, giving it the title of “universal tumor antigen”. Evidence from basic science, clinical, and epidemiological studies demonstrate that CYP1B1 is involved in cancer initiation, progression, and resistance to a wide range of chemotherapeutics. This work will define how CYP1B1 subcellular localization, oligomerization, degradation, and small molecule binding are altered in cancer cells as a function of specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and environmental factors, facilitating malignant progression, and will provide a new paradigm for small molecule inhibitors of the enzyme that function by inducing CYP1B1 protein degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Fracture nonunion poses a significant clinical problem and its treatment usually involves complicated and massive procedures in practice, and sometimes needs multiple surgeries, therefore increases the cost of health care and results in marked patient disability. The proposed studies will enhance our understanding of mechanisms by which systemic inflammation (via the NF-κB pathway) affects the angiogenic process through Dnmt3b. This work will establish an important therapeutic option to improve the angiogenesis and fracture healing.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: The high mortality rate associated with ovarian cancer results from the failure of tumor-directed therapy to produce lasting treatment responses. Published work from our lab demonstrates that combining PARP-inhibitors with immune checkpoint blockade can achieve long-term survival in ovarian cancer models and may overcome treatment resistance in patients with recurrent disease. Here we will investigate the mechanisms responsible for the therapeutic synergy of this combination to enable the optimal integration of immune therapy with cytotoxic regimens for long-term benefit in women with ovarian cancer.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Addiction-related health issues are estimated to cause 590,000 deaths and 40 million illnesses or injuries annually in the U.S. While the progression to addiction is a complex process and depends on many factors, including environment, the propensity to become addicted to drugs of abuse is strongly influenced by genetics. In this project, we will use precise genome editing in mice to identify signaling pathways that mediate addiction behaviors to produce novel preclinical mouse models that could be used to help identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) contribute an alarming ~7% of calories in the US diet among adults, making them the single largest source of added sugar. However, whether artificially sweetened beverages are a healthful alternative for reducing SSB intake among habitual SSB consumers is unknown. Therefore, we propose a 4-arm randomized diet intervention trial to test the effects of substituting SSBs with calorie-free alternatives on body weight and health, among habitual SSB consumers with overweight/obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Unconstrained evolution of HIV-1 proteins leads to rapid drug resistance, thus new targets are being sought among host-virus protein complexes in order to circumvent drug resistance. HIV-1 release is a vital step in the viral life cycle that is not targeted by any current drugs, owing in part to a lack of information on how to separate interactions hijacked by HIV from those necessary for normal physiology. This project will reveal the mechanistic basis for HIV assembly, budding, and release in unprecedented

PHR: In light of the “opioid crisis,” providers face a clinical conundrum of balancing opioid addiction risk with increasing concern of the undertreatment of patients in legitimate pain. The current proposal seeks to investigate a new class of fentanyl derivatives designed to maintain clinical efficacy with decreased potency to elicit unwanted effects (i.e., addiction, respiratory depression.) The findings of this proposal will improve public health through the development of safer analgesic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latent tuberculosis (TB) is referred to as the “seedbed” of TB disease, and TB elimination goals cannot be reached without addressing latent TB. Treatment of latent TB prevents progression to active TB, but completion rates are low. To address this problem, this study evaluates novel and scalable interventions that combine smartphone enabled adherence support through video observations of treatment (with case- management and electronic reminders), with and without financial incentives to promote completion of treatment for latent TB in in Baltimore, MD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite widespread vaccination, measles remains a leading cause of child mortality globally; in addition, it has been re-emerging in previously measles-free regions (e.g., the recent case increases in the US and re- establishment of endemic transmission in the UK and Venezuela in South America). By studying mechanisms governing the spread of measles in the modern, mass vaccination era, the proposed work will improve understanding of the persistence of measles transmission and aid development of improved interventions to eliminate measles worldwide.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality in the nation, and the burden of the illness is disproportionally experienced by individuals residing in rural areas and experiencing economic challenges. Recent advances in early detection and treatment of lung cancer foretell significant reductions in lung cancer mortality, engendering a need for research efforts to inform lung cancer survivorship care guidelines. This research outlines a randomized clinical trial of a precision lung cancer survivorship care intervention aimed at improving quality of life among rural lung cancer survivors within socioeconomically distressed areas in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We propose to create VOrtex, a virtual observatory for a cubic millimeter of cortex. The observatory will enable researchers to study neuronal and glial cell biology, cell types, and neural circuit structure and dynamics. New and fundamental knowledge about the cortex will inform basic research as well as research on brain diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative This research will enhance understanding of the complex emotional, cognitive, and physical symptoms experienced after injuries to the brain, spine, or limb. To accomplish this goal, the research team will apply innovative techniques to explore how disparate symptoms cluster together and how such “symptom clusters” might be identified and tracked in clinical settings. This will lead to improved healthcare by increasing use of precise and efficient methods for symptom assessment and providing targets for tailored interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative Solid tumors present a significant public health issue despite intense research and advances in patient care. Based on recent research, we now realize that tumors must avoid recognition by the immune system to progress but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Our work will delineate a key immune evasion pathway in solid tumors and establish the value of targeting this pathway for immunotherapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from parental grant) A new highly drug resistant form of aggressive prostate cancer characterized by no neuroendocrine features and low androgen receptor (AR) levels is on the rise and very little is known about the cellular processes that govern its growth. We have discovered that the steps of protein synthesis are absolutely critical for AR low prostate cancer cell proliferation in vitro and in vivo, which represents a potential therapeutic vulnerability. Our goal is to definitively investigate the fundamental link between AR and protein synthesis and determine the therapeutic implications of targeting this interface.

PHR: Project Narrative (Parent Grant Application) Advanced prostate cancer patients often fail androgen receptor-directed therapy and develop lethal castration- resistant disease, which constitutes a major challenge in clinical management, raising an urgent need to develop effective new therapeutic strategies to improve patient survival. The proposed studies define the functional and mechanistic roles of monoamine oxidase A, a recently identified therapeutic target in prostate cancer, which synergizes with androgen receptor to form a reciprocally interactive complex promoting prostate cancer growth and progression. Our studies will provide new fundamental knowledge of the molecular basis of androgen receptor regulation and the development of resistance to castration and next-generation antiandrogen drugs, thus laying the foundations for a new combination therapy with the potential for rapid translation to treat advanced prostate cancers.

PHR: This bench-to-bedside pilot study evaluates the safety of a novel medical technology, LANT (Laser-Activated NanoTherapy), for treating a type of skin cancer called cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Veterans have a high risk for this type of skin cancer due to extensive exposures during the line of duty to the sun and chemical warfare agents like Agent Blue and Lewisite. This project is of significant interest because Veterans with difficult-to-treat cancer facing poor clinical outcomes could greatly benefit from LANT. This new cancer treatment may address the unmet need for a local and minimally invasive alternative to radiation when surgery is not a viable option.

PHR: Project Narrative Esophageal cancer disproportionately affects US veterans and is associated with considerable morbidity and mortality. If repurposing the antifungal drug itraconazole to treat esophageal cancer successfully improves pathologic complete response rates in patients with surgically resectable disease, this should increase overall survival rates. Identifying which patients will respond to chemoradiation and itraconazole by developing novel biomarkers would maximize the impact of this intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Somatic cell genetic heterogeneity within an individual arises over the course of the human lifespan; but the quantitative extent and qualitative nature of this cell-to-cell change continues to be a matter of conjecture, because methods are limited. We recently developed a method to use single colon crypts as representative of one stem cell that would allow determination of the extent to which cells of the body diverge from each other genetically over the human lifespan. As analysis of the human body for medical and therapeutic reasons relies upon progressively fewer somatic cells, this knowledge of somatic cell genetic heterogeneity will become increasingly important.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Conventional type 1 dendritic cells (cDC1) are critical for antitumor immunity by presenting antigens to cytotoxic T cells and are directly associated with immune-mediated tumor rejection and the success of immunotherapy. A better understanding of the immune pathways regulating cDC1 metabolism and function may lead to new therapeutic strategies to boost antitumor immunity and increase the responsiveness of cancer patients to immunotherapies such as checkpoint blockade.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE THE PARENT GRANT APPLICATION Despite the documented importance of physical activity for cancer survivorship, a large proportion of breast and endometrial cancer survivors remain physically inactive. In contrast to the “one size fits all” approach used by most previous physical activity interventions for cancer survivors, this trial will test an adaptive intervention approach that reserves the most resources and support for women who do not fare well with a lower-cost, minimal intervention. The results from this trial will inform the development of scalable physical activity interventions for breast and endometrial cancer survivors.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Vilgelm, Anna E Project Narrative The focus of this project is on pre-clinical development of a novel therapeutic concept where melanoma tumor growth is controlled by directly targeting tumor cells and by making them easier targets for the anti-tumor immune response. This research will improve our understanding of tumor-host interactions, and enable effective therapeutic modulation of these interactions. This work should to have a profound impact on the survival of metastatic melanoma patients by advancing a novel therapy for patients who fail to respond to standard of care treatments. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of PD-1 and PD-L1 inhibitors is a major breakthrough in cancer immunotherapy, yet clinical success is restricted to a small subset of cancer patients. Our proposed studies aim to uncover a novel regulatory mechanism of the PD-L1/PD-1 pathway and to elucidate the mechanisms of action of their therapeutic inhibitors, using novel, unique and precise assays. Execution of the proposed research will lay the foundation for designed more effective and durable PD-1 targeted cancer immunotherapy.

PHR: Women Veterans are a fast growing population in VA and one that has healthcare needs distinct from the rest of the predominantly male population. In order to provide high-quality care for women, the VA has developed a specific program for women’s healthcare which includes designated women’s health providers and separate clinic structures for women. While the quality of women’s health care in VA has improved significantly in the last few decades, barriers to optimal care exist. Specifically, women Veterans face obstacles to receiving health care due to disproportionate caregiver responsibilities, work-life balance issues, and exposure to discrimination such as stranger harassment on VA grounds. Providing women Veterans the opportunity to use virtual care for the right health care concerns at the right time could create new ways for women to access timely needed care. This project seeks to create a package of approaches to improving when and how virtual care is offered to women Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The A1 domain of blood clotting protein von Willebrand factor mediates platelet adhesion to sites of vascular damage. The proposed project aims to understand how the autoinhibitory module, a structural and functional component at the flanking regions of A1, regulates A1 activation during bleeding. Elucidating this mechanism will help us understand how von Willebrand disease, the most common hereditary bleeding disorder affecting 1% of the population, is developed, as well as provide significant implications for treating bleeding and thrombotic disorders.

PHR: Inflammatory bone loss can be induced by excessive activation of bone-resorbing osteoclasts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is a major public health threat that spreads readily among humans or from animals to humans (termed zoonotic tuberculosis or zTB). Yet we lack accurate estimates of zTB risk, especially in high-TB-burden settings where the disease is endemic in both humans and livestock and where there are greater opportunities for transmission of zTB from animals to humans. Our innovative, rigorously designed, and first-of-its-kind study will fill this major knowledge gap by assessing the risks associated with zTB, and thereby enable the development of evidence-based approaches to reduce spillover from livestock to humans.

PHR: Public Health Relevance. Through the proposed project, we seek to elucidate the molecular and genetic basis of neurological disorders in humans. Advancing the understanding of the genetic basis of disease, as well as the molecular mechanisms in the brain is a prerequisite to developing therapeutic strategies for cognitive dysfunctions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans with experiences of homelessness have increased risks for adverse mental health and substance abuse (MHSA) outcomes, including psychiatric hospitalization, overdose, and suicide. Given VA’s strong investment in improving all Veterans’ access to evidence-based MHSA treatment in primary care, it is critical to determine if homeless patient aligned care teams (H-PACTs) enhance MHSA services quality and outcomes, and to determine effective elements of other patient aligned care team (PACTs) caring for homeless- experienced Veterans. VA facility leaders need comparative information on the quality of MHSA services in H- PACTs versus standard PACT settings to help them decide whether to adopt, expand, or modify this promising model of care. Information on how H-PACTs and other PACTs coordinate with specialists in VA and community settings is needed to determine targets for intervention. Facility-specific information on factors contributing to improved MHSA services quality will guide quality improvement and implementation efforts.

PHR: The purpose of this award is to support the research, training and service activities of Dr. Matthew Maciejewski, who is a health economist, Research Career Scientist, and experienced Department of Veterans Affairs investigator. Over his 20-year HSR&D career, Dr. Maciejewski has led numerous research studies that improve our understanding of how best help Veterans manage their obesity or cardiometabolic conditions. This research is important because Veterans with obesity or multiple chronic conditions incur a disproportionate share of VA expenditures and population- based care models that effectively improve their health and health care are not yet established. He has contributed to the methods literature, played a leadership role in VA service and mentored fellows who have gone on to make major contributions.

PHR: Veterans experience a high prevalence of peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is cholesterol build-up and blockages in the blood supply to the legs. A common symptom of PAD is pain in the legs or calves when walking. This pain often forces Veterans to limit their physical activity. The functional impairment caused by claudication promotes a sedentary lifestyle, placing Veterans with PAD at increased risk for heart disease. As such, the goals of therapy for PAD are: 1) maintain functional status, 2) manage claudication, and 3) to reduce cardiac events. Of the therapies, medical and invasive, recommended by practice guidelines, only one has the ability to simultaneously achieve all three treatment goals – exercise. Unfortunately, less than 10% of eligible Veterans participate in exercise rehabilitation programs due to a lack of availability and the burden of having to travel long distances to reach medical facilities.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans have higher rates of mental health conditions than other Servicemembers, perhaps related to longer and more frequent deployments. Given the overall high quality of mental health care provided at the VA, it is critical to understand why we see vast differences in enrollment rates in VA medical centers across the country as well as variability in engagement in care. As options for health care outside the VA have recently increased for this population, primarily though the Affordable Care Act’s Medicaid expansion, VA’s Choice Act and VA’s MISSION Act, Veterans’ health care has become more fragmented. To ensure that Veterans have access to high-quality integrated primary and mental health care, VA leaders need currently unavailable information to better understand enrollment and utilization patterns at their local facilities and regions. I propose to develop information and decision support tools to improve their understanding of and ability to impact VA enrollment and engagement in primary and mental health care.

PHR: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as “stenting,” is a common cardiac procedure that can improve survival and quality of life when used appropriately. The quality of PCI care varies among hospitals and physicians, and only 24% of elective procedures in VA are considered appropriate, potentially putting patients at risk without clear benefit. Nearly all PCI procedures are reported to national registries, but physicians receive little meaningful feedback about their care. This research will develop and test a peer learning intervention that facilitates clinician-to-clinician feedback and collaborative professional development. The intervention will provide actionable, personalized, and trusted feedback that promotes quality care and appropriate case selection. It will be designed with input from physicians and other stakeholders so that it is usable and acceptable. A successful peer review intervention could substantially reduce the number of patients receiving unnecessary stents and improve overall procedural quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: 1. In the US and throughout the world, the number of patients requiring orthognathic surgery for jaw  deformities, which involves skeleton, overlying soft tissue, or both, is escalating every ear. 2. Currently, while surgeons are able to accurately plan orthognathic surgery by virtually repositioning bony  segments to desired locations, they are still unable to practically predict the ultimate treatment outcomes  of orthognathic surgery, a desired postoperative facial appearance, during the surgical planning. 3. We are proposing to integrate outcome-driven and machine learning-based techniques together to first  estimate a desired postoperative face, and then plan the bony surgery, which will revolutionize the  surgical planning technique and enable clinicians to develop an optimal surgical plan based on both facial  and bony information, on-the-fly, using a single software in their routine clinical practice.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Biomedical Computing and Health Informatics Study Section[BCHI]

PHR: Patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) exhibit co-morbid alcohol use disorder (AUD) at far greater rates than the general population, but we have no effective therapies for these diseases when they present simultaneously. In Veteran populations the relationship between AUD and PTSD is even more prevalent as 63% of Veterans diagnosed with AUD are co-diagnosed with PTSD. Fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) is a secreted endocrine molecule that signals to the brain to decrease alcohol consumption and genetic variation in genes encoding FGF21 and its receptor, β-klotho, are associated with increased alcohol consumption in humans. More recently we have observed that FGF21 also increases fear memory following chronic alcohol consumption in mice and propose to investigate how FGF21 signaling in the brain influences both alcohol consumption and fear to provide new therapeutic targets to treat Veterans suffering from both PTSD and AUD.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed R01 is to advance the next generation of implementation research to end the HIV epidemic. MPIs Momplaisir, Gross, and Beidas partner with a network of clinics providing HIV care to experimentally test an adapted evidence-based practice, Managed Problem Solving, delivered by community health workers to improve viral suppression, retention, and reach within the City of Philadelphia. Our long-term goal is to improve retention in HIV care and viral suppression to achieve the benchmarks set forth by the EHE; the proposed trial has the potential to improve care in this network and produce findings that are generalizable to other health systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Cathelicidin is a type of antimicrobial peptide known to be important to human disease since infection occurs when expression of this peptide is insufficient, and inflammation occurs when cathelicidin is too abundant. This project builds on a breakthrough discovery into the mechanism of action of cathelicidin to promote inflammation. Our approach seeks to better understand this process and explore potential strategies that can be exploited to treat disease.

PHR: Project Narrative We aim to evaluate the use of a digital platform for enhancing the clinical effectiveness and supporting the integration of a proven psychosocial rehabilitation intervention for patients with schizophrenia into the ongoing national roll out of comprehensive non-communicable disease services in primary care settings in India. Our study will break new ground by testing whether the digital platform yields added benefits for patients while supporting implementation and sustainability of community care for schizophrenia. Findings from our study can inform novel approaches for scaling up community care for schizophrenia in India and in other settings globally where access to these effective interventions remains alarmingly limited.

PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we will study a radioligand therapy (RLT) that targets the prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA), a molecule that is expressed on the majority of prostate cancer cells. PSMA RLT relies on two basic premises: targeting the radiation to PSMA and the radiosensitivity of the tissue to the deposited radiation. In this work, we will understand how PSMA expression is regulated and whether tumors respond because of intrinsic sensitivity to radiation or high doses of deposited radiation, which will allow us to develop co- administered therapies to potentiate the effect of PSMA RLT.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance This project lays the foundation for improving diagnostics, rehabilitation, and ultimately functional outcomes and quality of life of the hundreds of thousands of people whose lives are negatively impacted by a brain injury that leaves them with often subtle, yet disabling visuospatial deficits. The findings will allow us to develop a comprehensive yet bedside-compatible assessment for core visuospatial deficits, identify visuospatial tests that are particularly sensitive to right-brain injury and thus can complement current screening tools (which underestimate right-brain injury), and pinpoint visuospatial deficits that are strongly linked to functional outcomes and should thus become the focus of rehabilitation efforts. Functional neuroimaging results will guide the development of non-invasive neurostimulation protocols to augment the effect of behavioral treatments by promoting adaptive patterns of functional brain organization.

PHR: Project Narrative Urge urinary incontinence is a common problem in older people which vastly reduces quality of life, yet the cause and mechanism of disease are not well understood. This study will further investigate the brain mechanisms involved in continence by evaluating brain changes after treatment by an anticholinergic drug to reduce urine leakage. This will expand our current knowledge of how the brain controls the bladder, better characterize the drug action mechanism and suggest ways in which we can better target treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the appropriate use of shorter radiation treatments (called “hypofractionation”) for breast and prostate cancer, a critical step to improving access to high-value patient-centered cancer care. This research proposal will assess variation across the United States in adoption of hypofractionation, and methodically evaluate and pilot test implementation strategies to improve adoption of hypofractionation in a community-based clinical practice setting. The results of this work will generate fundamental knowledge to inform healthcare leaders and policymakers about effective methods to facilitate adoption of evidence-based cancer care, thereby improving access to shorter radiation treatments that improve quality of life and reduce the burden of cancer treatment for patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging causes shoulder tendons to deteriorate for all people, but for people with spinal cord injuries who use a manual wheelchair, shoulder tendons will tear and cause pain at a younger age and higher rate than people without physical disabilities. Understanding what factors worsen the health of the shoulder tendons will inform early interventions to protect shoulders and keep them free from pain. This study will follow two groups of people, manual wheelchair users and able-bodied adults, while looking for differences in how they use their arms, the medications they use, and their general health indicators to determine which of these factors are related to worsening tendon tears in the shoulder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Reno, Nevada is impacted by smoke plumes from wildfires and prescribed burns. We will measure and model the pollutants in these smoke plumes, and we will estimate associations of smoke pollutants with maternal, child, and adult acute health outcomes. Our goals are to improve smoke pollutant modeling for public health and to better understand the health impacts of different types of fires.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our study will contribute to the evidence about effective public policy by local governments within states that have legalized retail cannabis by providing a systematic description of 1) local (i.e., county/city) policies to regulate cannabis and local market environments (e.g., density of retailers and sales activity); 2) the association between local cannabis policies, prices and market activity and health outcomes among youth, pregnant women and adults; and 3) further association with alcohol, tobacco and opioid outcomes among youth, pregnant women and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will develop a novel technology to measure cortical plate and subplate thickness in the human fetal brain using in vivo MRI, which in turn will enable us to understand trajectories (temporal dynamics) and inter-subject variabilities of fetal cerebral growth. The technology for fetal cortical and subplate thickness measurement will lay the foundation for clinical applications of fetal brain MRI analysis in many developmental disorders and extend the field of developmental brain imaging research. This study will provide a meaningful biomarker that could lead to greater insight into the mechanisms of normal and altered in utero brain development, allowing assessment of the impact of maternal exposures and informing strategies for future in utero therapies.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lineage plasticity is an emerging mechanism of therapeutic resistance in advanced prostate cancer. As more men are treated with next-generation androgen receptor targeted therapies, the incidence rate of resistant disease is on the rise. These studies aim to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the process of lineage plasticity, identify biomarkers of cells that are likely to develop resistance to therapy, and propose new strategies to improve outcomes for prostate cancer patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beneficiaries dually enrolled in Medicare and Medicaid have worse cancer outcomes compared to Medicare only beneficiaries, with lower screening rates, lower likelihood of receiving treatment, and higher risk of mortality. The Medicare Shared Savings Program is a delivery system reform that incentivizes healthcare providers and organizations to deliver coordinated, high-quality care. This proposed project will assess how much the Medicare Shared Savings Program improves cancer screening, time to treatment initiation after a cancer diagnosis, and cancer treatment costs for dually-enrolled beneficiaries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol use disorder is a debilitating neuropsychiatric illness that often presents with significant anxiety, increasing the risk of relapse. The overall goal of this K23 proposal is to launch the career of the Principal Investigator, A. Benjamin Srivastava, MD, as an independent translational researcher who can combine clinical and cognitive neuroscience methods in order to understand the neural mechanisms underlying anxiety during early and protracted abstinence in alcohol use disorder. Ultimately, this patient- oriented research program will lead to both improvements in diagnosis and the identification of new treatment targets aimed improving outcomes in alcohol use disorder and co-occurring psychiatric illnesses.

PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals use cannabis and cannabidiol (CBD), a constituent of cannabis, to treat their pain despite few empirical studies assessing their effects when used repeatedly or in combination. Pre-clinical studies show that CBD can attenuate the abuse-related effects of cannabis and enhance its analgesic efficacy but the effect of repeated CBD use on cannabis-induced analgesia and abuse liability in humans is not known. The primary goal of this mentored research proposal is to determine if daily CBD administration, across a range of doses and time, alters the abuse-related, reinforcing and analgesic effects of smoked cannabis.

PHR: New policies and healthcare processes are constantly rolling out to the front lines of clinical staff and providers across the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). Less is known about the investment needed into evidence based implementation strategies by VHA healthcare organizations to achieve systematic implementation. Moreover, implementation science has only recently begun to identify a set of implementation strategies; however, the evidence and strength of the effects of such strategies are unknown. Dr. Damush and colleagues are designing and evaluating implementation strategies to activate individual and teams of clinical providers to implement evidence based processes to improve the quality of care and improve Veteran and provider satisfaction with VHA care. Our work will also contribute to the implementation science base of effective implementation strategies across multiple clinical conditions and settings to modify provider behavior to improve VHA care and the health-related quality of life outcomes for Veterans

ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Depression is the most prevalent mental health condition among VHA patients and is strongly associated with poor functioning, negative health outcomes, and suicide. Despite effective and available treatments, engagement in care is poor. This study will analyze VHA electronic medical record data, to identify patient characteristics associated with poor treatment engagement. The study will then develop and formatively evaluate an eHealth intervention to improve and sustain engagement in mental health care through self-monitoring. This is an important step in engaging Veterans who, in part, based on their military training, may have difficulty identifying or accepting depressed affect and the benefits of treatment. The information obtained will inform clinical strategies and operations policy to improve quality, coordination, and efficiency of mental health services.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in imaging have led to the detection of innumerable pancreatic cysts that could never be seen before, now visible in >10% of patients who have an MRI and in >2% who have a CT scan for an unrelated reason. The majority of these cysts represent low-risk precursors of pancreatic cancer, a small percentage of which will progress to invasive cancer over months to years. In the proposed research, we will build a mathematical model that simulates the natural history of pancreatic cysts, and use it to formulate a management approach that optimally balances the benefits of cancer control with the risks and costs associated with overtesting and overtreatment.

PHR: Improving treatment access for Veterans with opioid use disorder (OUD) is a top VHA priority. With the national opioid crisis, many Veterans are suffering from OUD, which is associated with overdose, suicide and numerous other serious harms. Less than a third of Veterans with OUD receive evidence based pharmacotherapy treatment. Delivering treatment has been a major challenge due to a lack of trained providers in many VA facilities, particularly in community-based outpatient clinics (CBOCs). The current proposal will capitalize on the telehealth infrastructure in the VA to increase OUD treatment access by refining and then pilot testing a telehealth intervention delivering OUD treatment to Veterans in CBOCs and examine the VA OUD treatment landscape to understand where to best prioritize telehealth implementation. This research will inform the development of a telehealth intervention for OUD that can be implemented in the VHA and will inform future telehealth interventions to improve treatment for the large population of Veterans with substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative While the sensory neurons and brain circuitry underlying vision, hearing, and the chemical senses (taste and smell) had been deeply explored, less is known about the sense of touch. We have generated an array of mouse genetic tools that have enabled detailed investigation into the principal classes of low-threshold and high-threshold mechanosensory neuron subtypes (LTMRs and HTMRs) and the central touch circuitry. We are using these tools and a range of new physiological, behavioral, and anatomical approaches to elucidate the properties and functions of LTMR and HTMR subtypes across different skin regions and the functional organization of the subcortical touch circuitry, in health and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapies targeting the cell surface proteins expressed on cancer cells have revolutionized the treatment of B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL). However, B-ALLs that contain gain-of-function oncogenic mutations involving the KMT2A gene remain high risk, and often transition to an Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) identity, resulting in loss of the immunotherapeutic targets and aggressive tumor relapses that are usually fatal. This proposal takes an integrated approach to (1) identify clinically available pharmaceuticals that can limit the ability of KMT2A mutant B-ALLs to switch to an AML identity and (2) identify novel biomarkers that label the subset of KMT2A mutant leukemias that remain high risk, and can be used to develop more effective immunotherapies in the future.

PHR: Hoarding Disorder (HD) is serious and disabling in Veterans. Present in up to 7% of Veterans and even higher symptom rates in older Veterans; HD contributes to functional impairment and poor quality of life. Cognitive Rehabilitation and Exposure/Sorting Therapy (CREST) has shown promising functional improvement and symptom reduction. To reduce burdens and barriers to implementation of CREST, the proposed project will individualize CREST based on cognitive testing and participant preferences, provide all care in the participant’s home through telemedicine and home visits, and shorten the timeframe of treatment. A randomized controlled trial comparing 24 sessions of Personalized-CREST to case management for 130 adult Veterans with HD is proposed. Multifaceted functional and recovery outcomes including quality of life, HD severity, and sustained recovery outcomes will be examined throughout treatment and follow-up. By advancing our knowledge of the rehabilitative care of HD, we can interrupt the trajectory of this chronic and debilitating condition.

PHR: Pre-deployment hazardous binge drinking is highly prevalent in active-duty US military personnel and can increase the likelihood of developing an alcohol use disorder. This is particularly relevant to combat veterans who increasingly treat symptoms of depression and anxiety by ‘self-medicating’ with alcohol. This research furthers the VA mission by identifying novel non-neuronal mechanisms that are involved in the dysregulation of neuronal activity and subsequent neuronal remodeling that occurs after binge ethanol exposure. Understanding these mechanisms in the context of synaptic dysfunction and the emergence of alcohol use disorder could lead to the development of novel pharmacotherapies designed to break the cycle of chronic substance abuse in this at-risk population.

PHR: The Center for the Prevention and Treatment of Visual Loss (CPTVL) provides new discoveries for restoring vision and related brain functions, which are important to a Veteran's interpretation of their environment, daily productivity, and quality of life. This is done through a creative and scientifically rigorous interaction between clinicians and scientists who perform research in three main focus areas: Telemedicine, Cellular Mechanisms of Disease, and Novel Therapeutics. Research is translated into goals of rehabilitating and restoring visual function, thus enhancing the quality of life of Veterans. Examples of disorders that are targeted for rehabilitation include glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, macular degeneration, traumatic brain injury, optic neuropathy, multiple sclerosis, light sensitivity, and migraine. Enabling smartphone devices for home testing of function enhances rehabilitation of these disorders.

ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Over 40% of Veterans have obesity, a condition associated with multiple comorbidities and high healthcare costs. While lifestyle interventions addressing dietary change and physical activity produce clinically significant weight loss, many individuals experience weight regain due to decreased adherence to these changes. In this two-arm, randomized trial, Veterans with obesity and a cohabitating adult support person will be randomized to participate in a virtual weight loss intervention based on the VA’s MOVE! program with or without their support person. Those who participate with their partner will learn and practice communication and support skills. We predict that the dyadic intervention will result in greater weight loss, improved social support, and enhanced quality of life at 72 weeks compared to the patient-focused intervention. If effective, the support intervention will contribute to the identification and implementation of successful, evidence-based approaches to reduce the prevalence of obesity and associated comorbidities among Veterans.

PHR: Project Narrative Tumor Treating Fields (TTFields) are a novel electric field therapy to treat glioblastoma, a deadly brain cancer. Currently, only solid/contrast enhancing regions of tumors are selected to deliver TTFields completely overlooking the infiltrative neoplastic components wheretumor recurrence is inevitably observed. To address this inadequacy in the treatment plan, we are proposing to use whole brain spectroscopy derived metabolic maps for better delineating the boundaries of these infiltrative tumors and subsequently employing sophisticated tools to ensure enhanced delivery of TTFields to the entire viable tumor bed in an effort to improve overall patient outcomes.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will not only reveal critical molecular insights into the role of ARID1A mutation in cancer and particularly ovarian cancer, but also provide a scientific rationale for developing urgently needed new pre-clinical therapeutic strategies for this disease. These studies will also serve as a prototype for other epigenetic therapeutic strategies for cancers with genetic alterations in other regulators of chromatin structure, a well-recognized feature of many cancer types. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission in terms of developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burden of human illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adaptive immune receptors (i.e. antibodies and T cell receptors) enable our body to fight off disease, “remember” pathogens, and train the immune system through vaccination. Immunologists have learned via high‐throughput sequencing that adaptive immune receptors have a truly remarkable diversity. In this proposal, we develop machine‐learning methods for these sequence data, which will allow us to predict the maturation, statistical distribution, and binding properties of adaptive immune receptors, and thus to better design vaccinations, autoimmune disease treatment, and immunotherapy treatment for cancer.

PHR: The proposal is to enhance the DANDI archive, an easy to use infrastructure for scientists to share, collaborate, and process data from neurophysiology experiments, which in turn form the basis for understanding cellular level mechanisms of brain function. Performing the proposed research will improve the archive to prepare it for the challenges arising from the significant growth of neuroscientific data. Such open data helps to increase collaboration and benefits researchers, but can also be used as educational materials in high schools and colleges. An open archive will facilitate data publishing and improve access by scientific communities across the world, and can accelerate scientific discoveries about the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Concerned partners (CPs) are a powerful and often underutilized source of influence for individuals who misuse alcohol. This project will: (1) identify specific behaviors enacted by CPs that relate to increases and decreases in their partner’s drinking behaviors; (2) use that information to develop a web-based intervention for CPs; and (3) evaluate the success of this intervention in reducing drinking and related problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal will use kidney SPECT/CT of Tc-99m-tilmanocept to evaluate the mesangial changes seen in diabetics across the spectrum of kidney disease as well as persons with hypertensive kidney disease, the next most common cause of kidney disease in patients with diabetes. We aim to demonstrate that these different disease types and stages can be differentiated with Tc-99m-tilmanocept SPECT/CT and can thus be used for future trials evaluating early diagnosis and treatment of diabetic nephropathy.

PHR: Patients with neuropsychiatric disorders (attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, substance use disorders, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, Parkinson’s disease, post-traumatic stress disorder and depression among many others) often carry altered activity in the human dopamine transporter gene (hDAT). This proposal aims to identify molecular mechanisms by which regulated hDAT activity is altered, enabling our understanding of the genetic etiologies of the hDAT-related diseases. Our ultimate goal is to reveal pathogenic hDAT sequence variants and facilitate the development of precision treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The understanding of brain disease is profoundly impaired by the very primitive understanding of the brain as a system. The BRAIN Initiative ambition to produce a dynamic picture of the functioning brain by developing and applying improved methods for large-scale monitoring of neural activity was designed to address this deficiency. We address this objective for single cell resolved activity, increasing by 10-50X the number of resolved single unites in routine electrophysiology, compatible with freely moving mice or rats and many applications for primates.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative  Opioid use disorder (OUD), a significant epidemic with comorbid depression, polysubstance use and neonatal abstinence syndrome, is currently treated with buprenorphine to reduce withdrawal, effects the social emotional brain circuits of that govern maternal caregiving thoughts and behaviors and influence infant development are unknown. This interdisciplinary project will employ multimodal and longitudinal brain imaging and measure parent-infant interactions to investigate how the maternal brain adapts to the early postpartum, focusing on the effects of buprenorphine with comparison groups of depression matched and healthy controls. The completion of this grant will yield brain-based biomarkers connected with inexpensive measures that will contribute to improved assessment and treatment of families suffering OUD, their children and society - which ultimately bears much of the cost for the common trans-generational problems of peripartum drug use.

PHR: The proposed research will develop patient-centered evidence-based anticoagulant therapy for secondary pre- vention in older ischemic stroke patients with atrial fibrillation. It is relevant to public health because the devel- opment and adoption of personalized evidence-based anticoagulant therapy are expected to reduce recurrent ischemic events, minimize treatment complications, and improve outcomes most meaningful to patients. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to enhance health and reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Anterior Cruciate Ligament reconstructions are a common procedure resulting in significant impairments in the quadriceps muscle, and females have worse outcomes than males. The identification of biological targets underlying poorer recovery in females after injury is lacking, limiting the development of evidence-based therapies. We propose to define the muscle molecular and cellular sex-based differences underlying poor functional recovery, the recovery of muscle function and gait mechanics, as well as determine the timing and magnitude of the psychosocial recovery differences between females and males to define sex as a biological variable across scales to mitigate these differences in recovery through novel interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative Substantial human capital investments by the National Institute on Aging (NIA) and private partners have led to a growing number of clinician-scientists in aging research from a diverse array of specialties and disciplines. The pipeline of early-stage and established investigators would benefit greatly from a national platform that will convey scientific and research knowledge, foster networking and collaboration, provide mentoring and career development support, and advance transdisciplinary research. The overall objective of the Clin-STAR Coordinating Center is to establish a robust, multi-faceted and highly-networked national platform that will organize activities and provide resources for the cultivation, connection, and synergy of clinician-scientists in aging research from disparate specialties across the US.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The change of quality of life in autism spectrum disorders (ASD) individuals is primarily attributed to social deficits, which may be associated, or even triggered by, atypical sensory processing, specifically tactile hypersensitivity. However, this relationship has not been investigated extensively and could be best explained by looking at how mouse models of ASD maladaptively respond to social touch and how social touch is encoded in the brain of these ASD models. This project will utilize a novel head-fixed behavioral assay in mice to investigate when avoidance behaviors and aversive facial expressions to social touch first emerge in development and neural circuit disruptions in the primary somatosensory cortex and basolateral amygdala (S1- BLA) circuit that underly social touch deficits in mouse models of ASD.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to VHA’s mission to “honor America’s Veterans by providing exceptional healthcare that improves their health and well-being.” Post-acute skilled home health care is a vital service for older Veterans who are discharged from VA Medical Centers to their home in need of additional nursing or therapy support. However, little is known about the decisions that influence the selection of the payer for home care services (i.e., VA versus Medicare), the quality of community home health care provided, and how these factors influence Veterans’ experiences of receiving skilled HHC and their health outcomes. Therefore, it is important to leverage both VA and Medicare data to understand HHC financing, quality, and outcomes for Veterans who receive skilled home health care, as well as the experiences of VA clinicians and staff, home health agencies, and Veteran and caregivers’ who receive this service to both inform the delivery of skilled home health care and improve Veterans’ health and well-being.

PHR: Most patients with cognitive impairment are diagnosed relatively late in the disease process, and about half of people living with dementia are undiagnosed. We have developed a low-cost tool called eRADAR (electronic health record Risk of Alzheimer's and Dementia Assessment Rule) that uses information in electronic health records to help identify patients with undiagnosed dementia. This study will determine whether a supported process of reaching out to patients with high eRADAR scores as part of primary care leads to earlier detection of dementia and improves patient care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) is a homeostatic pathway for the targeted degradation of unwanted or defective proteins in cells, and cancer cells are especially dependent on the UPS to maintain pathologic cell proliferation and survival. Therefore, the variety of proteins that comprise the UPS have become high priority targets for cancer drug development. The goal of my research is to harness computational design and iterative sequence optimization to generate potent, specific, and cell-permeable stapled peptides that target a distinct binding interface on UBE1, the most apical enzyme of the UPS, in order to suppress protein ubiquitination at its source and thereby reactivate apoptosis in treatment-resistant leukemia.

PHR: Photoreceptor dysfunction is one of the hallmark pathologies associated with retinal degenerative (RD) diseases that manifests in patients as a progressive loss of vision. This encompasses heterogenous diseases such as retinitis pigmentosa, which affects 1 in 3500 people worldwide and age-related macular degeneration, which is projected to affect 288 million people by 2040. We have shown modest exercise provides retinal neuroprotection in a mouse model of RD, through increased brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) signaling. The cellular modifications provoking neural protection and repair from exercise are not understood. Our proposal reveals novel data supporting retinal astrocyte and vasculature involvement in exercise-induced BDNF signaling. Our studies will illuminate the roles of retinal astrocytes and vasculature in this known neuroprotective therapy, ultimately optimizing exercise-based therapeutics and creating new pharmacological strategies targeting the underlying mechanisms of exercise-induced neuroprotection.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: In addition to defects in DNA repair and fork protection, we have uncovered that cells deficient in the BRCA- pathway genes have defects in restraining DNA replication during stress and ssDNA regions (gaps) develop. Thus, we propose to employ state-of-the-art experiments to map the molecular determinants of this BRCA- pathway fork restraint function and identify the gap making and avoiding machinery that we find is critical for therapy response and resistance, respectively. Lastly, we will re-examine models of therapy resistance previously attributed to restored DNA repair and fork protection and determine if gap suppression is instead the fundamental resistance mechanism.

PHR: Narrative We propose a multi-site, double-blind, randomized clinical trial of the 5-HT2A receptor agonist psilocybin for smoking cessation, based on pilot research suggesting potential for high rates of efficacy. The majority of individuals who try to quit smoking do not achieve long-term smoking abstinence with the medications that are currently available. Therefore, the proposed research will address a large unmet public health need to examine novel approaches for smoking cessation medications.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a first-in-human study that combines an adoptive cellular therapy modality, known as endogenous T cell (ETC) therapy with a therapeutic cancer vaccine (ISA103) targeting the broadly expressing PRAME tumor antigen. By boosting the in vivo frequency of the transferred T cells with a vaccine capable of directly activating PRAME -specific CTL and generating CD4 helper responses, we postulate that augmented persistence of transferred T cells and induction of antigen-spreading, will lead to more effective treatment for solid tumor malignancies and address the unmet clinical need of patients with uveal melanoma. It is anticipated that the results of this proof-of-concept study, developed through a robust scientific partnership between ISA Pharma and MD Anderson Cancer Center will allow us to broaden this triple T cell-based strategy to other patients and other tumor types.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid overdose has claimed the lives of over 450,000 adults in the United States since the turn of the century, an epidemic fueled in large part by physicians’ reliance upon opioids for chronic pain management. Successful mitigation of the opioid crisis is therefore dependent upon the identification of novel, non-opioid analgesics. By identifying key neural circuits involved in pain chronification, this project will pave the way for targeted, circuit- based therapies that effectively mitigate pain without the deleterious effects of long-term opioid use.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients and parents want to receive timely prognostic information, yet pediatric oncologists often delay or censor poor prognostic disclosure. Presently, the field of pediatric oncology lacks empiric data from stakeholders to characterize the optimal timing and process for patient/parent-centered prognostic disclosure and lacks a conceptual framework and clinical tools to encourage an individualized approach to prognostic communication across an advancing illness course. Under the guidance of my mentors, I will 1) characterize the preferences of patients, parents, and oncologists with respect to optimal content, timing, and delivery of prognostic disclosure, 2) partner with stakeholders to develop a framework and communication intervention, and 3) test the feasibility and acceptability of implementing this intervention to promote timely, individualized prognostic communication in the setting of advancing pediatric cancer.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from the parent grant application) T-cell lymphomas (TCL), comprising 10-15% of non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) in North America, are molecularly heterogeneous, poorly understood, and are associated with poor clinical outcomes. Most patients will develop recurrent or refractory disease that is resistant to currently available therapies. In an effort to better understand mechanisms that promote TCL pathogenesis and identify rational and clinically translatable therapeutic strategies, we will investigate the role of the T-cell receptor and the transcription factor GATA-3 in a genetically engineered TCL model and primary patient specimens using complementary genetic and pharmacologic approaches.

PHR: Back pain is frequently associated with degeneration of the intervertebral discs (IVDs) of the spine and represents a significant health and economic burden, particularly to our active duty military and Veteran populations. Current treatments for disc degeneration, such as spinal fusion, are limited in that they do not restore healthy disc structure or function. The purpose of this supplemental award is to provide a more detailed analysis of the inflammatory milieu of the degenerating IVD and evaluate the immunomodulatory potential of a novel tissue engineered IVD replacement. This will be achieved via long term studies in a large animal model under clinically relevant conditions. Immunophenotyping of cells within the degenerated IVDs and engineered disc replacements will be used to evaluate the immunomodulatory effect of the engineered replacements and how loading impacts these features. This work will drive clinical translation of our tissue engineered disc, significantly improving treatment options for Veterans suffering from disc degeneration and back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We propose a novel integrative approach that targets the 3 main morphological changes that underlie erectile dysfunction (ED), which are cavernous nerve (CN) degeneration, smooth muscle apoptosis, and penile fibrosis. This application is innovative because we are developing two novel peptide amphiphile nanofiber hydrogels for delivery of sonic hedgehog (SHH) protein to the CN and to the penis to promote regeneration and prevent penile apoptosis. These studies will have broad clinical application and impact since SHH nanofibers can be used to regenerate any peripheral nerve that SHH plays a role in maintaining nerve integrity including the CN, sciatic and facial nerves and because the SHH nanofibers are highly translatable for treatment of ED in prostatectomy and diabetic patients.

PHR: Narrative The molecular mechanisms responsible for the higher incidence of developing early and more aggressive prostate cancer (PCa) in African American (AA) men are still unknown. We aim to investigate the functional consequences of common genetic alterations affecting the tumor microenvironment (TME) associated with increased risk. In addition, we will evaluate the clinical utility with emphasis on developing potential new therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is a degenerative condition of language loss that affects many patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD), and for which effective treatments are currently lacking. While recent evidence suggests that noninvasive neuromodulation techniques like transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) may be helpful, a critical barrier to further progress in this field is the absence of research that: 1) examines the role of neuroplasticity in the language system in persons with PPA, 2) reveals how neuromodulation alters the dynamics of the language network in this disorder, and 3) uses advances in clinical and neuroscientific understanding of PPA to determine which individuals are most likely to respond to treatment. This project addresses these knowledge gaps by combining a sham-controlled treatment trial of high-definition tDCS (HD-tDCS) and concurrent behavioral language therapy with advanced neuroimaging network analysis, in order to determine where in the brain and when in the course of disease to stimulate in PPA, and to elucidate which patients neuromodulation interventions can be applied to most effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Modified Narrative Section  People with HIV (PWH) are almost always co-infected with CMV, and CMV can hijack the human immune system in ways that allows HIV to persist in the setting of modern antiretroviral therapy. Leveraging clinical trials to collect appropriate samples and data we will test a new CMV drug in PWH, and we will rigorously elucidate the mechanisms of how CMV helps HIV persist, like clonal expansion of CD4+ T cells carrying HIV and exhausting immune responses. By understanding exactly how CMV promotes HIV persistence, we can develop better HIV cure strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The objective of this technology optimization is to enable broad adoption of flexible polymer neural interface technology by engaging the neuroscience user community and developing designs that can be used across species from mouse to nonhuman primate. This work will result in library of different designs that target multiple brain regions from cortical to sub-cortical to deep brain as well as the specialized methods to enable accurate implantation to these targets. This collaborative effort advances polymer microelectrode array technologies to meet the large scale, high density goals of the BRAIN Initiative and establishes a dissemination path to make them widely available to the neuroscience and neuroengineering community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will begin the development of a culturally adapted psychosocial intervention for chronic pain for American Indian/Alaska Native (AI/AN) individuals at the Portland Area Indian Health Service – Yakama Service Unit. In the short-term, the study will provide the information necessary for adapting interventions (e.g., AI/AN pain beliefs, treatment preferences, perspectives on chronic pain measures) as well as information on whether it is feasible to conduct a fully-powered randomized controlled trial. In the long-term, the study will provide an evidence-based process for culturally adapting chronic pain interventions for tribal communities and potentially decrease pain disparities by providing effective psychosocial techniques for pain management that decrease pain intensity, decrease pain interference, and increase quality of life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism affects up to 1.6% of the pediatric population, and can result in significant long term impairments. Autism is typically diagnosed after 2 to 3 years of age and there is a great need for improved early screening. This research is highly relevant to both early identification and intervention for children with autism. By utilizing state of the art methods for the assessment of infant cry and neurobehavior, this project seeks to develop a screening tool/process that can be used in the first year of life. This research work has the potential to open new doors for early intervention and will lead to an improved understanding of the early developmental course of autism.

PHR: NARRATIVE Anticonvulsants are commonly prescribed to older adults after stroke to prevent seizures, but these drugs may not be necessary or the harms could outweigh the benefits. There is limited rigorous evidence guiding when and how physicians should prescribe this type of treatment. This project will use the real-world experience of millions of Medicare beneficiaries to generate this evidence and inform both policy and future clinical decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Demand for heart transplant in the United States far exceeds the supply of donor organs and as a result, nearly 500 patients die annually while awaiting a donor heart. The proposed study will establish the feasibility and benefits of strategies to narrow the gap between donor heart supply and demand, thereby reducing waiting times and improving survival. Such strategies will include 1) reducing the discard of sub-optimal but still viable donor hearts and 2) identifying and removing from the waitlist patients who would fare better with alternative treatments (in lieu of transplant).

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it addresses the critical challenge of reducing therapeutic resistance in breast cancer. This study is expected to advance the mechanistic understanding on the IFN1-induced cancer cell resistance to therapy, as well as identify a potential novel therapeutic target, ARID4B. This knowledge will inform the development of new medical interventions to treat breast cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study provides an unprecedented opportunity to expand a study of sleep to include important clinical and geriatric outcomes of falls and fractures. A simple home-based approach for identifying modifiable sleep characteristics was implemented in 4959 women who are already being followed for cardiovascular, cancer and cognitive outcomes. Extension of the study to include additional outcomes of falls and fractures is a cost-efficient opportunity to substantially expand our understanding of the impact of sleep disturbance on the health of older persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the U.S., heat is responsible for more fatalities than all other weather events and the burden of morbidity and mortality attributable to heat is expected to grow in coming decades, particularly in Southern communities, such as New Orleans. The relationship between heat and health is context-specific and local data can be used to inform heat preparedness activities. The proposed project will estimate the health burden of heat in New Orleans and identify individual and neighborhood characteristics, as well as behavior patterns, that increase vulnerability to heat.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Record numbers of Veterans are pursuing higher education. However, difficulties with attention, memory, irritability, and self-regulation often ‘derail’ Veterans with traumatic brain injury, post-traumatic stress and related issues as they pursue academic and life goals. Increasing engagement with rehabilitation amongststudent Veterans is a top priority, as access, stigma, and competing life demands often limit their use of traditional VA services. Innovations in treatment formulation and delivery that cross gaps between healthcare and education may be required to betterengage these Veterans. In this project, we will (a) assess the feasibility and acceptability of delivering remote cognitive interventions to improve cognitive-emotional regulation or education to optimize brain functioning for student Veterans; (b) characterize critical aspects of the training process, and (c) explore student insights on ways to further improve cognitive trainings to best meet their needs. This project will inform Veteran-centered care by tailoring interventions to the specific needs of student Veterans in a larger study.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is associated with increased risk of developing and succumbing to endometrial cancer (EC), with ~60% of EC patients being obese. We hypothesize that gyn-onocologists may be under-dosing obese EC patients treated with monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), such as atezolizumab, inadvertently decreasing their potential treatment efficacy in this obesity-modulated cancer, due to differences in the mononuclear phagocyte system (MPS) between obese and non-obese women. Thus, our goals are 1) to establish in this phase 1 trial the pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics (PK/PD) and the safe maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of atezolizumab + ONC201 in combination as an innovative promising treatment for EC, with expectation that higher dosing of atezolizumab will be required for obese women; 2) use the results and MTDs of these phase 1 trials to design future phase 2 clinical trials; and 3) create new biomarkers and strategies to individualize therapy of this unique atezolizumab/ONC201 combination that could be expanded in application to other immuno-oncology agents used to treat obese patients with EC or other cancer types.

PHR: Narrative Hypoxia, a stress factor is commonly associated with poor prognosis of solid tumors, such as breast cancer. Our striking observation revealed that tumor cells in chronic hypoxia show a remarkably active RNA Pol I and ERK signaling. Our studies will investigate a novel strategy to debilitate the stress response of the nucleolus in hypoxia to curb metastatic progression of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Osteoporosis is a major health care problem since approximately 10 million people over the age of 50 have been diagnosed with the disease and 33.6 million more are estimated to have low bone mass (osteopenia). TRAPPC9 is a novel protein in bone and the proposed studies will generate new information regarding its effects and mechanisms of action on bone cell development and function. Once we understand its full effects on bone and how it works to promote bone formation, this information will be helpful in developing new therapeutic strategies to selectively enhance bone formation in patients with clinically significant bone loss.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will not only reveal critical molecular insights into the role of ARID1A mutation in cancer and particularly ovarian cancer, but also provide a scientific rationale for developing urgently needed new pre-clinical therapeutic strategies for this disease. These studies will also serve as a prototype for other epigenetic therapeutic strategies for cancers with genetic alterations in other regulators of chromatin structure, a well-recognized feature of many cancer types. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission in terms of developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burden of human illness.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Veterans who experience a significant cardiac event (surgery, stent placement, heart attack) qualify for cardiac rehabilitation, which is associated with clear benefits in improving health and survival. Unfortunately, enrollment and participation in cardiac rehabilitation is approximately 10%. Many VA sites use home-based cardiac rehabilitation in order to provide greater access to Veterans. There is major potential to improve Veteran engagement in home-based cardiac rehabilitation by using digital health technology in order to provide social support, which is a critical component for engagement. In our clinical trial, we will compare home-based cardiac rehabilitation alone (usual care) versus home-based cardiac rehabilitation plus digital coaching. Digital coaching is considered as providing social support, education, feedback, and motivation through a private social networking group and text messaging. We will examine group differences in cardiac rehabilitation participation, functional capacity, physical activity, psychosocial, clinical, and social cognitive outcomes.

PHR: Suicide is a national public health problem that disproportionately affects Veterans. However, the toll associated with suicide goes way beyond the death of an individual. This study addresses the problems that it is unknown how many Veterans need intervention following exposure to suicide, what types of problems should be addressed and what intervention approaches might be most beneficial. The primary objective of this study is to describe the health and functional outcomes of suicide exposure among a cohort of Veterans at particularly high risk for suicide and of priority for VA suicide prevention strategies – post-9/11 Veterans transitioning to civilian life. Our second objective is to elucidate the reasons some Veterans develop persistent problems following suicide exposure while others do not. This study starts with quantitative (which is the priority of the study) followed by qualitative data collection and analysis to explain and expand the quantitative findings. Findings can inform strategies to support Veterans affected by a suicide loss.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Dr. Kirsch’s research activities focus on restoring shoulder, arm, and hand movements to individuals with extensive paralysis due to spinal cord injury (SCI). SCI is a devastating condition that often causes significant disability and loss of independence. There are approximately 296,000 individuals in the United States with a SCI, at least 42,000 of whom are Veterans eligible for VA care. Dr. Kirsch has used functional electrical stimulation to elicit contractions in paralyzed muscles that can power movements, and novel control methods to coordinate these muscle contractions to generate functional movements. He has also examined cutting edge “brain computer interface” techniques to give the users of such a system the ability to intuitively command the desired movements of the upper limb. Dr. Kirsch is also very active in “translational research” programs that assist researchers in developing their laboratory discoveries into products that improve the independence and overall health of Veterans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The DIAN-TU Primary Prevention Trial is a clinical trial that will test if Alzheimer's disease can be prevented by starting an anti-amyloid therapy at the earliest stages of the disease. It is a 4 year double blind, randomized placebo-controlled study of anti-amyloid based therapies in individuals at risk of dominantly inherited Alzheimer's disease that are enrolled at a point when they have evidence of little to no amyloid plaques as measured by PET scan. The results of this study will have substantial public health benefits by testing if Alzheimer disease can be prevented by stopping amyloid pathology from developing.
