IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to identify how the nutrient-sensing cell of the intestine, the enteroendocrine cell, may signal changes in nutrient availability to other cells within the gut. This has significant implications for how changes in dietary intake or pharmacological manipulation of enteroendocrine peptides may influence the capacity for regeneration, nutrient absorption, and overall metabolic health. With the staggering rates of metabolic and digestive disease in the United States, understanding how enteroendocrine cells regulate gut function is a pressing public health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Arm strength is important for taking care one’s self. Predicting whether arm weakness due to a stroke will or will not improve would allow for more efficient and effective testing of new treatments, and more individualized treatment decisions. The VERIFY study will establish the ability of noninvasive transcranial magnetic stimulation and MRI to reliably predict patient outcomes in the important, early period of stroke recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse pregnancy outcomes and mental health conditions, such as posttraumatic stress disorder and depression, increase the risk of for cardiovascular disease in women. For some women, acute APOs (preeclampsia and preterm delivery) are also traumatic events that may precipitate the development of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression after pregnancy, but existing studies are limited. This research will utilize complementary data sources (prospective cohort studies, electronic health records, and qualitative interviews) to disentangle the complex relationships between APOs, mental health conditions, and cardiovascular disease across the life course, characterize the mental health sequelae following pregnancies complicated by preeclampsia or preterm delivery, and inform future strategies to reduce cardiovascular risk in women.

PHR: Project Narrative 90Y radiation lobectomy (90Y-RL) is a novel treatment paradigm for patients with unresectable HCC enabling both locoregional control of disease and may achieve adequate FLR hypertrophy for resection. The proposed project investigates the underlying mechanisms of the liver atrophy/hypertrophy complex following 90Y-RL using quantitative MR imaging and investigates the influence of radiation dose and glass bead embolic load on parenchymal dosimetry using non-FDG PET/CT. We hypothesize that 90Y-RL patient recurrence free survival will be similar to that of patients with HCC deemed to be surgical candidates at presentation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Limb malformations are the second most common congenital abnormality and are becoming increasingly linked to rare noncoding variants in transcriptional enhancers, short DNA sequences that activate gene expression. Yet, the disease mechanisms by which these rare noncoding variants disrupt normal limb development remain unclear. In this proposal, I will use novel transgenic mouse technology and single-cell epigenomics to determine the genetic factors mediating the unique susceptibility of limb-specific enhancers to pathogenic noncoding variants.

PHR: NARRATIVE Breast cancer (BC) is the most commonly diagnosed cancer and cause of cancer mortality in Asian/Pacific Islander (API) and Hispanic women; BC mortality varies substantially by immigrant status but factors underlying these disparities are unknown. This study will examine the multilevel (neighborhood and individual) influence of social networks on health behaviors and BC outcomes in diverse women, focusing on immigrant API and Hispanic women. Evaluating the influence of social networks on health behaviors and BC survival is central to identifying factors underlying BC disparities in ethnically diverse immigrant women, particularly those factors underlying favorable BC outcomes despite socioeconomic disadvantage.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While individuals ≥65 years and older makeup 40% of all inpatient surgeries and suffer from significantly increased risk of morbidity and mortality, there are no specific strategies in place to optimize their surgical care to improve outcomes. The American College of Surgeons (ACS) Geriatric Surgery Verification Program (GSV) introduced 30 evidence-based standards to systematically improve surgical care and outcomes. This proposal will develop guided implementation science approaches to develop strategies to increase the systematic uptake of ACS GSV program to (1) guide successful implementation of GSV program that will improve the patient outcomes significantly while reducing costs and (2) support the further training of Dr. Sevdenur Cizginer in dissemination and implementation science to become an independent researcher in aging research to enhance the surgical care of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Title: Infant atlas of brain perfusion This proposal will establish new age-specific population-averaged infant brain perfusion atlases and delineate the infant brain physiology-function and physiology-behavior correlations by optimizing a novel arterial spin labelling MR imaging technique. These atlases will serve as a clinical reference by providing normal distribution and variability of regional cerebral blood flow at multiple critical infant developmental stages as well as fill the knowledge gap of lacking fundamental infant brain physiological properties. The proposed project has a broad impact on detecting abnormality of brain disorders and conducting targeted early intervention to ameliorate functional or behavioral alteration related to perfusion changes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will design self-propelled urease-fueled DNA origami-based nanoparticles (DNA-SPPs) that can disrupt the topical biofilm matrix and deliver antibiotics in most acidic regions of the biofilms for efficient bacteria killing. Aim 1 will optimize the enzymatic propulsion mechanism for directed locomotion in different urea and pH distributions, while Aims 2 and 3 will respectively demonstrate the efficacy of DNA-SPP-mediated degradation of the biofilm matrix and DNA-SPP-powered delivery of antibiotics to kill bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Outcomes of this study will provide data-driven evidence to improve novel vaccine candidates and vaccination strategies aimed at inducing protective immune responses against tuberculosis. The study focuses on a novel indication for a licensed product, the BCG vaccine, which is not currently administered to adolescents in countries with high tuberculosis burden. A realistic estimate of vaccine efficacy and duration of protection in susceptible populations are the main determinants to evaluate the public health impact and cost-effectiveness of such intervention.

PHR: Lack of social connection—especially loneliness—is a common and powerful contributor to suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, functional decline, and even death. The COVID-19 pandemic and its long aftermath amplify risk for loneliness, health problems, and suicide as well as other causes of mortality. A population of particular concern is older adults and patients with medical or psychiatric problems who have limited engagement in treatment. Caring Contacts is an evidence-based suicide prevention intervention that can potentially help. In this project, we will conduct a clinical trial of an adaptation of Caring Contacts tailored to older Veterans who miss their VA healthcare appointments. This project will help advance scientific understanding of how, and in what ways, Caring Contacts works. It will also evaluate a timely, pragmatic, low-cost, and scalable intervention with applicability to post-pandemic treatment engagement and future disasters.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent stroke trials have shown that with the help of imaging, late thrombectomy is beneficial. We propose to further the development of pH and diffusion kurtosis imaging for improved ischemic tissue characterization. We will test the refined mismatch paradigm using permanent and transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) rats, laying the foundation for future clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Using a collection of novel monoclonal antibodies raised to structurally-defined species of mutant huntingtin exon1 (mHTTex1), we will characterize the structure and biochemical properties of various mHTTex1 assemblies, map the conformations influencing misfolding, seeding, and oligomerization in vitro, identify and characterize neuroinvasive species in human neurons and determine whether they trigger pathology in mouse models of HD. Moreover, we will examine whether any of the recombinant conformation-specific antibodies secreted in the CNS of HD mice inhibit the amplification of mHTT assemblies, and further validate their therapeutic properties. These studies will fill some of the knowledge gaps in the pathogenesis of HD, introduce novel therapeutic targets, and a collection of well-characterized antibodies and their recombinant versions for diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of protective immunity to influenza is of central importance to public health, yet little is known about how natural infections and vaccinations contribute to the development of protection against diverse influenza strains over time. This research uses observations from a large, longitudinal pediatric cohort to fit mathematical models to explain how protection evolves early in life. The results will contribute to fundamental knowledge of influenza epidemiology and the development of next-generation influenza vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Parent-based alcohol interventions (PBI) are an effective strategy for preventing alcohol-related risk during the transition into college; however, our understanding of how well PBIs work to protect against these risks is based on controlled studies that are unlikely to produce the same results in the real-world. The proposed project addresses this limitation by developing and optimizing low-cost PBIs so that they are maximally engaging to parents, appealing to university stakeholders, and effective at preventing and reducing alcohol- related risk under real-world conditions. The overall impact of this research can be tremendous given that the focus is not only only identifying the most effective PBI approach outside of tightly controlled studies, but also on how to improve the adoption of these programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Intubating newborns for mechanical ventilation is challenging due to their size and delicate nature. Unfortunately, nearly 40% of initial intubation attempts result in accidental misplacement of the endotracheal tube in the esophagus instead of the trachea or incorrectly in the trachea or bronchus, and it is critical to detect such tube misplacement promptly. This proposal combines deep learning Simultaneous Multi Source Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT)-based confirmation of tube placement with EIT images of lungs being ventilated, resulting in a real-time, closed-loop system for tube placement detection and ventilation imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The ultimate purpose of this research is to investigate what cellular, physical, and biochemical characteristics of the environment provided by the membrane in the Masquelet technique are responsible for the procedure’s success in reconstructing large segmental bone defects via grafting. Our results could save hundreds of thousands of limbs that would otherwise be amputated and improve patient care by refining the procedure and expanding its use. It will also uncover novel bone repair mechanisms that may be applicable to other bone formation scenarios like non-union and fusions.

PHR: Narrative: GBM is the most common primary brain tumor in adults, and recurrence is almost inevitable. The TIME model developed in this project will enable early prediction of GBM recurrence and salvage radiotherapy without harming the essential neurological functions. The early intervention for GBM recurrence has the potential to delay tumor growth and prolong patient survival.

PHR: Project Narrative The epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) program endows breast cancer cells with stemness, therapy resistance and metastatic competence. The intermediate filament protein vimentin serves an important biological role in sustaining cells that have undergone EMT, and regulated changes in its phosphorylation status (termed “phospho-malleability”) are critical for its function. The proposed studies aim to link vimentin phospho-malleability uniquely to cancer stem cells and develop strategies to treat metastasis, including increasing sensitivity to commonly used chemotherapeutic drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Missense-loss of function mutations in TTC7A result in severe infantile-onset congenital diarrhea and intestinal inflammation, with a median survival age of patients with TTC7A disease less than 1 year. To expand our understanding of these patient mutations, we are exploring how TTC7A causes symptoms in an evolving model of epithelial cell development and cellular polarity in primary patient derived organoids. The findings from these studies will be broadly impactful for the developmental biology of the GI tract, congenital enteropathies and inflammatory bowel diseases.

PHR: Effective psychotherapies for depression are available in VA but are underutilized by therapists working in specialty mental health clinics. Reasons for low use have not been empirically investigated. Findings from research on the implementation of evidence-based psychotherapies for other conditions such as PTSD cannot be fully generalized to depression because depression care is organized differently in VA. In this project, we use an explanatory sequential mixed-methods approach to examine contextual and system factors that impact delivery of evidence-based psychotherapies for depression as well as explore the impact of potential therapist- and patient-level factors. Findings will inform an intervention framework that will help our partners and stakeholders in the field to prioritize barriers on which to intervene and identify promising solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Dengue, Chikungunya, Zika and other mosquito-borne diseases continue to pose a major global health burden through much of the world, despite the widespread distribution of insecticides and other interventions. Novel strategies have been proposed to control these diseases, including the release of mosquitoes transfected with Wolbachia and engineered with gene drive systems, the safety and efficacy of which critically depends on a detailed understanding of mosquito movement. In this project, we will use genetic data to quantify the fine- scale movement patterns of Aedes aegypti mosquito vectors and explore implications for novel intervention strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide an inclusive technical training to cover key facets of the iterative medical device development process, spanning discovery, invention, regulatory decision-making, prototyping, testing and commercialization. The main objective of this training is to improve students’ problem recognition skills, their motivation to propose and validate a solution, and their ability to apply multidisciplinary knowledge. This training opportunity will allow students to apply fundamental knowledge learned from classes to real applications in team-based biomedical device design, and will prepare students for a career in healthcare technology research and development.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite a burgeoning elderly population (i.e., globally the number of individuals older than 50 years old is projected to increase to 1.2 billion by 2025), there are insufficient clinicians and researchers to meet this demand. Through this NIA MSTEM project (Advancing Diversity in Aging Research through Undergraduate Education at the University of the District of Columbia), we aim to expose, train, and mentor a diverse cadre of underrepresented minority undergraduate students at the University of the District of Columbia, a Historically Black College and University, to become the next generation of researchers and professionals contributing to novel investigations and interventions tied to aging-related issues.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Cognitive impairment, particularly slowed cognitive processing speed (CPS), is prevalent among 67% of the nearly one million American adults living with multiple sclerosis (MS). The proposed Phase-II, randomized controlled trial examines the effect of a highly-developed and refined Internet-delivered physical activity (PA) intervention for yielding immediate and sustained improvements in remotely-assessed CPS among 280 persons with mild MS-related ambulatory disability who demonstrate impaired CPS. The research proposed in this application, if successful, will provide Class I evidence for the efficacy of an Internet-delivered PA intervention as an accessible and translatable approach for rehabilitation of impaired CPS among persons with MS who most need such an intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19/SARS-CoV-2 is now a world-wide pandemic threatening humanity, with emerging Variants of Concern threatening the efficacy of drugs and vaccines against it. This project will seek define the limits of the B cell and antibody response directed against the Receptor Binding Domain (RBD) of the Spike protein in their ability to protect against current and future potential variations in the SARS-CoV-2 virus. We will also address the fundamental question if RBD-specific immunity differs whether it is the result of natural infection and vaccination.

PHR: Patients diagnosed with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) suffer dismal prognosis due to limited treatment options, especially for those with locally advanced pancreatic cancer or metastatic disease. We recently developed an innovative therapy that resulted in compelling and durable responses in preclinical PDAC models. This application will translate these promising findings into a clinical trial and further optimize this therapy to be effective against metastatic disease.

PHR: Previously believed to be uncommon, subscapularis tendon tears are present in 50% of patients undergoing rotator cuff repair. Unrecognized subscapularis tears may be a source of chronic shoulder pain and dysfunction. The objective of this study is to determine the effects of subscapularis tendon tears on shoulder joint damage, function, and pain. The study will identify the mechanisms of these changes and delineate the contribution of the tear alone versus the potential compounding effect of a tear in the setting of shoulder overuse. Results will highlight the importance of detection and influence future clinical studies to reduce pain, improve function, and preserve shoulder joint health. With the high prevalence of subscapularis tears now recognized, this study will have significant impact on the aging and veteran populations, and is highly relevant to the Veterans Health Administration’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinician burnout has reached endemic levels and is an established risk factor for cardiovascular disease, but knowledge gaps in assessing and understanding the longitudinal development of burnout hamper risk-based prevention and targeted interventions. We propose a novel digital phenotyping approach using deep learning based on a video-recorded interview about the experiences of emergency clinicans at work with the aim to identify objective digital biomarkers that predict burnout and cognitive functioning in emergency clinicians. We will determine how candidate digital biomarkers relate to physiological markers of chronic stress, and test the potential of digital biomarkers to self-manage burnout risk and promotes low-threshold burnout prevention.

PHR: Pancreatic cancer is currently the 3rd leading cause of cancer death in the United States with an estimated 56,770 new pancreatic cancer diagnosed in the United States in 2019. Prior epidemiological studies have been limited in size and lacked representation from individuals of African ancestry. We will discover new pancreatic cancer loci by conducting the first genetic study of pancreatic cancer risk specifically focused on African Americans as well as doubling the size of existing GWAS studies of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to develop a new senior year capstone design course and summer immersion program for Bioengineering students at George Mason University where three neighboring clinical centers will be hosting students for summer immersion. Nursing and Health Informatics and Administration faculty and students will join Bioengineering students and faculty in this senior design program to provide a bread of skills for solving clinical challenges involving medical data and patient-oriented care. Industry advisors will be members of the advising teams to provide guidance on marketability and product development for novel solutions to newly identified clinical needs. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative About half of extremely premature infants develop lung disease (bronchopulmonary dysplasia), which is associated with high rates of poor outcomes. A large ongoing trial in the NICHD Neonatal Research Network will evaluate whether hydrocortisone treatment reduces bronchopulmonary dysplasia and improves outcomes at 2 years in high-risk preterm infants. The proposed study will measure how hydrocortisone and lung disease affect the functional respiratory and developmental outcomes of this established trial population at 5 years old, or early school age.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) patients frequently suffer from relapse and resistant disease with a large number of these resistance mechanisms remaining elusive. From a genetic screen followed by functional validation and clinical genomic correlation, we identified a putative resistance biomarker in SCLC for both current and novel drug therapies (i.e. cisplatin and PARP inhibitors, respectively). This proposal aims to understand how this biomarker works in a protein-recycling pathway (i.e. ubiquitin-proteasome pathway) and DNA repair with identification of novel treatments for treatment resistant/relapsed SCLC dependent on this biomarker to improve outcomes for afflicted patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is an infectious disease that continues to cause extensive morbidity and mortality throughout tropical and sub-tropical regions of the developing world, especially among young children in sub-Saharan Africa. This project focuses on the ability of malaria parasites to avoid the human immune response and to cause severe disease. A better understanding of these processes will lead to new forms of treatment that will help to relieve the enormous public health burden that malaria inflicts on the developing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The overarching goal of this project is to evaluate the activity of the Tat inhibitor, didehydro-Cortistatin A (dCA), for inhibition of HIV transcription. Tat inhibitors are not yet part of the clinical antiretroviral ammunition despite their immense potential at shutting down particle production from infected cells and blocking Tat toxicity. We expect to gain valuable insight into the potentially transformative benefits of adding HIV transcriptional inhibitors to current antiretroviral therapy, whether dCA could act as a single-therapy to block HIV expression, and whether dCA can limit virus recrudescence when therapy is interrupted.

PHR: The Covid pandemic and the continued rise of fentanyl and stimulant use have dramatically worsened the national public health crisis of substance use in the US. PHR: One in three women and one in six men over age 50 will suffer a spine fracture in their remaining lifetime. This project focuses on determining how age-related changes in the structure of a key region of the bone in the spine, and degeneration of the intervertebral discs adjacent to this bone, affect the likelihood of fracture.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Re: Sani Kizilbash, MBBS, MPH (eRA Commons ID: skizilbash, FOA # RFA-FD-21-001) WSD0922-FU is a novel drug which both penetrates into brain cancers and blocks a genetic change in the cancer (EGFR) that is critical for brain cancer growth and survival. The clinical trial proposed in this research study will determine the safety of WSD0922-FU in patients with brain cancers and will provide valuable data on how effective this drug can be in these patients. The results of this research will accelerate progress in developing new treatment strategies for patients with these brain cancers, and may eventually improve patient survival.

PROJECT_TITLE: Phase I study to evaluate safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics and anti-tumor activity of WSD0922-FU

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Epilepsy is now believed to result from aberrant activity of multiple neural “nodes” that together create a self- reinforcing network phenomenon. Standard clinical electrodes used in the diagnosis and treatment of drug- resistant epilepsy do not offer sufficiently fine resolution for microscale interrogation of the epileptogenic networks. This project aims to deliver a fully wireless multi-thousand channel electrode system with large-scale but precise cortical coverage, which will advance our understanding and treatment of epilepsy through analysis of neural activity at an unprecedented resolution, as demonstrated in acute human studies, semichronic animal safety and efficacy tests, and a small clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Scleroderma is a chronic disease of the connective tissue that is characterized by excessive accumulation of fibrous material (i.e. collagen) in the skin and ultimately in the lungs and other internal organs leading to multiple organ failure and death. Although there is no cure for this disease, research progress in animals and humans has led to better understanding of the disease process, and possible treatment options that can halt or reverse the disease are on the horizon. Recently, our research identified that an FDA-approved drug (for other disease) might be effective for scleroderma, and we now propose to conduct additional studies to develop the drug, as well as understand the mechanism(s) by which it blocks collagen accumulation in cells obtained from scleroderma patients, and in animal models of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative WHO estimates that there are currently 5 million humans living with some form of lupus. There is a great need for developing effective therapies for lupus, a condition that is difficult to diagnose and treat due to variability of symptoms from person to person. The goal of this grant is to engineer highly potent lymphatic system-targeting nanoparticles for customized delivery of cyclosporine, an immunosuppressive drug often used as last option due inherent shortcomings of conventional formulations, such as poor lymphoid targeting and toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We will perform a detailed cartography of the metabolic programing of the immune cells in the gastrointestinal tract and adjacent tissues and probe the role of metabolism in driving HV pathogenesis by administration of a western diet (WD, rich in fats and sugars, low in fiber) and therapeutic interventions with statins and assessment of their impact on the reservoir seeding, maintenance and reactivation. We developed and optimized the assays necessary for the proposed studies and established strategic collaborations with academic and industry leaders in this field. Importantly, if our strategy is successful, our project could have a major impact in the management of HIV patients, either alone or in combination with latency reversing agents, and will represent a significant step towards a better control of HIV.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Bell, Thomas, J.): Project Narrative: The first public resource correlating gene expression and genetic variation in pediatric tissues from all major organ systems in the human body will be available to scientists upon the completion of the developmental Genotype-Tissue Expression (dGTEx). To enable this groundbreaking effort, the pediatric Biospecimen Procurement Center (BPC) will provide high-quality tissue samples from a cohort of pediatric donors for the dGTEx project to the pediatric Laboratory Analysis Data Collection Center (LDACC) suitable for their experimental analysis. This proposal supports the development and implementation of the BPC to empower the advancement of pediatric research and the development of new clinical approaches to treat pediatric disorders. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall aim of the proposed program of research is to better characterize and improve rediction of outcomes in the clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis clinical population. This will lead to substantial benefits for clinical care (using dynamic risk calculators to estimate risk of a range of outcomes for individual patients, informing treatment strategy), healthcare services (informing decision-making regarding allocation of resources), and for research in this field (stratification of samples for treatment trials, directing the engagement of treatment targets, and refining aetiological models). The broad aim will be achieved by leveraging a recently established network of early psychosis service systems across Australia, including EPPIC and PACE at Orygen, to recruit, comprehensively assess and follow a large sample of CHR patients, with international partners recruiting an independent sample for validation purposes and to test generalizability of findings across healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The current standard of care for ACL injuries (400,000 each year) is ACL reconstruction, which is good at stabilizing the knee but requires compromising other uninjured structures around the knee to obtain an autograft that is subsequently used to replace the ACL. Further the early posttraumatic OA is not mitigated despite ACL reconstruction. A new technique, Bridge-Enhanced ACL Repair (the BEAR technique), where the ligament is stimulated to heal using a tissue engineered scaffold, has shown promising results in preclinical testing with lower rates of osteoarthritis and in initial safety cohort and small clinical trial. We now propose to conduct a 200 patient, multicenter, randomized controlled clinical trial of this novel technique against our current gold standard autograft ACL reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are currently no interventions that predictably and durably shift the human vaginal microbiome toward the optimal Lactobacillus dominant microbial community associated with lower risk for infection, cervical dysplasia and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Antibiotics and probiotics, or a combination of the two have been tried, with limited success. We propose a randomized trial of vaginal microbiota transplant in women with recurrent bacterial vaginosis, as an in vivo experimental model to better define the factors that drive composition of the vaginal microbiota. We will perform deep sequencing analysis and comprehensive characterization of host, donor and transplanted material, which will allow us to assess causal relationships between microbial features and colonization, and identify novel strategies for a durable, predictable intervention for vaginal health.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Youth in all types of justice settings are at substantial risk for suicidal behavior (SB) and correlated poor outcomes, yet protocols for SB identification and service delivery, while common for those in secure care, are rare for those in community settings (e.g., probation). e-Connect is one of the few evidence-based, digital clinical-decision support systems that assists probation officers in identification of SB and associated behavioral health need, and in successful referral of youth across systems to improve youth uptake of behavioral health treatment. In this proposal, we address a critical public and juvenile justice health need – identifying and preventing SB in youth on probation -- as we scale-up e-Connect and identify implementation strategies that will ensure the successful transfer of knowledge, skill and expertise in delivering e-Connect to support the more widespread, sustained and rigorous adoption of e-Connect in new contexts.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The decision process regarding treatment with chemotherapy in older women with early-stage breast cancer can be difficult. Patients and physicians as must not only consider the benefits and side-effects of treatments, but also the other medical conditions that a patient may be dealing with and a patient's own personal values and preferences. The goal of our project is the development of a decision-aid to be used by patients and physicians to help navigate this important decision process.

PHR: Whole Health STEPS (Structured Tiered Engagement with Peer Support) is designed to improve functional outcomes for primary care Veterans with mental health concerns who are not actively engaged in mental health services. Whole Health STEPS uses a Peer Support Specialist, or Peer, to provide support for Veterans to make progress on wellness goals using the Whole Health model. The level of support provided will be determined based on Veterans’ progress and will be stepped-up based on pre-defined decision points through four levels of care until Veterans receive the level of support they need. Whole Health STEPS will improve existing VA healthcare services through offering a non-mental health referral option for Veterans with mental health concerns who are not engaged in services, providing a structured package of existing Whole Health services that enrolls Veterans in the appropriate level of care, and providing a structured service for peers in primary care settings to offer to primary care Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus (STN DBS) can provide motor benefit yet occasional mood and cognitive side effects in Parkinson disease (PD). It is thought that downstream network level effects are a critical mechanism of STN DBS’s influence on motor and non-motor behavior, however our ability to test this hypothesis has been limited due to safety concerns about magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in people with DBS. We have developed a safe and novel high-density diffuse optical tomography (HD-DOT) system for measuring brain networks in cortex. With HD-DOT, we will test hypotheses about networks that are responsive to important characteristics of STN DBS (e.g. location) and their relationship to motor and non-motor function. This information could help with guiding the selection of DBS parameters for clinical treatment, identify cortical areas involved in the benefits or side effects of DBS, and reveal fundamental properties of cortical network plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Monoclonal antibodies have revolutionized the treatment of many malignancies, autoimmune disorders, and infectious disease, but have poor patient adherence due to required repeat injections. Plasma cells engineered to express therapeutic monoclonal antibodies may provide an alternative therapy that may only need to be dosed once in order to provide life-long therapeutic effects. This proposal seeks to generate anti-EBV monoclonal antibody secreting primary plasma cells and validate their ability to provide protection from EBV infection in an autologous humanized mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Intracranial atherosclerotic disease (ICAD), is one of the largest causes of stroke in the world. After surviving the initial ICAD stroke, roughly 1 of 8 will have a second devastating stroke within the next year. There is currently no way to determine who will fall victim to the second ICAD stroke. The use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is widespread in the evaluation of patients ICAD. Typically, MRI is used to locate the pathological narrowing (i.e. stenosis) of a blood vessel in the brain (intracranial stenosis/plaque). We will develop new MRI scans to measures a patients’ ability to re-route around a stenosis, gradual loss of compensatory reserve and the likelihood that the stenosis “throws off” a blood clot. It is these risk factors of an that could change the management to prevent an impending stroke. Our long term goal is to develop advance MRI scans that create images to better identify patients destine for a stoke, so that eventually the disease can be aggressively treated to PREVENT a secondary stroke.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune homeostatic state influences immune responses to infection, but is itself is a function of age, environmental stressors, and underlying genetics. Therefore, it is critical to understand the interplay between these factors and their overall impact on systemic and organ specific immunity at the steady state. This proposal studies the mechanism by which genetic variants in Methyl-CpG binding domain protein 1 regulates steady state antibody levels, and further proposes to extend the work on immune homeostasis to investigate the interaction between age and cytomegalovirus in modifying the immune architecture in the lungs and responses to respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infects one-third of the world’s population and causes almost 1.3 million deaths per year, including 100, 000 children. Approximately 90% of infected persons have latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI), have protective immunity and remain well, but 10% develop primary tuberculosis (TB) soon after infection or reactivation TB many years later. TB is the leading cause of death in HIV-infected persons and more than half a million coinfected people die annually. Children are more susceptible to TB infection, due to an immature immune system. HIV infection in children markedly increases susceptibility to TB. To develop adequate prophylaxis or therapy, it is important to understand immune responses to Mtb. Identification of HIV+ children with LTBI who are at greatly increased risk for development of TB would allow treating only high-risk children, facilitating completion of therapy for LTBI and preventing future development of TB. To identify these children, it is important to pinpoint the nature of the defective immune responses that permit development of active TB in HIV+LTBI+ pediatric patients. This proposal will identify a novel memory-like NK cell subpopulation mediated mechanisms that regulate immune responses and pinpoint the nature of the defective responses that permit development of active TB in HIV-LTBI+ and HIV+LTBI+ children. These studies will lay the groundwork for strategies to develop novel anti-tuberculosis vaccines that stimulate strong NK cell mediated immunity in HIV+ and HIV- children with LTBI, and reduce development of TB.

PHR: Narrative Despite maximal surgery, radiation and chemotherapy, glioblastoma (GBM) remains invariably recalcitrant, and necessitates development of new therapies. We have developed a novel FDA-IND approved agent (BB-19304, Sayour) utilizing RNA-lipid nanoparticles (RNA-LPs) to reprogram innate/adaptive immunity against GBM. In this proposal, we will explore the safety, maximum tolerated dose (MTD), and immunologic activity of RNA-LPs in a first-in-human clinical trial (NCT04573140) for patients with newly-diagnosed GBM.

Understanding how Morrbid functions at the molecular level in CD4+ T cells is expected to identify pathways that could be targeted to improve allergy treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The microbial community colonizing a newborn baby's gastrointestinal tract is very important for the ongoing development of that community, which has a strong impact on the optimal development of the baby's immune system, leading to better child and adult health and specifically the prevention of allergy and allergic asthma. This collection of projects will identify relationships between factors influencing a mother's gastrointestinal and vaginal microbes during pregnancy, and how these factors and the mother's microbes affect her newborn's gastrointestinal microbial community and immune system development from birth through the first years of life in both human and mouse studies. We believe that taken together these advances in understanding will lay the foundation for a strategy for the primary prevention of allergies and asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: LAY SUMMARY Overactivation of the inflammatory response underlies a multitude of inflammatory diseases, and the Abbott lab attempts to identify novel proteins that can be targeted pharmaceutically to halt these diseases. To this end, we have identified small molecule inhibitors of the kinase, RIPK2, a key inflammatory kinase. The current application aims to extend this work by studying the kinase activity of RIPK2. Which proteins does it phosphorylate? Which signaling pathways does it influence, and can we identify clinical scenarios in which its inhibition would help ameliorate disease? Answers to these questions are important as our RIPK2 inhibitors move into patients.

ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Many Veterans who have cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) still smoke cigarettes or drink too much alcohol, which worsens these diseases. The VA has many programs and treatments available for Veterans who are ready and willing to change these behaviors, but there are many patients who are not yet ready. Patient- aligned care teams (PACTs), which include primary care mental health integration (PCMHI) providers, are the ideal setting to reach Veterans who are not ready to change smoking or hazardous drinking and discuss ways to increase readiness. Helping Veterans understand the risks of these behaviors, the possible benefits of changing, and how and why they engage in these behaviors is key to increasing readiness and intention to change; this intervention can occur during a Veteran's already-scheduled PACT appointment for optimal convenience. Incorporating Veterans' and providers' treatment preferences will enhance the intervention is acceptable, Veteran-centered, and able to be successfully implemented into real-world PACT clinical practice.

PHR: NARRATIVE In many cancers, a clear understanding of the tumor microenvironment including the presence, antigen- specificity and functionality of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) is revolutionizing therapeutic approaches. Yet for KS we have a dearth of information about the nature of TILs and whether the tumor microenvironment is suppressing their anti-neoplastic function in an HIV-1 dependent manner. This project seeks to rectify this knowledge gap in a Case (HIV-1+/KS+) versus Control ((HIV-1+/KS-) design by comparatively investigating the phenotypes and the functionality of TILs in comparison to the same cells in the peripheral immune system and by comparing the tumor and peripheral immune cell expression patterns.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to identify new driver genes and potential therapeutic targets in the Group 3 subtype of medulloblastoma, which is an aggressive pediatric brain cancer with poor outcomes. This career development grant will provide the applicant with research training to investigate the non-canonical protein, ASNSD1 uORF, as a novel Group 3 medulloblastoma driver gene. The information gained by this project will enable future study of ASNSD1 uORF as a potential therapeutic target in Group 3 medulloblastoma and demonstrate the importance of non-canonical proteins as disease driver genes.

PHR: Although multiple national efforts have been introduced to address Veteran suicide, Veteran suicide rates remain high and are elevated compared with the general population. Systematic reviews have identified few interventions that effectively decrease suicide risk. One promising area for intervention is social connectedness, which has been identified as a strong protective factor. However, little research has been done on interventions that directly target social connectedness. Studies also suggest that supported engagement with community activities is associated with positive mental health outcomes, but such strategies have not been studied among Veterans. The current project proposes to develop and pilot a multicomponent, peer- support facilitated intervention for increasing social connectedness through participation in community activities among Veterans at elevated risk of death by suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electrographic seizures (ESz) and some epileptiform abnormalities (e.g. high-frequency periodic discharges HF-PD) captured on continuous EEG (cEEG) are common after severe traumatic brain injury (sTBI) and are associated with supply-demand mismatch, in-hospital neurologic deterioration, and outcome in a variety of conditions. A gap in knowledge exists in the treatment of sTBI patients regarding whether ESz and HF-PD result in secondary brain injury and respond to anti-seizure drug treatment. The goal of this project is to link the relationship between established biomarkers of metabolic demand (PbtO2), EEG abnormalities (ESz and HF- PD), clinical outcome, and treatment, to identify dynamic EEG biomarkers of secondary injury that will power future interventional trials targeting hypermetabolism to improve functional outcomes for sTBI patients.

PHR: The number of women in the United States dying during or around pregnancy has been increasing for the past thirty years. Women from racial and ethnic minorities, women who live in rural areas, and women with low- income have a higher risk than other women of dying during or around pregnancy. Many of these deaths are related to pre-existing chronic health conditions and may be preventable by improving women’s health before they become pregnant. Women Veterans have a high prevalence of chronic medical and mental health conditions; little is known about their maternal outcomes. This project will use quantitative and qualitative research methods to understand how women Veterans’ pre-pregnancy health conditions, social characteristics, healthcare experiences, and maternal outcomes are linked. This critical new information will be used to design interventions that improve women’s pre-pregnancy health and reduce the incidence of adverse maternal outcomes, including maternal death.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Chronic Effects of Neurotrauma Consortium (CENC; W81XWH-13-2-0095) has been a highly productive, coordinated, multicenter, basic science-to-bedside, research collaboration led by VCU/VA researcher David Cifu, MD and jointly funded since 2013 by the DoD and VA. CENC linked basic, translational, epidemiologic, and clinical neuroscience researchers from the VA, military, academia, and private sector to effectively address the diagnostic challenges and therapeutic ramifications of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and its potential long-term effects. Experienced and proven researchers from the CENC comprise the LIMBIC team at the level of Consortium Leadership, Core Facility, and Research Study Directors. This proven team of leaders, infrastructure supporters and researchers will initiate targeted, expanded research studies that extend CENC research findings, address all priorities (required and secondary research elements) detailed in the program announcement, and will produce deliverables for the clinicians in the field.

PHR: PTSD is one of the most common mental health conditions affecting Veterans and is associated with significant burden. Highly effective treatments exist for PTSD, evidence-based psychotherapies, but very few Veterans receive them. Although VA has trained over 8,500 providers in evidence-based psychotherapies for PTSD over the past 10 years, only 6% of the 650,000 VHA patients with PTSD receive an evidence-based psychotherapy. It is critical that we connect Veterans with our most effective PTSD treatments and that we do so in a way that is Veteran-centered. Shared decision making is a patient-centered approach to choosing healthcare treatment options. It has been shown to increase patients’ motivation for treatment and ability to stay in treatment long enough to get benefit. It has also been shown to help providers align their practice with evidence-based guidelines. This proposal will refine and pilot test a shared decision making intervention for PTSD to be used in VA primary care clinics, where the vast majority of Veterans with PTSD are treated.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (lay abs) The mortality gap between African Americans and Whites with breast cancer in the US reflected the unmasking of differences in the biology of breast cancer between AA and WA women related to targeted therapies. Our previous findings implicated African alleles of the DARC gene in etiology of breast cancer phenotypes and its tumor expression with survival, suggesting ancestry-related differences in tumor immunological responses that may stratify patients for improved use of immunotherapy treatments to decrease tumor-subtype-related disparities in mortality. Our proposed work will define the clinical associations of DARC in African breast cancer patients and “DARC tumor” characteristics that will give insight to shared genetic risk among women of the African diaspora who share unique burdens of aggressive breast tumor phenotypes.

ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The incidence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) among combat-experienced Veterans is much larger than the general population. Moreover, 50% of Veterans with PTSD are also diagnosed with substance use disorders (SUDs). Patients with comorbid PTSD and SUDs show poorer treatment outcomes than patients diagnosed with either disorder alone. This special need of Veterans is largely unaddressed by preclinical research. Cannabis and opioids are among the addictive drugs most widely abused by Veterans, and we employ cannabis or heroin use and life-threatening acute stress in rats to study the neurological mechanisms PTSD/SUDs comorbidity. In the first funding period we discovered that cannabis use exacerbates responses to conditioned stress. Going forward we expect to identify brain circuits and molecular mechanisms underlying the synergisms between stress and cannabis that can be exploited as targets for treating the high incidence of comorbid PTSD and SUDs in our returning combat Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has had a profound negative impact on population mental health in the United States, especially for marginalized populations such as sexual minorities (SMs). SMs with diverse sexual orientation, gender, and racial/ethnic identities may be differentially impacted due to unique structural vulnerabilities, although few studies have explored this. The goal of this project is thus to examine the intersectional distribution and upstream determinants of SM mental health disparities over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic using an unprecedented data source and advanced epidemiologic methods, with the goal of generating knowledge to inform mental health equity efforts for COVID-19 relief and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing the diversity of the model systems we study will proportionally increase our understanding of how sensory systems evolve, reveal conserved principles of sensory processing, and ultimately help us better extrapolate results we obtain in animal studies to the human nervous system, in both normal and disease states. Here, we propose to expand our understanding of the organization of temperature and humidity sensing circuits by introducing the desert fly Drosophila mojavensis (adapted to dry and heat conditions) as a new model alongside the common laboratory fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. This comparative work will lead to a greater understanding of the conserved principles behind somatosensory processing and behavior, and in the long term help enhance our understanding of temperature and pain sensation in both animals and humans.

PHR: 8. Project Narrative In the United States, there are approximately 2,500-3,000 new cases per year and approximately 28,000 people living with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), a relatively rare form of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL), and there is currently no FDA approved cure or first line treatment for CTCL. SGX301 (0.25% hypericin), a novel, first-in-class photodynamic therapy utilizing safe visible light for activation has received Orphan Product and Fast Track designation from the FDA and has recently shown efficacy in the study's primary and key secondary endpoints of a Phase 3 pivotal study. The primary objective of this proposal is to advance the clinical evaluation of SGX301 by conducting the clinical study RW-HPN-MF-01, “Assessment of Treatment with Visible Light Activated Synthetic Hypericin Ointment in Mycosis Fungoides (MF) Patients”, evaluating extended administration of SGX301 as a photodynamic therapy (PDT) for MF/CTCL.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessment of Treatment with Visible Light Activated Synthetic Hypericin ointment in Mycosis Fungoides Patients.

PHR: Project Narrative: Children and young adults with high-grade brain/spine tumors have limited treatment options and a dismal prognosis, underscoring the urgent need to develop novel therapies for this vulnerable patient population. The proposed clinical trial will assess the safety and effectiveness of 177Lu-DOTATATE, a targeted radiotherapy that binds to tumor cells that express somatostatin receptors, causing tumor cell death through localized release of radiation. If 177Lu-DOTATATE proves safe and effective in treating children and young adults with refractory brain/spine tumors that express somatostatin receptors, further studies will be planned to expand to a larger patient population and eventually incorporate 177Lu-DOTATATE into upfront treatment backbones for these aggressive diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Phase I/II Study of 177Lu-DOTATATE in Children and Young Adults with Recurrent/Progressive High-Grade CNS Tumors and Meningiomas which Express Somatostatin Type 2A Receptors [9/24/21 IND]

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Chronic Effects of Neurotrauma Warfighter Epidemiology Cohort was developed to identify phenotypes of comorbidity among deployed Post-9/11 Veterans in order to compare emergence of neurosensory, neurodegenerative, pain, and mental health comorbidity in Veterans TBI. We will extend the Warfighter Epidemiology Cohort by 1) including deployed and non-deployed Veterans, 2) adding new data sources, and 3) extending the science of longitudinal analyses of outcomes associated with TBI. We will identify mTBI phenotypes using VA/DoD data, identify prevalence of key comorbidities neurodegenerative disease, SUD, psychological comorbidities, and self-harm behaviors before and after mTBI exposure, and use deep learning models to develop risk scores for key comorbidities and identify optimal processes of care for mTBI. These analyses will illuminate specific target areas to improve the quality of TBI care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This study aims to perform a two-stage randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study to test the effectiveness of behavioral weight loss and pharmacologic treatment with a recently FDA-approved weight-loss medication (naltrexone/bupropion), alone and in combination, for the treatment of loss-of-control (LOC) eating following bariatric surgery. This study will produce important new information about the relative efficacy of behavioral and pharmacologic treatments following bariatric surgery, will produce important novel information regarding whether to continue weight-loss medication to improve longer-term outcomes amongst those who respond to initial treatments, and whether an alternative (distinct) medication enhances outcomes amongst those who do not respond to the initial treatments.

PHR: Lay Abstract The number of African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, and Pacific Islanders who do drug addiction research is much lower than would be expected based on their representation in the U.S. population. We will establish a national Center for Underrepresented Research in Addiction (CURA) program that will promote the advancement of these underrepresented minorities who are junior faculty members in academia. The program will involve a series of workshops and mentoring over several years with instruction and mentoring in drug addiction research, professional development, and ethics provided by a large number of nationally recognized faculty members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Strategies that shift attention to the future may improve health decision-making, and one such strategy, Episodic Future Thinking (EFT), has been shown to improve food choices and reduce intake, but it remains unclear whether and how this strategy may impact weight loss. This randomized controlled trial will compare three Internet-delivered behavioral weight loss (iBWL) programs to test whether adding prevention-, or promotion-focused EFT-based strategies to a standard iBWL may improve weight loss and related outcomes. Further, it may determine for whom each approach is best in order to optimize weight loss in individuals with overweight/obesity.

PHR: This study will utilize mouse models and patient biopsies to assess significance of Sprouty2 gene in colorectal cancer (CRC). Studies are planned to test whether Sprouty2 gene serves as prognostic marker of disease-free survival in advanced rectal cancer patients. Studies will also test whether reduction in Sprouty2 would regress tumor growth. We strongly believe that understanding the role of Sprouty2 gene in CRC will identify better strategies to treat patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Discussions between patients and physicians about end-of-life care preferences allow older adults to maintain control over their medical care at the end of life and reduce unwanted medical interventions. The emergency department visit provides a unique opportunity to promote these discussions among patients likely to benefit from these conversations. The proposed study will test an intervention which combines a certified video decision aid, a semi-structured conversation with a social worker, and secure electronic communication with the patient's primary provider and admitting physician to support end-of-life care discussions for older adults receiving care in the emergency department.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because spondyloarthritis is the most common form of childhood arthritis in large parts of the world and although inactive disease is a realistic goal since the introduction of biologic agents we do not know if or how to de-escalate therapies with minimal morbidity. There is a critical need for imaging and serologic biomarkers to accurately predict flare after therapy de-escalation so that we can eliminate much of the guesswork associated with the current standard of care. This project is directly aligned with the program announcement (RFA-AR-20-001) as the primary goal is to leverage the infrastructure and resources of a funded parent trial to enhance its scientific content and value, improve the research community’s understanding of the clinically inactive disease state, and to test the utility of imaging and serologic biomarkers to guide treatment de-escalation decisions at point-of-care.

PHR: Kidney transplantation is the preferred mode of replacement therapy for those with kidney failure. Since 1962, the VA National Transplant Program provides kidney transplants to Veterans at 8 VA Medical Centers as well as by contracted care across the US. About half of these patients will die prematurely by 10 years after transplant due to cardiovascular disease, while another half will suffer with graft failure and return to dialysis. Improving these outcomes is a critical unmet need. New therapies for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) such as SGLT2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) have had substantial positive impacts on patients with kidney disease, but they have not been in kidney transplant patients. In this application we will test the safety of using these agents in an open label fashion in kidney transplant recipients with T2DM. We will compare their outcomes to a cohort of kidney transplant recipients in the VA health system that are getting standard care treatment. We will also assess the economic impact of SLGT2i therapy in this patient population.

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: VA has recognized that Agent Orange, and more recently burn pit, exposure is associated with development of several malignancies including the most common soft tissue cancer, fibrosarcoma. Patients with advanced cases of fibrosarcoma are resistant to chemo, radiation, and biologic therapies, which results in poor long-term survival. An effective solution is to target essential cancer growth and metastasis pathways. This Validation study will screen for novel small molecules that induce degradation of a therapeutic target protein Acss2, a lynchpin protein in a key signaling pathway that promotes cancer growth and metastasis. The proposed studies will identify hits in a primary screen, validate hits in a secondary screen, and evaluate their effectiveness on endogenous Acss2 in a tertiary screen. Candidates that meet pre-established criteria will be designated lead candidates and will undergo further optimization in future efforts. The Potential Impact on Veterans Health Care gained from these studies is development of novel first-in-class drugs for treatment of advanced stage fibrosarcoma in Veterans.

PHR: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is among the most common and deadly forms of cancer, and the racial CRC disparity in South Carolina exceeds the national average. This study will use a biobehavioral case-control design to determine whether the disruption of circadian rhythms and sleep, including their genetic and epigenetic (DNA methylation) correlates, is associated with inflammation or colorectal adenomas among African- and European- American patients receiving a screening colonoscopy. Our study will rigorously evaluate whether circadian- based factors may serve as novel, modifiable targets for CRC prevention.

PHR: Chronic pain is a major health concern for returning Veterans, and non-opioid treatment is a priority of the Veterans Administration. Weighted Blankets (WB) have shown large benefits for improving both anxiety and sleep disturbance, frequent comorbidities that amplify chronic pain. Decreasing sleep disturbance among Veterans with chronic pain has the potential to greatly reduce the impact of pain. Indeed, our data suggest that WBs can also reduce pain, especially in individuals with higher anxiety or poorer sleep. Yet, there is lack of information on whether WBs improve pain and sleep in Veterans suffering from chronic pain. Our proposed randomized controlled trial will identify the effects of a WB on chronic pain and sleep disturbance, and the relationship between these clinical factors. The proposed research findings will provide critical evidence for effects on pain and sleep disturbance for this novel, accessible and fully remote intervention. Study results will inform both future research and treatment of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms of Insulin resistance in Man More than 400 million people in the world have either type 2 diabetes or pre-diabetes. The diagnostic hallmark of these conditions is elevated blood sugar levels first thing in the morning. Therefore, this application focuses on how, when and why does the liver release excess glucose into the blood stream during the day and at night in people with type 2 diabetes and whether certain antidiabetic medications can modulate some of the causal factors related to high blood sugar in order to develop rational approaches for and management of type 2 diabetes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innovative platform MILC is designed to provide an integrated and comprehensive professional and social support network with personalized breastfeeding (BF) education to target exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) and any BF behaviors in low-income Hispanic women. Formative research conducted for the development of MILC and results from pilot testing will help guide completion of the development and testing of this prototype that specifically caters to Hispanic women. In the long-term, MILC has the potential to increase the rates of EBF and any BF up to 12 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . Acute ischemic stroke caused by occlusion of the vertebral or basilar arteries is a devastating disease that results in high rates of death and disability. Patients with vertebral or basilar artery occlusions often undergo endovascular thrombectomy treatment to restore blood flow in these vessels, which is thought to improve the chances of a good outcome in these patients. The goal of PRECISE is to determine if advanced cerebral perfusion imaging can identify a subset of patients with vertebral or basilar artery occlusion who are more likely to benefit from endovascular thrombectomy. The results of PRECISE will improve our ability to identify patients for emergency thrombectomy and may lead to improved patient selection and prognostication in this understudied stroke population.

PHR: Project Narrative Aging is associated with significant declines in muscle mass, strength, and physical performance, all of which lead to disability, loss of independence, and poor clinical outcomes. Currently, health care providers have no treatment options to offer their patients to slow declines in physical function. Evidence suggests that statins could be an effective treatment for preserving physical function by preventing disabling chronic conditions; however, a large number of patients discontinue statins because of side effects including muscle pain and weakness. Thus, determining whether statins can preserve physical function and independence in older adults is needed to inform treatment guidelines for the use of statins in older adults.

PHR: Fatty liver disease is an inflammatory response to accumulation of toxic metabolites within the liver. In United States Veterans, the progression of fatty liver disease to liver inflammation/fibrosis/cirrhosis will soon be the leading cause of liver transplantation; creating a challenge for our country’s Health Care budget. The metabolic pathways that protect fatty liver disease’s progression to inflammation are under intense study. Recent findings provide evidence that abnormal hepatocyte cholesterol metabolism drives fatty liver’s transition to inflammation. StarD5, a unique protein involved in intracellular cholesterol movement and highly expressed in liver cells, appears able to provide an adaptive protective response; and may play a controlling role to protect the liver’s progression to inflammation in fatty liver disease. The proposal outlines a framework of studies to define this novel hypothesis; ones likely to unveil new pathways for pharmacological control of cholesterol/lipids and its associated pathologies.

ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Relevance to Veterans’ health and healthcare: Shockwave-induced, blast traumatic brain injury (bTBI) is a significant problem for U.S. service members, including combat Veterans. The debilitating neuropsychiatric consequences associated with bTBI necessitate an effective intervention. The current application aims to meet this critical need by determining the utility of neuromodulation and pharmacotherapy to reduce neuroinflammation, which may mediate associated neuropsychiatric impairment. In a rodent model, we will test two treatments that target the same anti-inflammatory pathway, vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) and anatabine, with the ultimate goal of human translation. Both VNS and anatabine have shown efficacy in experimental testing but have yet to be used for bTBI. If successful, these treatments have the potential to improve the quality of life of service members and advance the standard of care for military personnel who have experienced bTBI.

PHR: The prevalence of health factors that compromise the immune systems of US veterans and predispose them to infection with opportunistic pathogens like Pneumocystis is significant. Besides infection with HIV, obesity in the US has increased over the past several decades. Obesity is linked to more than 60 chronic diseases, including cancers. In 2014 (the most recent update), the VA estimated that 78% of US veterans (including men, women and ethnic minorities) were overweight or obese (Spotlight on Obesity, May 2020) rendering them susceptible to cancers, other immune debilitating diseases, and opportunistic infections like Pneumocystis pneumonia. Opioid drug overdoses of US military veterans have increased by 53% from 2010- 2019, establishing another susceptible veteran population who are often co-infected with HIV and HCV.

PHR: Project Narrative  There are no currently available mindfulness-based stress reduction interventions specifically tailored for adults with intellectual disabilities (ID). And, while there are a number of efficacious mindfulness-based stress management interventions for the general population, these approaches have significant limitations for use by people with ID – in that they do not address this populations unique learning needs. There is a need for an adapted approach giving individuals with ID low cost, immediate access to the help and support they need. This project addresses a significant public health need by developing and evaluating a low-cost, accessible online integrated mindfulness-based stress reduction program that can be easily implemented by individuals in this population with the support of their care providers to reduce their stress and strengthen their healthy coping skills.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease presents a significant burden for the VA Healthcare System and hepatocellular carcinoma is among its most consequential complication. Because the underlying mechanism(s) of the development of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease are poorly understood, treatment and chemoprevention options are lacking. In this proposal, we will study the effects of lipid pathways, including statins, on the emergent YAP/TAZ oncogenic pathway in hepatocellular carcinoma. We will test the hypothesis that treating normal and cancer cells with a combination of lipid-modifying agents and mTORC1 targets (part of the YAP/TAZ pathway) will affect cell growth and proliferation. Thus, the most translatable outcomes of the findings from this proposal could be the identification of chemoprevention methods and therapeutic targets important in the progression of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease to hepatocellular carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myosins are molecular motors responsible for generating much of the force in the human body, including the heartbeat and the movement of limbs. Small changes to the cardiac myosin gene can cause cardiomyopathies, the leading causes of sudden cardiac death in young adults. This proposal aims to combine molecular simulations with experiments to understand how these subtle changes to the myosin gene create such large effects in protein function and how we can develop novel drugs to treat cardiomyopathies and other common heart conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative There is growing consensus that dysfunction of cortico-striatal circuits is a key component of psychiatric illnesses. Moreover, there is compelling evidence that points to neurodevelopmental origins for most psychiatric disorders. This study will examine the anatomical underpinnings of functional integration through the cortico-striatal neural network and changes in its circuitry during early postnatal development.

PHR: NARRATIVE  Cancer radiation treatment plans that employ lung functional avoidance methods require 3D maps that differentiate regions of healthy lung function from regions of compromised tissue to deliver sufficient dose to the tumor while preserving as much functioning lung as possible. Hyperpolarized xenon-129 MRI can provide maps of ventilatory function and gas exchange to the bloodstream. Improving treatment plans based on this novel imaging modality could reduce risk or severity of radiation pneumonitis and improve post-treatment quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative While prevention measures for HIV have made significant progress, such as PrEP, these measures are often either ignored, misused, or non-negotiable for the female partner; therefore, there is a clear need world-wide for new approaches for the prevention HIV infections that are female controlled. In this application we plan to develop a synthetic mRNA-based approach for the delivery of broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV to the female reproductive tract (FRT) through direct, rapid, aerosol exposure of the FRT epithelium to naked mRNA in water, and when combined with antibody engineering, should allow for rapid expression, and controllable persistence of the protective antibodies in tissues and secretions. Overall this approach represents a new paradigm for HIV prevention, one that can be extended and combined with the co-expression of other anti-sexually transmitted infection antibodies, such as those against HSV-2.

PHR: Project Narrative The Rutgers Youth Enjoy Science project is relevant to public health because it will develop a more diverse biomedical, cancer research and healthcare workforce to reduce cancer health disparities in New Jersey and nationally. This project at the Rutgers Cancer Institute of New Jersey will train, motivate and support students from underrepresented groups to pursue biomedical, cancer research careers. High school and undergraduate students will engage in mentored hands-on research experience, co-curricular and professional career development activities and their science teachers will be provided with mentored research experience and curriculum development support. Innovative outreach activities will connect program participants with schools and families in their communities to enhance awareness and appreciation of science education and research careers.

PHR: NARRATIVE Difficulty walking and cognitive impairment are common in aging and often associated with changes on brain imaging, but not everyone is afflicted equally. We propose to identify what brain imaging features distinguishes those who age with and without disability. Our findings will inform us about ways to maintain healthy brain aging and prevent dementia and falls.

PHR: In the US, 1.5 million people are affected by sepsis, with a mortality of more than 250,000 annually. There is no effective treatment for sepsis, which is a major healthcare issue among the Veterans. Every year over 35,000 Veterans are hospitalized with sepsis. A high rate of post- sepsis readmission, post-sepsis mortality, and significant increases in healthcare facility use are reported among Veterans surviving sepsis. A number of immunomodulatory therapies that targeted sepsis were not successful in clinical trials. Our focus on bioenergetic modulation provides an alternative approach in sepsis treatmentOur studies, if successful, will result in the identification and preclinical confirmation of BACH1 as a molecular target in reducing or preventing mortality following sepsis, and identify possible mechanisms by which Bach1 deficiency is related to improved outcome.

PHR: HLA class-II genes and gut microbiota had emerged as an important genetic and environmental factor linked with the pathobiology of multiple sclerosis (MS) a relevant medical problem faced by Veterans. However, the mechanism through which interaction between gene (HLA class-II) and environmental factor (microbiota) might predispose to or protect form MS is unknown. Thus, our proposal on understanding the mechanisms through which the HLA and gut microbiota can modulate disease in MS patients will be an essential step in that direction as a better understanding of the same might lead to discovery of novel treatment options.
