PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BDNF dysfunction has been observed in neurodevelopmental disorders, neurodegenerative disease, and psychiatric conditions, leading to increased interest in determining BDNF signaling mechanisms of action that may serve as therapeutic targets. Our proposal seeks to identify RhoGTPase signaling partners that are modulated by TrkB.T1 receptor activation in astrocytes, a key regulator of CNS support, homeostasis, and function. Our contributions will provide valuable information to understanding the fundamental role of developmental BDNF signaling onto astrocytes as well as identifying if novel pharmacological interventions are able to rescue astrocyte specific deficits.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to discover molecular mechanisms that link genetic factors to disease risk in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). SLE is estimated to affect more than 200,000 people in the U.S. Treatment options for SLE are limited, as only two new therapies have received FDA approval since 1950. Available therapies cause substantial morbidity due to excess immunosuppression and infection. Thus, new therapeutic strategies are needed. The proposed research is relevant to the health of Veterans because it will define the molecular mechanisms that link genetic factors to disease risk, and provide fundamental insight into the role of the MIR146A in the etiology of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This insight is expected to lead to improved diagnostic, prognostic, therapeutic and preventative approaches that will improve the health of veterans and civilians with SLE and other autoimmune diseases.

ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The goal of this study is to develop an optimal mesenchymal stromal cell-based treatment protocol for reducing pain associated with chronic pancreatitis and to understand any mechanisms of protection. If proven effective, such strategy can be used as a therapeutic option for chronic pain associated with chronic pancreatitis as well as other diseases related to the health of our Veterans.

PHR: Project Narrative We have identified a modular cell-type specific super-enhancer (SE) upstream of Vsx2, a transcription factor that is expressed primarily in the retina. I will examine the modularity of this SE in a human retinal organoid to understand the effect of enhancers on cell-type specification in a human model of retinal development. During my postdoctoral fellowship, I will apply this knowledge to the brain to study how epigenetic mechanisms contribute to chromatin architecture regulating gene expression and how dysregulation in these mechanisms contribute to CNS disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About half of all people living with HIV in the U.S. are afflicted with HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND), yet the neural mechanisms remain unknown. This project will apply structural and functional MRI to determine the role of frontostriatal neural circuits in HAND to inform the development of early diagnostic methods and help identify potential targets for therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE What we perceive and hold in working memory is dependent on selective attention — a top-down cognitive ability that regulates the limited cortical resources available in the human brain from moment to moment. The proposed work will use a combination of cutting-edge non-invasive human brain imaging (fMRI and EEG), combined with computational modeling, to reveal the neural computational mechanisms through which attention regulates limited visuocortical resources. Understanding the neural substrates underlying attention in healthy adults is paramount for developing targeted interventions for brain disorders that disrupt attention, perception, and working memory — crucial cognitive functions in our everyday lives.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and age-related hearing loss (ARHL) are both complex neurodegenerative disease with common causes, including age, diet, smoking, and at the tissue level, macrophage invasion and complement activation has been reported. Macrophage and complement activation creates a viscous feedback loop of inflammation. Here our study aims to develop a treatment strategy in animal models by inhibiting the alternative pathway of complement in damaged tissues to partially reduce inflammation and mitigate wet AMD and ARHL pathology.

PHR: Project Narrative KRAS mutant lung adenocarcinoma remains a challenging clinical problem without specific inhibitors. We have demonstrated that alveolar Type II cells become cancer stem cells when Kras is activated. We will analyze sphingolipid pathways in these cells to identify new therapeutic targets. We will also use gene editing technology (Cas/Crispr) to find sphingolipid genes that are necessary for the survival and growth of Kras mutant stem cells. Finally, we will test new methods of activating the immune system against these cells. These approaches should allow rapid translation to the clinic to help Veterans with KRAS mutant lung cancer.

PHR: Use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) is increasing rapidly in the VHA. However, there are major gaps in our understanding of CGM including whether it improves long-term glucose control, prevents or delays diabetes complications, and serious health events such as death. Using the VHA health records we will construct one of the largest datasets of type 1 and 2 diabetes CGM users to date. This will allow us to assess in T1D and T2D the effect of CGM initiation not just on long-term glucose control but also on a) hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia events, b) development of diabetes renal disease, a composite diabetes complication index, and c) cardiovascular outcomes and death. This study will help create an informed precision medicine based approach for the use of CGM.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Veterans enrolled in the VHA health care system are almost three times more likely to suffer from diabetes than the general population. Studies have shown that lowering high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) among diabetic veterans does not adequately reduce their risk of developing serious cardiovascular disease caused by fatty blockages in arteries, called atherosclerosis. Our published findings show that hyperglycemia increases atherosclerosis by enhancing the inflammatory properties of microvesicles that circulate in the bloodstream, called “exosomes”. Our publications also show that we can produce protective exosomes from cultured cells that suppress inflammation when injected into diabetic mice. Through studies of exosomes isolated from diabetic veterans, and cultured cells, we will study how hyperglycemia increases the inflammatory and atherogenic properties of exosomes. We will also seek to develop protective exosomes that could serve as new treatments to control atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease among diabetic veterans.

PHR: Opioid prescribing has fallen across the US, both within and outside the US Veterans Administration. Although this change likely will prevent prescription-related harm for a number of patients, reports signal adverse events including suicide, for others. Where harm has occurred, it is crucial to know what factors, modifiable and nonmodifiable, played a role. Whereas much research has sought statistical associations between prescription opioid change and outcomes like suicide, we offer a different approach. We will recruit bereaved survivors of suicides following a prescription opioid change. We will carry out detailed survey, medical record review, and in-depth psychological autopsy interviews to learn which patient and clinical context factors could help to account for why the suicides took place. This research is descriptive. The research team includes scholarly experts and members of the affected communities. Working with VA partners, we seek actionable points of leverage for policy makers, and for health systems seeking to prevent these suicides from taking place.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTH TEXAS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Narrative Chronic musculoskeletal (MSK) pain and co-occurring depressive symptoms often result in refractory disease, worse outcomes, and additional burden on the patient and society, costing over $600 billion annually. An accessible, safe, and effective behavioral intervention targeting older Veterans with chronic MSK pain and comorbid depressive symptoms is sorely needed, especially in older populations where the efficacy and safety of pharmacologic options are less favorable. We propose to conduct a hybrid type 1 randomized controlled trial at two large VA facilities to evaluate the effectiveness, implementation processes, and cost of MOTIVATE-- a health coach, virtually delivered, behavioral intervention for older Veterans with MSK pain and depressive symptoms. Results from this research will inform the scalability and implementation of MOTIVATE to ultimately improve pain interference, depressive symptoms, among other outcomes in a rapidly growing population of older Veterans with co-occurring MSK pain and depressive symptoms.

PHR: Project Narrative Our brain is incredibly plastic during critical periods in development: experience reorganizes trillions of synapses between neurons, enabling neural circuits to mature and optimally process sensory information. The proposed research will determine how experience shapes the functional properties of neurons in the visual cortex by applying advanced physiological and molecular techniques to visualize synaptic modifications in functional synapses. Successful completion of this proposal will broaden our understanding of the synaptic mechanisms that underlie aberrant sensory processing and neurodevelopmental disorders, such as amblyopia, autism and schizophrenia.

PROJECT_TITLE: Alignment of visual features in binocular cortical circuits through experience dependent synaptic plasticity

PHR: Telemental health (TMH), in which services are delivered from a distance via videoconferencing or phone, can increase Veterans’ access to high quality mental health (MH) care. Its use has skyrocketed during COVID-19 in order to reduce the infection risk of in-person care; this has provided an unprecedented opportunity to examine TMH use on a national scale. Specifically, we need to understand how the quality of TMH care compares to in-person care (as limited evidence suggests phone care may be lower quality than video and in- person), as well as which modality of care patients prefer across various clinical circumstances (e.g., medication management versus therapy appointments). These findings will be used to improve MH care modality decision-making at the patient, provider, and/or system levels, with a focus on increasing video use in circumstances where it is clinically effective and preferred by patients. Results will inform national VA clinical and operational decisions regarding how MH care is delivered well beyond the COVID-19 pandemic.

ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Among women Veterans, breast cancer (BC) is the most diagnosed cancer, accounting for 30% of female cancers and is more prevalent among older Veterans. Of great significance is the fact that BC is more common among military servicewomen, than in the general population. Further, this is particularly important for South Texas Veterans where BC prevalence is rampant. This research program is significant, as it will identify therapeutic targets and develop novel combination therapy for treating triple negative breast cancer (TNBC, a deadly subtype of BC). These treatments are urgently needed for many VA patients and will be a cost-effective approach with potential to save millions of dollars to the VA health care system.

PHR: Although rates of alcohol-use disorder in women veterans have been steadily increasing, sex differences in immunological and neurobiological vulnerabilities or sex-sensitive risk factors, such as trauma or emotion regulation difficulties are rarely examined in clinical trials. As the systematic study of sex differences may provide a mechanistic understanding of biobehavioral interactions that differentially affect treatment outcome in men and women veterans, this project will leverage results from past studies of naltrexone and examine whether its anti- inflammatory or neuromodulating properties attenuate psychosocial factors and reduce alcohol use in a sex- dependent manner. As women veterans have unique vulnerabilities that contribute to disease severity, results from this study will have substantial impact in advancing the VA mission for precision medicine by providing biomarkers for tailored treatment approaches, as well as, supporting a VA priority in addressing the unique needs and improving health outcomes for female veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) is complicated by high failure rates in young active individuals. The surgical methods to reconstruct the ACL-deficient knee, including graft selection (autograft bone-patellar tendon-bone or quadriceps tendon) and performance of a lateral extra-articular tenodesis may reduce the risk of graft failure in young active individuals. Improved surgical methods to reduce the risk of graft failure will minimize the need for revision ACLR and the associated decreased quality of life and socioeconomic burden that occurs because of ongoing knee instability and the increased risk for post- traumatic osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neurogenic bowel dysfunction is manifested as a slow colonic motility and constipation, and it is the 2nd most common complication and 4th most common reason for re-hospitalization in people with spinal cord injury (SCI). More than 1/3 of people with SCI rate neurogenic bowel dysfunction as the most significant quality of life issue. Progress in developing effective drug treatments for improving neurogenic bowel dysfunction has been slow, despite an urgent unmet need. In our clinical studies, we discovered that transcutaneous neuromodulation applied at the ST36 acupuncture point (below the kneecap) improves neurogenic bowel dysfunction in patients with stroke chronic constipation, and other disorders. The long-term goal of this project is to develop a novel noninvasive transcutaneous neuromodulation therapy using a wearable device placed on ST36 acupuncture point for treating neurogenic bowel dysfunction in SCI. The specific aims of this project are to design and develop an easy-to-use leg-worn transcutaneous neuromodulation device AccelBand and to evaluate its clinical potential in treating neurogenic bowel dysfunction in SCI.

PHR: A major barrier to HIV eradication is maintenance of latently infected cells in people living with HIV (PWH). The Veteran population of PWH is nearly 2.5-fold greater versus non-Veteran individuals living in the United States, underscoring a major unmet need within the United States Veteran's population for safe, specific agents that can cure HIV and prevent or reverse associated co-morbidities. Chronic inflammation despite suppressive ART drives HIV persistence and co-morbidities, (cardiovascular disease, frailty, diabetes, and HIV-associated neurocognitive dysfunction (HAND)). We will define the multi-functional action of baricitinib, a Jak ½ inhibitor developed by our team for treatment of viral infections including HIV and COVID-19, towards reducing HIV reservoirs. We will leverage our now-enrolling Phase2a study for baricitinib towards reduction of HIV-1 reservoir in the CNS (NCT05452564) across peripheral blood and cerebral spinal fluid samples. Data will streamline translation to human studies in the Veteran PWH population, for comorbidities and eventual HIV cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The ability to learn and produce specific motor movements is critical for many aspects of life and is dysregulated in a range of neurological conditions that affect the basal ganglia circuits. Our ability to help patients critically depends on a deep understanding of basal ganglia function, however, the principles of basal ganglia function and dysfunction in health and disease conditions remain elusive. The proposed work aims to provide a mechanistic, circuit-level understanding of diverse action-specific basal ganglia subcircuits that goes beyond the classical prokinetic versus antikinetic model, with profound implications for a range of brain disorders such as Parkinson's and Huntington's diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mounting evidence suggests that several neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy, have origins in defective neural circuit formation. The goal of this proposal is to advance our understanding of how neural circuits form at the cellular and molecular level using a simpler model system. Knowledge drawn from such simple systems will build the foundation for studies aimed at understanding neural circuit formation in humans, and thus will be instrumental in the design of therapies to treat neurodevelopmental disorders in the future.

PHR: Toxoplasmosis causes death and severe disability in immunocompromised Veterans. Current treatments have high rates of side effects that complicate use for treatment and prophylaxis, and fail to reduce established latent brain infection. This research will identify drug targets whose inhibition will increase the activity of ELQ-422 and identify compounds that increase the efficacy of ELQ-422 against acute and latent infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A large proportion of patients with temporal lobe epilepsy suffer from chronic spontaneous seizures, which cannot be controlled with existing drug treatment options. This proposal will utilize recently developed molecular and genetic tools to investigate seizure active cellular ensembles and their associated circuits. A greater understanding of neuronal circuits controlling seizure development may lead to the identification of new targets for therapeutic intervention.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Urothelial carcinoma (bladder cancer) is the most common cancer of the urinary tract. It represents a significant health burden to the aging Veteran population due to the cumulative effects of smoking and deployment-related carcinogen exposure. Treatment resistance and disease relapse are unfortunately very common for bladder cancer. We propose to study, narrow down and target cancer-promoting factors and devise new precise combination strategies to effectively treat bladder cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Synapses bridge communication between neurons and form the basis of neural circuits and cognitive function. This proposal will study molecularly how synapses assemble during development and how that assembly is regulated. These fundamental studies will reveal molecular components that can influence synapse formation in neurological disorders like autism or during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In diseases like Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, sarcopenia, or spinal cord injury, the degeneration of specific subsets of adult motor neurons can lead to loss of muscle control, paralysis, and death. This project will produce a map of the motor neuron types found adult humans, lead to development of methods to produce adult-like motor neurons from patient cells, and generate virus based gene delivery tools that can be used to study motor neuron function and deliver therapeutics. The completion of this work will facilitate better understanding of adult motor neuron diseases and the development of treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is the leading cause of disability in the United States, leaving a substantial number of survivors with permanent hand function deficits impairing dexterity. While most pre-clinical research focuses on descending movement pathways, anatomical and clinical studies underscore the critical role of somatosensory signals in recovery. This proposal uses multi-area electrophysiology to monitor functional interactions in the cortical and subcortical sensorimotor circuit during dexterous hand skill acquisition in intact and stroke-injured networks, laying the foundation for future therapies targeting normalization of somatosensory signals to enhance hand function recovery.

ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Reward seeking is normally suppressed in inappropriate conditions, yet opioid use and seeking often occur despite negative consequences in Veterans who are disproportionally vulnerable to opioid use disorder (OUD). We recently found that activity in a novel brain circuit, from paraventricular thalamus to accumbal parvalbumin interneurons, provides top-down inhibitory control over natural reward-motivated behaviors. Here we determine the influence of opioid self-administration on activity and plasticity in this thalamo-accumbal ‘brake’ for reward seeking, and further determine the function of this pathway for opioid seeking and use. Based on preliminary findings, we predict that selectively rescuing activity within cell-type specific thalamo-accumbal output circuits will prevent relapse to opioid use. Such findings would not only provide key mechanistic insight into the neurobiology of OUD, but would also provide candidate neuronal substrates that could be targeted for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: 8. Project Narrative One fifth of the US population struggles with chronic pain, but the only effective class of drugs for treatment of severe pain also drives the opioid addiction and overdose epidemic. We have synthesized a series of opioid pain killers with reduced side effects, including abuse liability. In this project, will identify and optimize related analogs, designed for improved brain delivery, for improved treatment of pain with low abuse liability, tolerance, and respiratory depression relative to currently used opioids. Successful tests will provide proof-of-concept that the novel compounds can effectively treat pain with reduced side effects and provide support for development for clinical use.

ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Heart failure (HF) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality and is especially prevalent among US veterans. One of the pathologic hallmarks of HF is myocardial fibrosis. Fibrosis is a reparative mechanism that follows any type of injury. In the heart, it leads to reduced tissue compliance, cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and apoptosis, chamber dilation, and eventually HF. HF patients undergoing implantation of a left ventricular assist device or heart transplantation present a unique opportunity as cardiac tissue becomes available at the time of the above operations. Our studies in HF patients have identified adipocyte enhancer binding protein 1 (AEBP1) as a major node associated with myofibroblast activation, abnormal extracellular matrix (ECM) homeostasis, and impaired wound healing following cardiac injury. Our goal is to investigate the mechanisms by which the aberrant expression of AEBP1 contributes to cardiac fibrosis and to exploit its inhibition as a potential antifibrotic therapy.

PHR: Approximately 5% of Veterans have heart failure and between 2014 and 2018 14.5% of those died because of it. Heart transplant is the life-saving cure for end-stage heart failure, but there are not enough hearts for the people who need them. This is often because the heart accumulates damage from lack of blood supply the longer it is out of the donor before being placed in the recipient, so it cannot be transplanted successfully. If this damage could be lessened there would be more hearts for transplant. A type of cell isolated from fat can be cultured and the factors they produce reduces this kind of damage. This study aims to test whether those factors, a particular part of the secretions or a very similar commercially available compound, could be used to treat hearts and reduce the amount of this damage They will be tested in models of a recent method to obtain hearts called donation after circulatory death during which hearts get more damaged than the traditional donation after brain death, thus potentially greatly increasing the number of suitable hearts for transplantation.

PHR: Obesity and associated comorbidities such as metabolic syndrome and diabetes affect up to 48% of Veterans, and are known risk factors for cognitive impairment and development of Alzheimer’s disease. The incidence of these neurodegenerative diseases may be higher in Veterans than in the general population. Our work supports that the onset of brain immune response (neuroinflammation) represents a link between obesity and cognitive impairment. Dietary metabolites such as fatty acids affect lipid metabolism in brain immune cells (microglia), resulting in a state change to a toxic inflammatory microglial phenotype. We hypothesize that obesity alters microglial function to directly trigger dysregulated brain immune responses and neuronal cell death, resulting in impaired cognition and altered brain circuitry. Our short term goal is to characterize regulatory changes that promote neuroinflammation and subsequent cognitive decline. Our long-term goal is to leverage this knowledge to develop targeted therapies to treat cognitive impairment and neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. In this project, a phase 2 clinical trial will be conducted in children with a killed, non-capsulated avirulent whole-cell Streptococcus pneumoniae (wSp) vaccine that elicits Th17 cell- mediated immunity and antibodies against all tested pneumococcal serotypes, and which has been tested in adults and toddlers. Nasopharyngeal (NP) colonization is a prerequisite to pneumococcal diseases and transmission. We will evaluate the efficacy of wSp vaccination in young children on pneumococcal NP colonization at times of health and onset of acute otitis media infections. The prevention of new acquisitions and/or reduction of NP colonization density may be a surrogate for prevention by wSp of pneumococcal infections. In addition, we will confirm the safety and immunogenicity of wSp.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Tanzania, breast cancer is the second most common cancer and second leading cause of cancer-related death in women. Although hormone receptor testing is recommended in all breast cancers by the recently published Tanzanian National Cancer Treatment Guidelines, testing is available at only two public hospitals, resulting in pathology laboratories that are overburdened and in turnaround times of weeks to months. Using implementation science frameworks, this study aims to identify effective implementation strategies to promote routine hormone receptor testing in low resource settings, and in turn, to improve clinical outcomes by increasing access to guideline-recommended treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines the role of indoor and outdoor (urban) air pollution in modulating the infectiousness of persons with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) and the transmission of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to their household contacts in a major urban slum population in Kampala/Uganda, a high TB incidence environment. This project aims at understanding if, and to what extent, household and outdoor air pollution particulate matter (PM2.5) exposures affect the amount of Mtb in respiratory aerosols (source strength) and the cough frequencies of TB index cases on one side, and the transmission of Mtb from TB index cases to their household contacts on the other side. This project has important global public health and environmental justice significance as slum populations are predicted to strongly increase worldwide and air pollution regulations and interventions could help to curb Mtb transmission in poverty settings, which is the primary driver of the devastating TB pandemic.

This is an inherited lysosomal disorder that is currently screened at the neonatal period. There is an unmet need for efficacious and safer therapies to arrest and eventually revert the neurological course of this neurological condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumors affecting the brain, with the most devastating type a Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) with the H3K27M mutation, result in more cancer-related deaths than any other type of tumor in children. The major pathologic finding in H3K27M tumors is a global loss of H3K27me3 that dramatically change gene expression and are likely to function as drivers of malignancy in these tumors. Our goal is to develop new therapies for treating children with H3K27M tumors by developing a toolbox of primary and secondary assays and to identify small molecule compounds that increase the suppressed H3K27me3 levels and leads to H3K27M mutant tumors death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major cause of death and disability in developed societies. Every year, approximately 3.5 million Americans sustain a TBI, of which 50,000 die, and another 300,000 are hospitalized and survive the injury. This proposed study focuses on the most severely injured of this group, approximately 27,000 Americans each year who experience prolonged coma from a TBI, and require sophisticated care in neurological Intensive Care Units. This group experiences high rates of mortality and morbidity, and only 20% make a good recovery resulting in an enormous psychosocial burden on patients, their families, and society. This study proposes to determine whether a treatment protocol based on brain tissue oxygen monitoring, using technology that has been available for over 10 years, improves neurologic outcome in this most severely injured group of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative Microglial activation is increasingly recognized as an important component of the nervous system’s response to demyelinative injury in progressive multiple sclerosis (MS); however, our current inability to identify the nature and extent of the microglial response to injury limits our monitoring of the therapeutic response. Our proposed studies aim to fill this gap by developing a PET radioligand as a diagnostic tool that can differentiate the subsets of microglia in order to stratify MS patients. This stratification will allow a more accurate prediction of disease outcome and monitoring of therapeutic response, as well as the development of novel treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parents may struggle to adjust to first-time parenthood, but the mechanisms underlying parents’ mental health symptoms during this period are not well understood. Though sleep quality is associated with mental health symptoms and white matter microstructure (WMM), no study has examined the role of sleep quality on parents’ mental health symptoms and WMM during the transition to parenthood. The proposed study examines sleep quality in new fathers at six months postpartum and tests associations with their WMM and mental health symptoms at one year postpartum, with the goal of identifying modifiable policy and practice targets to support parents’ adjustment to parenthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The symptoms of Essential Tremor (ET), the most common movement disorder in adults, are seriously disabling. Deep brain stimulation is a very effective treatment strategy to control tremor, however, efficacy can wane over time and side effects can develop, likely due to an incomplete understanding of the network effects of chronic stimulation. The work proposed in this study, to perform imaging analysis of deep brain stimulation over time, will advance our understanding of the larger network response to stimulation so that a biomarker may be identified for an improved future treatment paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Providing more effective therapies for impaired awareness of hypoglycemia (IAH) will allow more people with type 1 diabetes (T1D) to safely achieve target glucose and reduce the incidence of diabetic complications. This work may also highlight potential opportunities for basic scientists to better understand fundamental mechanisms and develop specific therapeutic interventions for IAH. Improving the ability of individuals to recognise the onset of hypoglycemia will allow people with T1D to improve their quality of life by reducing anxiety, fear of hypoglycemia and diabetes distress.

Nosebleeds critically limit daily activities, while anemia and iron deficiency reduce productivity and lead to the use of substantial medical resource. Pazopanib has the opportunity to change the lives of these patients.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Thousands of Veterans suffer a stroke every year, and these individuals often suffer emotional and cognitive changes that negatively affect their quality of life as well as their ability to recover. In addition to traditional rehabilitation such as physical and occupational therapy, a number of alternative treatments are now being studied for their ability to enhance patients’ recovery following stroke. One of these treatments, Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction or MBSR, involves an 8-week course that teaches individuals strategies such as breathing techniques, meditation, and movement therapy. The current study proposes to teach MBSR to a group of Veterans with a history of stroke to determine whether this type of intervention has beneficial effects on psychological and cognitive functioning. We hope to find that MBSR is a useful, additional intervention that can improve Veterans’ well-being and quality of life as they recover from stroke.

PHR: Over 80,000 Veterans with Parkinson’s disease (PD) obtain their medical care within the Veterans Administration (VA) Health Care System and this number is expected to increase due to the greater longevity of the population. Health-Related Quality of life (HRQoL), cognition, and mood are compromised in those with PD and worsen as the disease progresses. Interventions that target cognitive and mood symptoms as well as improve HRQoL are critically needed. Preliminary evidence indicates that Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) is a promising behavioral intervention for HRQoL, cognition, and mood in PD; however, a systematic randomized controlled trial (RCT) is needed to establish efficacy and determine long-term benefits. The aims of this proposed study will address this need and are consistent with the VA’s clinical care goals. Findings will potentially greatly benefit the VA and its role as a leader in providing high quality care and empirically-validated treatments to Veterans.

PHR: Chronic pain symptoms are very common among U.S. Military Veterans and have a profound negative impact on mental health symptoms and quality of life, in addition to increasing risk for suicidal ideation and suicidal behaviors. There are currently extremely few safe and effective pharmacological treatments for chronic pain disorders, and the clinical need to develop new therapeutics for pain has never been more urgent. Fueled by the worsening opioid crisis and further exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, opioid and other drug overdose deaths have climbed to staggeringly high levels. The rapid development of medications for the management of chronic pain conditions that are safe, well-tolerated, efficacious and non-addicting is thus of paramount importance. The two neurosteroid candidates to be investigated in this trial are naturally occurring molecules enriched in human brain and potentially ideal candidates for safe and effective chronic pain treatment.

ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: VA use of prescribed stimulants (PS) has skyrocketed > 400% since 1999. VA’s upcoming Psychotropic Drug Safety Initiative (PDSI) will target PS. This grant uniquely supports the PDSI by using VA’s nationwide data to support the safer use of PS. We will identify patient groups at higher risk of adverse outcomes from PS (mortality, overdose, psychosis, mania, and substance abuse), and quantify the amount of increased risk. This will enable our Partners (OMHSP & PBM) to promote reduced use or increased monitoring of PS in these high- risk groups. We will also quantify risks attributable to prescriber choices, such as prescribing certain forms (immediate versus extended release) or high doses of PS, or choosing to continue PS despite “warning signs” (e.g., tox screen results). Findings will directly inform the PDSI as it occurs. We will then develop an implementable risk score, similar to VA’s opioid risk tool, to help providers assess PS risks for specific patients, who may have multiple risk factors. This study will improve care for thousands of Veterans receiving PS.

PHR: Narrative Myotonic dystrophy causes progressive disability and premature death. This proposal seeks to develop the essential clinical research tools that are needed to evaluate new drug treatments for myotonic dystrophy. The long-term goal is to promote the development of treatments that prevent the disease, slow the progression, reduce the disability, or reverse the symptoms.

PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is an aggressive and difficult to treat cancer, with an overall 5-year survival rate of 9%. PDAC is a leading cause of cancer death affecting the VA population and most of these deaths are the result of cancer metastases. Pancreatic cancer is characterized by a stiff extracellular matrix that increases tissue pressure and shear stress. We recently discovered that these forces enhance pancreatic cancer growth and metastasis. This project will investigate the molecular mechanism by which mechanical forces affect PDAC and provide a strategy for treating pancreatic cancer and reducing metastases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tight regulation of meiosis, the specialized cell division that results in haploid gametes (sperm and eggs) is crucial for proper ploidy (correct number of chromosomes). Perturbations in meiosis can lead to gametes with the wrong number of chromosomes, which is the leading cause of infertility, miscarriages, and birth defects. The results from this proposal will begin to determine the sex-specific mechanisms that contribute to gametes with the correct ploidy providing a further understanding for the differences in male vs. female infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative  Increasing evidence indicates that, in a group of patients, Parkinson’s Disease (PD) may start in the gut and spread to the central nervous system via the vagus nerve. Indeed, gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as gastroparesis and constipation are prodromal to the onset of PD. We have discovered recently a nigro-vagal pathway that modulates colonic motility, and is impaired in an experimental model of PD. Based on our preliminary data, the present proposal aims to investigate the hypothesis that the GI hypomotility observed in PD induces a maladaptive plasticity in the nigro- vagal pathway that favors the progression of PD which, if corrected with therapeutic interventions, will slow down the progression of PD. Results from these studies will provide important translational information that will be used to target vulnerable patients and delay/ameliorate the progression of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The global SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 pandemic, with unprecedented mortality rates of COVID-induced ARDS, has dramatically highlighted the critical role of lung endothelial cell (EC) dysfunction and permeability, the lack of key insights into ARDS pathobiology, the lack of key insights into ARDS health disparities, and the absence of FDA-approved ARDS pharmacotherapies. This competitive PPG renewal application maintains its highly translational focus on a key ARDS target, the lung endothelial cell, and the essential role of the EC cytoskeleton in the pathobiology of ARDS with the vascular endothelium as a highly druggable target to attenuate lung vascular permeability and inflammation and ARDS mortality.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Hazardous drinking is common among Veteran primary care patients and increases risk for more costly and complex medical problems over the long-term. Yet, the vast majority of these Veterans go untreated due to patient, provider, and organizational barriers. By providing an option for care that is easily accessible, private, and self-directed, mobile applications (apps) circumvent many of the often-cited barriers to alcohol use treatment. However, poor patient engagement remains the Achilles’ heel of these apps. Through supportive accountability, Peer Specialists can maximize the reach and engagement of these apps with patients and improve drinking outcomes. If successful, our proposed research has the potential to transform care and increase access to alcohol-related services for Veterans who engage in hazardous drinking but rarely seek treatment, and, in turn, mitigate the adverse health outcomes that stem from untreated hazardous drinking.

PHR: Project Narrative Aging is the greatest risk factor for memory decline and associated pathologies, including Alzheimer’s disease. No treatments exist to slow or reverse memory decline, but this proposal will address this deficit by identifying new genes and small molecule regulators of long-term memory formation. By identifying new candidates involved in long-term memory, these experiments may lead to better therapeutics for maintaining memory function with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Fond du Lac Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Regional Research Institute (FDL-RRI) brings together research, education, and tribal research capacity building in a tribal-led partnership to contribute to national efforts to reduce health disparities, improve mental and physical health outcomes, and ultimately promote health and wellness among American Indians and Alaska Natives (AIAN). Our projects are informed by AIAN key stakeholders and health researchers and have the potential to increase the availability of high-quality AIAN health data through the implementation of innovative science that will ultimately lead to improved health and the reduction of health disparities among American Indian and Alaska Native populations.

ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Direct to consumer (DTC) marketing strategies, in which a service or product is advertised directly to the end user rather than a health care provider, are frequently used and highly effective at driving demand for psychotropic medications (e.g., Avery et al., 2012; Woloshin et al., 2001). DTC marketing may also be effective at driving Veteran demand for evidence-based psychotherapies (EBPs) for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) because advertisements can directly target some of the primary barriers to EBP use. This proposal aims to develop DTC marketing advertisements for EBPs based upon established strategies from the marketing literature (e.g., testimonials, the utility strategy, and the compare/contrast strategy) and with input from Veteran, family member, and other stakeholders. In a randomized controlled trial, we will test their effectiveness at improving Veterans’ attitudes about psychotherapy, intention to seek psychotherapy, and initiation of a psychotherapy referral, compared to control conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will evaluate whether self-management of blood pressure (defined as pharmacist- guided Veteran-driven titration of blood pressure (BP) medications) is more effective than self-monitoring of home BP and the standard care in 160 Veterans with chronic kidney disease (CKD). The study will further evaluate Veteran characteristics that influence the acceptability of and the adherence to the self-management approach. Qualitative analyses will focus on system factors that may facilitate or hinder the implementation of the self-management approach within Veterans Health Administration (VHA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Plant-derived compounds (PDCs) such as gingerol from ginger, allicin from garlic, and carvacrol from oregano can improve bone disorders' healing. This follow-up application's objective is focused on mechanistic understanding of osteogenesis and angiogenesis behaviors of doped HA coatings along with PDCs. Our design goals are to improve bioactivity, introduce osteoinductivity to minimize healing time, and enhance interfacial mechanical properties between the HA coating and the implant to increase the coating in vivo lifetime. This program's scientific understanding will lead to improved long-term fixation of cementless joint replacements and minimize aseptic loosening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Persons with spinal cord injury have paralysis of the muscles necessary to cough and therefore have a high incidence of respiratory tract infections and secondary high mortality. Lower thoracic spinal cord stimulation has been shown to restore an effective cough and improve life quality in these individuals. We plan to develop an electrical stimulation system to restore an effective cough and test this device in a multi- center clinical trial leading to FDA approval and eventual world-wide availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired awareness of hypoglycemia affects one in four adults with type 1 diabetes and prevents them from achieving optimal blood sugar levels to protect them from the long-term complications of diabetes. It also increases the risk of severe hypoglycemia, which can cause loss of consciousness, seizures, accidents and even death. This study will develop better ways to diagnose, classify, predict and treat impaired awareness of hypoglycemia, using the most advanced technologies available, in patients with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Recurrent HG in patients with type 1 diabetes may lead to the potentially lethal condition of impaired awareness of HG (IAH) where the first sign of a low blood sugar is confusion or unconsciousness. The purpose of this project is to perform a randomized clinical trial where a 12-month intervention of HG avoidance education and use of a hybrid closed loop system for insulin infusion is compared to standard care (which includes HG avoidance education, insulin administration via regular pump or injections, and CGM usage) to learn which best restores awareness of hypoglycemia in these patients. Individual physiological and experiential factors will also be collected to determine which exposures and experiences modify the restoration of hypoglycemia awareness and a new diagnostic tool will be tested and validated against standard methodologies.

PROJECT_TITLE: University of Minnesota Clinical Center for the Restoration of Impaired Awareness of Hypoglycemia in Type 1 Diabetes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypoglycemia remains a major barrier to the achievement of adequate glycemic control for most individuals with type 1 diabetes. Moreover, a substantial portion of adults with type 1 diabetes experience life-threatening episodes of severe hypoglycemia, and those with long standing disease complicated by impaired awareness of hypoglycemia (IAH) share the greatest burden of problematic hypoglycemia and its related morbidity and mortality. The present proposal aims to determine whether counterregulatory responses to hypoglycemia can be restored in individuals with long standing type 1 diabetes and IAH using state-of-the-art interventions implemented by an adaptive randomized clinical trial design with outcomes related to measures of physiologic defense mechanisms against the development of low blood glucose, glycemic control derived from continuous glucose monitoring, and participant reported assessment of hypoglycemia problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roughly 1 out of 20 patients living with type 1 diabetes will experience an episode of severe, life-threatening low blood sugar each year. Currently, we do not have ways to identify the patients that are most likely to experience one of these episodes, and we do not have strategies to help reduce that risk. This proposal seeks to address these two large, unmet needs by using continuous glucose monitoring technology to identify the patients at highest risk, and then use up to date management with new insulin pump technologies (called “hybrid closed loop”) to determine if these tools can reduce that risk and keep patients safe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: “Restoration of Impaired Awareness of Hypoglycemia U01 Consortium: University of Kentucky” Narrative For people with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) who must use insulin daily to stay alive, hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) is the rate limiting step in their goals to appropriately control their blood sugar and avoid long-term diabetes complications. People with T1D often develop an inability to sense when their blood sugar is low (known as “impaired awareness of hypoglycemia”) that increases their risk for life-threatening episodes of severe hypoglycemia. This grant application seeks to establish a 10-site clinical consortium to determine if advanced diabetes care technology coupled with intensive hypoglycemia avoidance education will improve their awareness of hypoglycemia and thus decrease their risk for life-threatening low blood sugar events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) The Rural Drug Addiction Research (RDAR) Center brings together basic and applied scientists from neurosci- ence, cognition, simulation, epidemiology, psychology, and sociology to address the etiology, assessment, pre- vention, and treatment of substance use and misuse. In Phase 2, RDAR will enhance the success of investiga- tors competing for external funding and increase the Center’s thematic footprint regarding basic, clinical, trans- lational, and community research by supporting the scientific growth and career development of investigators and fostering interdisciplinary research to investigate substance use and health disparities in Nebraska and the Great Plains. Working with community, university, and IDeA-state partners, RDAR will engage with clinical, com- munity health, and policy sectors to address the challenges of substance use in rural and underserved popula- tions, setting the stage for national, evidence-based impact on this critical health issue and supporting the trans- lation of research into intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses the following public health concerns regarding neonatal seizures: 1) high morbidity rates (40-60%) of permanent disabilities such as cerebral palsy, global developmental delay and post neonatal epilepsy1, 2) knowledge gaps regarding optimal dosing of Levetiracetam for the treatment of neonatal seizures, and 3) critical barriers in developing advanced technology for highly sensitive and specific automated seizure detection algorithms. In the long term, the proposal’s contribution to the fundamental knowledge of neonatal seizure research will impact neurodevelopmental outcomes through refining neonatal seizure treatment (by seizure burden and side effect profile) and rapid detection (with associated rapid treatment) of neonatal seizures.

PHR: The Fond du Lac Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Regional Research Institute (FDL-RRI) brings together research, education, and tribal research capacity building to apply what we know to contribute to national efforts to reduce health disparities, improve mental and physical health outcomes, and ultimately promote health and wellness among American Indians and Alaska Natives (AIAN). Our projects informed by AIAN key stakeholders and health researchers has the potential to increase the availability of high-quality AIAN health data through the implementation of innovative science that will ultimately lead to improved health and the reduction of health disparities among American Indian and Alaska Native populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation therapy is one of the pillars of cancer treatment as approximately half of all cancer patients receive radiation therapy. The overarching goal of this R35 research program is to widen the therapeutic window of radiation therapy by using sophisticated genetically engineered mice, human sarcoma cell lines, and sarcoma patient samples. By dissecting mechanisms of sarcoma development, normal tissue injury from radiation, and tumor response to radiation therapy alone and in combination with immunotherapy, I anticipate that our studies will not only reveal fundamental mechanisms of radiation and cancer biology but will also lead to improved treatment for sarcomas and other cancers.

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is the second most common urologic malignancy; yet, remained a significantly underfunded and understudied cancer type. Major clinical gaps in early bladder lesions [defined as non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC)] include 1) lack of mechanistic insights defining NMIBC progression, and 2) lack of platform for risk stratifying NMIBC that recur but never progress, from those that progresses into MIBC and consequently demonstrate poor prognosis. The knowledge gained by our Center will inform future NIMBC management through 1) the development of novel urinary profiling strategies that could risk stratify aggressive NMIBC (Project 1-3); 2) the identification of targets for future precision intervention, either by enhancing/sustaining the tumor- restraining mechanisms (Project 1) and/or inhibiting the tumor-promoting mechanisms (Project 2).

PHR: The large number of Veterans with chronic low back pain who seek care at the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) are being asked to try non-drug options before higher-risk pain medications. Although there are effective non-drug options, including complementary and integrative health treatments, they can be challenging to access. This research will examine self -administered acupressure for pain relief for Veterans with chronic low back pain. It is a low-risk treatment shown to be effective for people with other pain conditions and can be done virtually anywhere with an app for guidance. This study will engage Veterans an d other stakeholders to help [determine strategies to best integrate acupressure into VHA if effective and offer the app through a Whole Health class at three VA sites and virtually]. This study will contribute to evidence for self-administered acupressure as a treatment for chronic low back pain and begin to examine how it can be sustained system- wide using established resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current biological evidence suggests that light profoundly influences the physiologic capacity with which an organism responds to stress; yet, the ramifications of light on human health and disease remain to be convincingly defined. Our published data highlight that a short exposure to bright blue light can be used to favorably modify the biology and outcome of sepsis. We will now examine the biological and circadian mechanisms underlying our observation that acute exposure to high illuminance blue light during sepsis enhances immune competence and control of the infection, attenuates inflammation, and protects against organ injury. We will then confirm the biological relevance of these mechanisms and blue light therapy in patients with pneumonia. Our characterization of the biological mechanisms through which blue light beneficially alters the cellular response to sepsis provides conceptual and translational innovation to develop a potential therapeutic for the treatment of many diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated hypoglycemia can blunt the usual protective physiological symptomatic and hormonal responses to hypoglycemia, leading to impaired awareness of hypoglycemia that affects up to a third of people living with type 1 diabetes and puts them at increased risk of the morbidity and mortality associated with severe hypoglycemia. Advances in patient education and technology, including continuous glucose monitoring systems and hybrid closed loops can reduce the exposure to hypoglycemia, but have demonstrated limited ability to restore impaired protective counter regulatory and symptom responses to hypoglycemia. The overall objective of this project is to provide a better understanding of demographic, glycaemic and behavioural factors that contribute to restoration of awareness of hypoglycemia, including normalisation of symptomatic and hormonal responses to hypoglycemia, and develop better tools for allowing us to assess awareness and changes in awareness status.

PHR: The IRACDA-MERIT Program is designed to address the growing demand for future faculty who can conduct cutting-edge research and teach effectively. By providing outstanding postdoctoral scholars with formalized research instruction at the Host Institution and teaching instruction at the Partner Institutions, which serve undergraduates from underrepresented groups within the state of Alabama, the IRACDA-MERIT Program meets this need while positively impacting and promoting diversification of the future biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Because of the difficulty in treating chronic pain, development of brain signal predictive biomarkers is of growing interest. Here we propose to develop a predictive biomarker signature of pain severity and duration using two commonly available techniques – electroencephalogram (EEG) and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) – and perform initial clinical validation in first onset temporomandibular disorder (TMD). The biomarker could have utility in identifying patients at high risk of transitioning from acute to chronic pain, and has additional potential for clinical application in the treatment and prevention of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Fibromyalgia (FM) is a chronic non-malignant pain disorder that results from abnormalities in central pain processing and accounts for a major percentage of opioid prescriptions thus contributing to the opioid epidemic. An objective marker identifying FM could confirm the presence of disease and mitigate opiate prescribing for this condition that does not respond to them. We will evaluate the potential of vibrational (infrared and Raman) spectroscopy technology and supervised pattern recognition analysis (“chemometrics”) coupled with complementary metabolomics analyses by LC-MS/MS to differentiate FM subjects from other conditions and identify potential pharmacologic targets of interest for this condition that suffers from a lack of reliable therapeutic options.

PHR: As many as 75% of people with Parkinson’s disease (PD), including many veterans, complain that their PD medications do not work well for them all the time, resulting in "OFF-time". We want to look at how different types of exercise might improve veteran satisfaction with their PD medications. Our data show that patients with PD who did partnered dance aerobic exercise (PDAE) reported less OFF-time. These patients also improved in spatial cognition, endurance and mental quality of life. Although the PD community recognizes exercise as helpful, no one has shown that it actually slows down neurodegeneration in the brains of people with PD. In veterans with PD, we will determine if PDAE reduces OFF-time, and improves cognition. Also, using cutting-edge, new and robust imaging techniques, we will determine if PDAE or another type of aerobic exercise slows neurodegeneration in PD.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Inner ear hypofunction is characterized by subtle compromise without that escape detection by traditional measures of cochlear and vestibular function. They may be associated with loss of synaptic components within sensory structures, but occur without overt loss of sensory cells or neurons. These synaptopathies can be induced by mild ototoxicity resulting in the hypofunction and not complete loss of function. US service personnel and Veterans are exposed to various conditions representing risk factors for vestibular hypofunction, including jet fuel vapors and treatments with known ototoxic agents including aminoglycoside antibiotics. There is recent evidence indicating that it may be associated with dizziness secondary to traumatic brain injury. The proposed research plan represents a comprehensive investigation of peripheral vestibular hypofunction in an animal model through which direct cellular, electrophysiologic, and behavioral correlates will be obtained. In particular, we will test whether vestibular hypofunction is associated with loss of synaptic structures as has been found in the cochlea. Through this research will emerge a novel behavioral test of vestibular function that can be readily translated to the clinical vestibular evaluation, and be implemented as a rehabilitative tool. Hence, the outcomes of this investigation will serve as a foundation for diagnosis and therapy to improve alleviate functional decline.

PHR: Heart disease and diabetes are leading causes of death and disability in the US, especially among Veterans. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a disabling condition that also affects many Veterans. New research suggests that PTSD further increases the risk of developing heart disease and diabetes. What causes this increased risk is unknown. However, individuals with PTSD are often less physically active and make more unhealthy dietary choices than individuals without PTSD. Maintaining a physically active lifestyle, staying physically fit, and eating a healthy diet may be important for reducing the PTSD related risk for heart disease, diabetes and disability. The proposed research seeks to assess how important these lifestyle factors are for reducing the risk of heart disease, diabetes and disability in Veterans with and without PTSD. A better understanding of these lifestyle factors and cardiometabolic health in Veterans will help to clarify how lifestyle interventions can best be applied to the prevention and treatment of long-term disability in Veterans.

PHR: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is prevalent and debilitating chronic disease in Veterans. COPD is highly co-morbid with depression and anxiety conferring greater morbidity and mortality risk. Physical activity is a modifiable behavior that can improve COPD outcomes. However, to date, interventions targeting physical activity have not addressed the high comorbidity between COPD and depression and/or anxiety symptoms (“emotional distress”) despite emotional distress predicting poorer response to physical activity interventions. This CDA-2 proposal will develop and test the feasibility and limited-efficacy of an integrative physical activity and mental health intervention for Veterans with COPD, emotional distress, and low physical activity. The intervention will be delivered via VA Video Connect enabling access to care among Veterans with substantial barriers to hospital-based outpatient care.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: As Veterans transition to community, success in achieving school, work and other goals are top priorities. However, difficulties with concentration, memory, irritability and other symptoms of cognitive-emotional dysregulation can ‘derail’ the life paths of Veterans with traumatic brain injury (TBI), post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and related issues. Many Veterans are interested in approaches to building their personal strengths – approaches that help them help themselves. Barriers to care leave gaps for many Veterans. Our overall mission is to help Veterans build strengths for regulating attention, keeping key information in mind, staying on track, and following through despite challenges in order accomplish goals. This project will provide access to learning experiences to improve brain functioning via tele-rehabilitation. The project will inform Veteran-centered care that Veterans can access at home, in school, and in other settings.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common neurologic disease that is often more aggressive in men than women. As Veterans are mostly men, a higher proportion of Veterans with MS have more advanced disability (i.e., need assistance to walk or use a wheelchair) compared with non-Veterans with MS. Unfortunately, there currently is a lack of evidence to support exercise interventions in people with advanced disability due to MS. This project proposes to study a strength training program using blood flow restriction (BFR) in people with advanced disability due to MS. BFR uses a device that partially blocks blood flow to the exercising limb and causes a response in the muscle which can replicate the effects of high-intensity training using much lower intensities. This is ideal for people with MS who have advanced disability, as they often cannot tolerate higher intensity exercise due to severe weakness and fatigue. By studying BFR training in people with advanced disability due to MS, we hope to help improve strength, mobility, fatigue, and quality of life in Veterans with MS.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Upper extremity limb loss disproportionately affects veterans compared to the general public. Loss of a limb robs the veteran of both function, and equally important, the sense of touch. The loss of touch comes with significant deficits in quality of life and connection to others. Significant investment over the past decade, however, has resulted in advanced prostheses that have significantly greater function than has ever been available and with a sense of touch such that the user feels the prosthesis as though it is their hand. These advances, however, have only been available in the lab. This project is the first randomized clinical trial to evaluate the if these new prostheses provide a better quality of life compared to prior devices. This project is the next critical step toward making advanced prostheses available as standard of care to veterans and to give them a prosthesis option that effectively replaces their lost hand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) are susceptible to repeated episodes of hypoglycemia, which can result in impaired awareness of hypoglycemia (IAH). As a consequence, IAH contributes to diminished recognition of the need for external glucose. This can be a very risky situation for T1D individuals with IAH, possibly leading to coma and in some circumstances, death. The NIDDK is forming the IAH Consortium, which will conduct studies to determine if the most up-to-date management strategies using diabetes technology will restore awareness of hypoglycemia.

PHR: Relevance to the VA: The VA cares for nearly one million veterans with COPD at a cost of more than $5.5 billion annually. COPD profoundly impairs quality of life as it limits ability to work, to maintain physical exertion and to engage in social activities. Hospital-based rehab can decrease the need for inpatient and outpatient medical care and can improve exercise capacity, quality of life and, possibly, decrease mortality. Unfortunately, access to hospital-based VA rehab is insufficient and, over time, the few veterans who attend experience progressive loss of functional gains. We reason that our proposed home-based exercise program augmented by patient-tailored, RAS-enhanced music will overcome the many limitations of hospital-based rehab. Through our innovative program, we expect to enhance the benefits of rehab and better maintain them over time. The easy applicability of our innovative, accessible and economical program has the potential to modify the spiraling pattern of increasing disability and reduce health-care cost and mortality in veterans with COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired hypoglycemia awareness (IAH), present in 25% of people with type 1 diabetes, increases the risk of severe hypoglycemia, which adversely effects their physical and psychological well-being and productivity and impacts their families and communities. Furthermore, the consequent fear of hypoglycemia may lead to reluctance by the person with diabetes and their carers to target optimal glucose levels, thus increasing their risk of long-term diabetes complications. Interventions proposed herein, utilizing widely available tools, will improve our understanding of IAH, should improve hypoglycemia awareness and substantially benefit many people with type 1 diabetes and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders (PIDD), like other rare diseases, have suffered from a lack of clinical trials to study new therapies because of the relatively small number of patients affected with each specific disorder. To address this barrier, we plan to take a new approach to clinical trial design in PIDD, namely the use of a basket clinical trial to study patients with multiple genetic immune disorders that share related mechanistic underpinnings (STAT1 gain of function (STAT1 GOF), STAT3 GOF, STAT5b GOF, and JAK1 GOF) that will be treated with a single, targeted therapy (Itacitinib, a second-generation JAK1 inhibitor) in a phase I/II safety and efficacy trial. Clinical evaluation will be paired with deep profiling of the immune system before and after treatment to judge efficacy in each different disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Down syndrome (DS) is the most common genetic form of intellectual and cognitive disability, occurring in ~1 in 700 live births. DS patients also experience age-related progressive cognitive decline, neurodegeneration, and the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD)-like pathology, for which there are no therapeutic options. The chromosome 21 gene, Dyrk1a, is associated with this progressive cognitive decline and AD-like neuropathology and Iluminos Therapeutics’ unique small molecule inhibitor, which we propose to test in in vivo DS mice and to progress through IND-enabling studies herein, holds significant promise as a first-in-class treatment approach in Down syndrome.

PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VHA) acknowledges greater need for improvement in stroke prevention and post-stroke care. Post-stroke frailty and cognitive decline are significant problems. Identifying novel neuroprotective strategies to improve post-stroke cognition remains a high priority. In the current proposal we will test the treatment efficacy of combining therapeutic hypothermia and whole body vibration on post-stroke cognitive improvement in aged rats. Our study will provide a novel therapeutic approach for rehabilitation of stroke patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide the preliminary data for an R01 application to test an endometrial cancer navigation intervention against usual care using a Type 1, hybrid effectiveness-implementation design. Findings from this future R01 research will contribute to reducing disparities in the treatment and outcomes of rural endometrial cancer patients. Additionally, the current proposal will provide a model for how to effectively design implementation-ready, pragmatic patient navigation interventions to reduce disparities among other medically underserved patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Craniofacial disorders are among the most common birth defects in humans and are often congenital, caused by mutations in protein coding or regulatory sequences of deeply conserved developmental genes active in cranial neural crest cells. To better understand how gene regulatory networks respond to mutations in these conserved genes, we propose using pipefish, seahorses, and seadragons which not only have very unique faces but have also lost several of these genes. Our work will discover how regulatory networks can compensate for the loss of key genes that lead to alterations in craniofacial development and will improve our understanding of the developmental genetic basis of human craniofacial disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE In contrast to acute pain, which is a common and an often-transient experience necessary for survival, chronic pain is a detrimental pathological state that drives changes in the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) and associated prefrontal (PFC) brain regions – needed for cognitive functions, modulation of the descending inhibitory pain pathway and emotion regulation – culminating in high negative affect, cognitive impairments and amplification of pain suffering that defies current treatments. Our proposal seeks to develop a patient-centered, cost- effective alternative strategy – the chemosensory-based Computerized Orbitofrontal Cortex Training (CBOT-Pain) – for rapid and sustained relief of pain and negative affect through home-based noninvasive olfactory stimulation of the canonical secondary olfactory cortex (i.e., the OFC). Accomplishment of the Aims of this proposal would lead to a breakthrough product that closes the unmet need for treatment of more than 700 million people globally with chronic pain and high negative affect through (1) attenuation of chronic pain-associated OFC/PFC shrinkage, (2) rapid and sustained relief of pain and negative affect, and (3) improvement of OFC/PFC-dependent cognitive functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Physicians struggle to assess the true influence on patients of interventions for chronic low back pain. This creates a significant barrier to their ability to help patients rapidly regain their quality of life. This application aims to provide a service for physicians, supported by a disposable and burden-free patient wearable, that can provide quantitative and objective assessments of daily physical activity to support physician decision making.

PHR: Approximately 15,000 Veterans are hospitalized for stroke each year with new cases costing an estimated $111 million for acute inpatient, $75 million for post-acute inpatient, and $88 million for follow-up care over 6 months post-stroke. We have previously established the effectiveness of a backward walking training program to improve gait and balance in post-stroke Veterans. To best serve our Veterans in this era of personalized medicine, there is a current need to determine the appropriate training dose as well as which post-stroke Veterans would most benefit. This study addresses both needs as it will 1) test responses to two different doses (18 vs. 27 sessions) of backward walking training and 2) assess brain activity, measured by magnetic resonance imaging, before and after training intervention to determine its ability to predict rehabilitation response as well as brain mechanisms of behavioral change.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Over 15,000 Veterans are hospitalized for stroke annually, leading to combined costs for acute, post-acute, and follow-on care exceeding $274 million. As the baby boom generation (individuals born from 1946-1964) ages, the prevalence of stroke in Veterans is anticipated to more than double. While stroke can occur at any age, stroke risk doubles by decade after age 55. Male Veterans, who currently average 64 years of age, reveal an 81% increased stroke risk compared to non-veteran age counterparts. Due to the significant impact of stroke on quality of life, improvements in prognosis, intervention, and clinical care are therefore critical to the future of Veterans' healthcare. The large proportion of baby boom era Veterans, disproportionately represented by males with substantially elevated stroke risk, underscores the importance of accelerating discoveries that will maximize recovery, restore activity participation, and optimize quality of life for Veterans with stroke-related disability. Resulting advances in neurorehabilitation will place the VHA at the forefront of this critical healthcare need.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The population of older Veterans with non-traumatic lower limb amputation is growing. Following lower limb amputation, asymmetrical movements persist during walking and likely contribute to disabling sequelae including secondary pain conditions, poor gait efficiency, impaired physical function, and compromised skin integrity of the residual limb. The proposed study seeks to address chronic gait asymmetry by evaluating the efficacy of two error-manipulation gait training programs to improve gait symmetry for Veterans with non- traumatic lower limb amputation. Additionally, this study will evaluate the potential of error-manipulation training programs to improve secondary measures of disability and residual limb skin health. Ultimately, the proposed study aims to improve conventional prosthetic rehabilitation for Veterans with non-traumatic amputation through gait training programs based in motor learning principles, resulting in improved gait symmetry and lower incidence of long-term disability after non-traumatic lower limb amputation.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypothalamic astrocytes form a core, yet incompletely understood, component of the neural circuit underlying reproduction. This project will interrogate to what extent astrocytes regulate elements of the reproductive control circuit and the mechanisms by which astrocytes and neurons residing in this circuit communicate. The findings of this proposal will further our understanding of the mechanisms underlying typical reproduction and may point to novel therapeutic targets for treatment of infertility.
